_Renewables_ Renewable energy continues to be a key priority in NI and the RoI and both governments have set targets for increasing the proportion of electricity sourced from renewables. NI’s energy strategy targets the achievement of 80% renewable electricity by 2030 and the RoI Climate Action Plan also sets an 80% renewable electricity target by 2030. As at March 31, 2023, the Renewables segment owns and operates 309MW onshore wind generation assets across the RoI and NI, and has a pipeline of 49MW onshore wind generation assets under construction and 218MW of onshore wind generation assets in development. The Renewables segment also has a pipeline of 628MW of solar PV projects in development, and is currently commissioning a hydrogen electrolyzer onsite at ----- one of its NI onshore wind farms. In addition, the Group is also progressing the development of two offshore wind generation projects off the coast of Ireland totaling up to 1.8GW. The Renewables segment’s operational and inconstruction onshore wind generation assets are outside of the Restricted Group. Similarly, assets in relation to the pipeline of other wind projects and solar PV projects, are also owned by Unrestricted Subsidiaries and therefore outside of the Restricted Group. The Restricted Group received distribution from the unrestricted subsidiaries under the Existing Notes Indenture totaling €61.8 million during Fiscal Year 2023. The Renewables segment also purchases renewable electricity through PPAs covering 1,247MW of operating renewable capacity as at March 31, 2023. Energia Group was the first independent supplier to participate in the deregulated electricity market and an early mover on offering offtake contracts to third parties. Its first renewable PPA was signed in 2002. The Group estimates that it currently represents approximately 21% of the Irish market for Renewable Obligation Certificates (“ROCs”) and Renewable Energy Feed-In Tariff (“REFIT”) supported wind PPAs. The Renewables segment provides the Energia Group with further access to regulated renewable support mechanisms, with minimal capital requirements and potential upside to the extent of future increases in wholesale power prices, as well as positioning Energia and Power NI as ‘green’ suppliers and enhancing relationships and presence with key stakeholders within the sector. In addition, the Group has a entered into a REFA with Microsoft designed to meet a substantial proportion of their electricity demand in Ireland, whereby the output from the Renewables segment’s pipeline of in-development onshore wind projects (including the 49MW of renewable capacity currently under construction) and solar PV projects are expected to be supported by corporate PPAs with the technology company. Energia Group’s Renewables segment revenue for Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022 was €427.2 million and €401.9 million, respectively, and its Adjusted EBITDA during these periods was €224.5 million and €211.5 million, respectively. _Flexible Generation_ The Flexible Generation segment undertakes trading, regulation and asset management activities on behalf of the Group. This includes the day-to-day operation and commercial optimization of two CCGT plants (Huntstown 1 and Huntstown 2) owned by the Group. The two Huntstown CCGTs are highly reliable, flexible and efficient plants, and their strategic location in the constrained Dublin area ensures at least one unit is running on most days of the year. Moreover, the Huntstown plants have the technical capacity to provide system-critical “Delivering a Secure, Sustainable Electricity System” (“DS3”) ancillary services, the importance of which has been increasing as the proportion of electricity generated by wind in Ireland has been growing. As at March 31, 2023, Huntstown has a total combined generation capacity of 747MW, which is able to supply approximately 10% of peak demand on an all-island basis (based on estimated peak demand of approximately 7,700MW). We believe that the two Huntstown CCGTs are critical to the security of electricity supply in the Dublin area. Under the Single Electricity Market (“SEM”), the Huntstown plants sell the generated energy into the Day-Ahead (“DAM”), Intra-Day (“IDM”) and Balancing Mechanism (“BM”) markets and sell capacity several years in advance via ‘Reliability Options’ as part of the Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (“CRM”). The Reliability Options have been awarded to the Group’s Huntstown plants for the current and next four capacity years, and include a clearing price of €83,050/MW for the capacity year 2026 to 2027. See also “Industry—The _All-Island Single Electricity Market—Energy Trading Arrangements—Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (CRM).” Huntstown sells energy at the market clearing prices in the DAM and IDM as well as receive (or in some_ cases make) other payments for energy through constraint payments in the BM. The Huntstown plants also receive payments associated with DS3 ancillary services. The Group has also recently developed and commissioned a 50MW battery storage project in NI which is operated and traded by the Flexible Generation business. The project has been awarded a 10-year capacity contract commencing in the capacity year 2022/2023, at a clearing price of £78,600/MW for 8.15MW of its 11.3MW derated capacity. The Group plans to develop a further pipeline of battery storage projects, which we expect will strengthen the Group’s position for future capacity auctions and provide an additional source for ancillary revenue. The Group has also entered into a contract with EirGrid to provide 50MW of emergency gas generation located at the Huntstown site for a duration of three years, extendible by EirGrid to five years. Construction of this emergency gas generation project commenced in December 2022 and is planned to be completed by the end of 2023. ----- The Group is developing a 165MW data center at its Huntstown campus in Dublin. The proposed data center has a grid connection offer and the lands necessary for the project have been acquired. Planning consent for the data center was received in April 2022 but the decision was appealed and the planning application is currently being considered by An Bord Pleanála, RoI’s national independent planning body. The Group expects _An Bord Pleanála to issue its decision in the near term and does not believe that there are grounds on which_ planning permission should be refused. The Group has entered into a contract with an international hyperscale technology company for a long term lease by it of the electrical infrastructure, buildings and integrated equipment at the data center. Capital expenditure in respect of the development of the data center was €20.0 million in Fiscal Year 2023 and €11.1 million in Fiscal Year 2022, primarily, in respect of land and development of electrical connections. Going forward, the Flexible Generation segment’s investment in the proposed data center in respect of the development of the data halls is expected to be an unrestricted investment and therefore outside of the Restricted Group. Investment in respect of the purchase of land, the design and build of all the high voltage electrical infrastructure (including a gas insulated substation and high voltage transformer switchyard) will be within the Restricted Group. The Flexible Generation segment also includes the Group’s PPB business which administers 600MW of contracted generation capacity from the Ballylumford power station in NI, which is subject to price control and entitles it to an allowance (effectively a management fee). This legacy PPB contract will expire in September 2023 in accordance with its terms. The PPB contract generated €14.6 million, €8.5 million and €9.3 million of EBITDA during the Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2022 and Fiscal Year 2021, respectively. For Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022, Flexible Generation generated €1,769.7 million and €989.5 million in revenue, respectively, and €204.7 million and €104.0 million in Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, based on, or after taking into account the adjustments for over/under recovery against, the regulated entitlement of PPB. _Customer Solutions_ The Group’s Customer Solutions business operates under the Energia and Power NI brands. Energia Energia is a price control unregulated retail supply business, which supplies electricity and natural gas to residential and business customers in the RoI. Business customers include LEU and SME customers. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, Energia supplied electricity to 14% of the LEU market, 30% of the SME market and 12% of the residential market in the RoI in terms of consumption. As part of its hedging strategy, the Group’s Flexible Generation segment undertakes wholesale electricity, natural gas, carbon and green certificate trading activities on behalf of the Customer Solutions segment. Power NI Power NI is the incumbent electricity supplier in NI, supplying electricity primarily to residential customers. While the residential electricity supply market in NI is open to competition, Power NI remains the biggest supplier with a 55.0% market share of residential supply in terms of consumption during the twelve months ended December 31, 2022. As a result, Power NI is still regarded as the dominant supplier and is therefore subject to price regulation. As a regulated business, Power NI is subject to price control which permits it to recover an allowance calculated by reference to its forecasted operating costs at the time of the relevant price control, plus an allowed margin based on a percentage of forecasted regulated revenue. On January 26, 2023, the UR confirmed the extension of the existing price control (which applies in respect to residential customers) to March 31, 2025. In addition, Power NI supplies electricity to business customers in the unregulated market and secures additional revenues through off-take from certain contracted smaller scale third party renewable generators (which are reported through the Renewables segment). In addition, the Customer Solutions business also offers energy efficiency services and car charging solutions to its customers across Ireland. For Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022, Customer Solutions generated €2,345.2 million and €1,780.1 million in revenue, respectively, and a loss of €162.1 million and €115.4 million in Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, based on, or after taking into account the adjustments for over/under recovery against, the regulated entitlement of Power NI. -----

The Group is a leading integrated Irish energy business active in both Republic of Ireland (“RoI”) and Northern Ireland (“NI”). The Group primarily operates through three business units: - Renewables; - Flexible Generation; and - Customer Solutions. The Renewables business owns and operates 309MW of onshore wind generation assets as at March 31, 2023, and purchases electricity from 1,247MW of renewable generation capacity across Ireland as at March 31, 2023, through off-take contracts (primarily, renewable Power Purchase Agreements (“PPAs”)). In line with the Group’s decarbonization strategy, the Renewables business has expanded in recent years and now has a substantial pipeline of additional onshore wind and solar photovoltaic (“PV”) development projects and has also entered into a renewable energy framework agreement (“REFA”) with Microsoft, which is designed to meet a substantial proportion of their electricity demand in Ireland. The Renewables business is also currently commissioning a hydrogen electrolyzer onsite at one of its NI onshore wind farms and is progressing the development of two offshore wind generation projects off the coast of Ireland totaling up to 1.8GW. The Flexible Generation business owns and operates 747MW of conventional gas-fired generation assets in the RoI and procures power under contract with 600MW of conventional generation assets in NI, in each case, as at March 31, 2023. In addition, under the Flexible Generation business, the Group is currently undertaking the following key initiatives: - 50MW battery storage project in NI, which has been recently commissioned; - 50MW emergency gas generation project under a contract with EirGrid that is currently under construction and is planned to be commissioned by the end of 2023; and - a 165MW data center at its Huntstown campus in Dublin, which is currently under development. The Customer Solutions business supplies electricity or gas to a total of 828,300 customer sites across Ireland, comprising 311,700 customer sites in the RoI and 516,600 customer sites in NI, as at March 31, 2023, through its two retail brands, Energia and Power NI. With a digitally-enabled customer-centric focus, the business also offers energy efficiency services and car charging solutions to its customers across Ireland.

Subsubsection Title: Vertically integrated energy business with growing, predictable and resilient cash flows
Subsubsection Text: Energia Group is a leading vertically integrated energy business active in the energy market across NI and the RoI. The Group enjoys strong strategic positioning in each of its business segments, with revenue generation in each underpinned by one or more of: regulatory support, pro-renewable energy policies, a contracted nature, or a comparative/structural advantage. In particular, Energia Group’s EBITDA is supported by strong regulatory underpinnings. For instance, REFIT supported PPAs in the RoI provide a floor on price per unit of electricity sold, and eligible renewable generators such as our Group receive ROCs for each MWh of electricity generated and consumed within NI (or used in a permitted way), which are freely tradable at auctions and can be sold to suppliers throughout the UK. Furthermore, Power NI Energy is subject to regulated price controls in respect of its residential customer base and its current price control runs to March 31, 2025. Additional factors that should further underpin the Group’s earning resilience include, a long-term lease arrangement with an international hyperscale technology company in respect of the proposed 165MW data center at the Group’s Huntstown campus, corporate PPAs through the REFA with Microsoft, which is expected to support the pipeline of 218MW of onshore wind projects in development and the five-year hydrogen gas purchase agreement with Translink. The Group has a strong track record of resilience through turbulent market conditions. In particular, the Group demonstrated resilient performance through the COVID-19 pandemic, and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, and despite their impact on the commodity environment, the Group’s EBITDA has continued to grow such that the Group’s Restricted Group Adjusted EBITDA (excluding distribution from Unrestricted Subsidiaries) for Fiscal Year 2021, Fiscal Year 2022 and Fiscal Year 2023, was €150.2 million, €121.0 million and €177.6 million, respectively. We believe that our sustained EBITDA growth is driven by our high-quality asset bases, the Group’s vertically integrated business model and credit enhancing investments. Moreover, Energia Group’s vertically integrated structure (comprising supply activities as well as both renewable and thermal electricity generation) provides a natural hedge against volatility in wholesale electricity prices to the extent that the dispatch of the Huntstown plants and the generation of the renewable generation portfolio offsets exposure to retail supply contracts sold. For example, the annual average of electricity purchased for supply by the Energia Group from Fiscal Year 2021 to Fiscal Year 2023 was 6.1TWh, and the annual average of electricity generated and sold by the Energia Group during the same period was 6.2TWh.

Subsubsection Title: Strategically positioned to benefit from attractive market fundamentals reflecting our focus on energy transition and sustainability
Subsubsection Text: The Group also expects to benefit from strong growth and demand. Strong growth in demand for energy is expected across Ireland, particularly driven by population growth, development of data centers in the Dublin region and the electrification of heat and transport across Ireland (Source: Ireland Capacity Outlook). In particular, the Irish system continues to face a potential supply deficit, with capacity shortfall particularly prevalent in Dublin given rapid growth in large energy users and Dublin’s electricity system remains constrained in the medium-term. We believe that given its strategic positioning in each of its business segments, the Group is well positioned to benefit from these market factors in the Irish Market. The island of Ireland enjoys some of the best wind resources in Europe. Renewable energy continues to be a key priority in NI and the RoI and both governments have each set targets for increasing the proportion of electricity sourced from renewables. NI targets achieving 80% renewable electricity by 2030 and the RoI Climate Action Plan also sets an 80% renewable electricity target by 2030. In addition, NI has adopted a “Path to Net Zero Energy” policy, which aims at 48% reduction in net CO2 emissions by 2030 (as compared to 1990). In light of these policies, the governments in Ireland support investment in renewable sources and which in turn strongly supports the Energia Group expansion in the renewables sector in Ireland. In addition, we believe our continued endeavors in renewable energy development will effectively align with and address the stronger investor demand and expectations surrounding ESG commitments.

Subsubsection Title: Extensive Renewables assets and PPA portfolio complemented by system-critical Flexible Generation
Subsubsection Text: In light of the NI and RoI governments’ targets, and in line with its own strategy to build on and diversify its platform of renewable assets to accelerate low carbon growth and increase earnings, Energia Group, through its Renewables segment, has successfully built-out its onshore wind farm portfolio. Its operational owned onshore wind farm capacity has increased from 9MW as at March 31, 2014 to 309MW as at March 31, 2023. The Group currently has 49MW of onshore wind farm capacity under construction supported by a corporate PPA and a further ----- pipeline of 218MW of onshore wind projects in development which are expected to be supported by corporate PPAs with Microsoft. In addition, the Group has a strong presence in the renewables market as a PPA provider to third party wind farms, with 1.2GW of capacity contracted as at March 31, 2023. The Group is a leading developer and operator of renewable energy across the island of Ireland and supplies 21% of renewable electricity in Ireland through 15 onshore operational and wholly-owned wind farms Huntstown 1 and 2 are flexible CCGT plants, benefiting from high efficiency and low CO2 emissions, as well as a strategic location on the outskirts of Dublin. Dublin and the surrounding area represents the highest concentration of customer demand in Ireland, which is expected to grow significantly in the coming years in the context of general economic growth as well as the significant expansion in data center capacity that is projected for the Dublin region (Source: Ireland Capacity Outlook). The Dublin area is also presently characterized by a high level of electricity system constraints. Such system constraints include, for example, voltage control, in which generation is required in a particular area of the electrical system to support local voltage, or load flow control, in which generation is required to enable the efficient flow of electricity. Energia Group’s plants are critical to the security of energy supply and system stability in Dublin and the surrounding area due to existing electricity system constraints, and as such receive energy payments not only based on market clearing prices set on the basis of an “unconstrained” (“in merit”) dispatch (i.e. in a theoretical world where no restrictions or physical limitations on dispatching such electricity exist), but also constraint payments, designed to compensate the plants when they get dispatched “out of merit.” Energia Group’s CCGTs are frequently dispatched “out of merit,” and at any time, at least one of the plants is typically running either ‘in merit’ or on a “constrained” basis to ensure system stability. See “Industry—Generation—Network infrastructure, _constraints and curtailment.”_ The Huntstown plants also receive capacity payments under Reliability Options acquired through the Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (“CRM”). The CRM was established by the regulatory authorities as part of the SEM design to provide an incentive to generators to invest in building and maintaining generation capacity. Huntstown 1 and Huntstown 2 are modern CCGT plants, which the Group believes are among the most reliable conventional plants in Ireland, as evidenced by their high availability levels since being commissioned, with both plants achieving lifetime availability levels of approximately 92%. The Group believes that Huntstown 1 and 2 will continue to benefit from revenues under the CRM due to the overall need for capacity in the SEM and Huntstown plants system-critical role in alleviating the localized constraints in the Dublin area. As at March 31, 2023, both Huntstown plants have secured Reliability Options under CRM auctions for each capacity year to September 30, 2027, being the latest year for which Reliability Options have yet been awarded. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors affecting _results of operations—Capacity and availability.”_ In addition, as flexible and responsive generators, Huntstown 1 and 2 receive certain payments in return for the provision to the system operator of ancillary services necessary for the secure operation of the electricity system. We believe that these services (including operating reserve, reactive power, replacement reserve, synchronous inertial reserve, fast frequency response, ramping margins and fast post-fault active power recovery) are becoming particularly important as the proportion of electricity generated from wind increases in the Irish energy market, with some models suggesting more than 14GW of wind generation capacity to be connected to the grid by 2030 as part of the RoI and NI governments’ endeavors to meet their renewable targets (Source: Ireland Capacity Outlook). Wind is an intermittent and non-synchronous technology, and power demand on the island varies throughout both the day and the year, giving rise to transmission system supply and frequency imbalances. Energia Group’s CCGTs have the technical capability to provide ancillary services under DS3, meaning they are well-positioned to benefit from system service payments.

Subsubsection Title: Digitally enabled Customer Solutions business supporting the energy transition
Subsubsection Text: Energia Group has strong market positions in electricity and natural gas supply across Ireland. In NI, for the twelve months ended December 31, 2022, Power NI remained the biggest residential electricity supplier and had a 55.0% market share in terms of consumption, in a market where the total consumption was 2.855TWh (Source: QREMM Reports). In the NI business supply market, where the total consumption was 4.639TWh, Power NI was the third largest supplier with a market share of 26.0% by consumption for the twelve months ended December 31, 2022 (Source: QREMM Reports). Although the market share of Power NI across all customer classes has fallen since market liberalization, its EBITDA contribution has remained stable, underpinned by the form of Power NI’s current price control, which runs to March 31, 2025, and fixes 70% of its regulated allowance with the remainder variable based on customer ----- numbers, thus limiting the impact of customer attrition on Power NI’s results. The Group believes that Power NI is well-positioned for the future, irrespective of the continuation of its regulated status, as its efficient operations, strong brand awareness and excellent customer service represent significant competitive advantages vis-à-vis other players in the market. While the NI residential supply market has been open to competition since 2007, when Power NI held 100% of the market, Power NI has been able to maintain its competitive advantages and retain strong market share. Power NI generates further revenues through its strong presence in the deregulated business customer segment of the market and through certain smaller scale contracted renewable PPAs. In the RoI, where the total consumption in the business electricity and gas markets was 19.801TWh and 13.987TWh, respectively, for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, Energia had 14.0% and 30.0% market shares, by volume of the LEU and SME business electricity supply segments, respectively, and 14.0% and 13.2% shares of the LEU and SME natural gas supply segments, respectively, making Energia the second largest electricity and fourth largest gas supplier to business customers by volume (Source: Energy and Water Monitoring Report). Energia has a diversified customer base, with a particular focus on single and multi-site SMEs, which we believe represents the most profitable market segment. Energia entered the RoI residential supply market in January 2014. Leveraging the low cost-to-serve billing and customer service platform of Power NI, Energia now serves 280,832 residential sites as at December 31, 2021, including single fuel (electricity or gas) and dual-fuel (electricity and gas) customers. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, Energia held a 12% share of the RoI residential electricity market and 11% share of the residential gas supply market, where the total consumption was 9.381TWh and 7.723TWh, respectively (Source: Energy and Water Monitoring Report). Digitalization remains a priority and the Group continues to progress its development of innovative, enhanced and differentiated product offerings to customers. Accordingly, the Group has invested in the development of a ‘digital IQ’ platform to allow customers greater access and transparency, thereby accelerating the shift to zero carbon. From advanced billing to smart EV charging, the ‘digital IQ’ platform will empower the Group to provide a more efficient and personalized service to its customers. This real-time cloud platform helps reduce costs while improving customer engagement and enabling decarbonization through smart, low-carbon energy technologies.

Subsubsection Title: Proven track-record of earnings resilience and growth along with strong cash flow generation.
Subsubsection Text: Notwithstanding volatile economic conditions and energy markets in recent years, the Energia Group has been able to deliver stable earnings and strong cash flow generation, underpinned by the natural hedge of a vertically integrated energy business and the diversified nature of the business. During the period from fiscal year 2017 to Fiscal Year 2023, the Restricted Group Adjusted EBITDA has increased by a CAGR of 10.0%, and during this period, due to the Restricted Group’s low maintenance capital expenditure requirements, Restricted Group’s cash conversion (defined as Restricted Group Adjusted EBITDA less Restricted Group capital expenditure, divided by Restricted Group Adjusted EBITDA), has averaged 80.8% (Fiscal Year 2021: 86.7%, Fiscal Year 2022: 70.6%, Fiscal Year 2023: 85.2%). Restricted Group capital expenditure excludes capital expenditure on the Group’s data center and offshore wind strategic projects and includes deferred income received in relation to the emergency generation project. Over the last three Fiscal Years, Restricted Group Adjusted EBITDA has averaged €178.9 million, the Restricted Group capital expenditure has averaged €32.5 million. This strong performance has historically also benefitted from diligent and timely management of baddebt levels in the Customer Solutions businesses. This was achieved through proactive credit management, including a focus on creditworthiness at the time of customer acquisition, and the use of prepayment meters and direct debit plans. For Fiscal Year 2023, approximately 35.4% of Power NI’s customers paid using prepayment meters and direct debit payment plans covered approximately 92.0% and a further 39.0% of Energia’s and Power NI’s customers, respectively. In addition, the Customer Solutions business further mitigates the effect of customers defaulting by using credit insurance in respect of certain customers.

We believe that the Group offers a favorable investment opportunity underpinned by credit enhancing data center and renewable investment initiatives. ----- The Group’s proposed 165MW data center at its Huntstown campus in Dublin will benefit from a twentyyear lease term contract with the end user, which is an international hyperscale technology company. The technology company has leased the electrical infrastructure, buildings and integrated equipment (the powered shell) from the Group and has the option to further extend the lease by two five-year periods. The data center is strategically located, adjoining the existing Huntstown power station campus, which enables the Group to maximize profitability from auto producer benefits by co-locating power generation and electricity consumption at the same site. In addition, the end user would pre-fund the construction of the first two phases of the data center and payment from the Group to the end user would be due only at completion. Going forward, the development and construction of the data halls is expected to be financed pursuant to ring-fenced project finance arrangements, entered into by Unrestricted Subsidiaries, and hence outside of the Restricted Group. Consistent with the Group’s decarbonization strategy, the Group has a strong pipeline of renewable projects, including 218MW of onshore wind generation assets and 628MW of solar PV assets in development, 49MW of onshore wind farm capacity under construction, two offshore wind generation projects off the coast of Ireland totaling up to 1.8GW, and a REFA with Microsoft, which is designed to meet a substantial proportion of their electricity demand in Ireland. The Group’s renewable projects are developed pursuant to ring-fenced project finance arrangements, entered into by Unrestricted Subsidiaries, and hence outside of the Restricted Group.

Subsubsection Title: Highly experienced management team with proven ability to deliver against targets
Subsubsection Text: The collective industry knowledge and leadership of the Group’s management team combined with their record of accomplishment in responding to economic conditions and evolving market dynamics are key assets to the business. Under the leadership of its management team, the Group has grown substantially, increasing EBITDA generation by more than €140 million since fiscal year 2017, establishing one of the largest renewable energy businesses in the RoI and NI and being an early mover in innovative new energy-efficient technologies, such as battery storage and green hydrogen. The Group’s management team has a proven track record of consistently delivering superior performance and successfully completing growth strategy projects, such as the build-out of the Group’s owned wind portfolio, including the securing of dedicated, commercially favorable project financing with an aggregate €288.5 million of indebtedness outstanding under project finance bank loan facilities as at March 31, 2023, for these ring-fenced assets. The members of the management team have an average of 23 years of experience with the Group and an average of 25 years of experience in the energy industry and have won numerous awards in the energy sector. The Group believes that the team is highly regarded throughout the industry, has excellent relationships with regulators and government departments, maintains active representation on several electricity and gas industry organizations in Ireland, enhancing insight into and influence on ongoing market consultations, and has been directly involved in the strategic development of the energy markets in which the Group operates. We believe our management plays a pivotal role in Ireland’s ongoing energy transition. The Group also benefits from its ownership by I Squared Capital, an investor focusing on infrastructure, including the energy, utility and digital infrastructure sectors. I Squared Capital has extensive experience and expertise in developing and operating energy and utility businesses across the globe and provides the Group with management experience and technical support. I Squared Capital is committed to implementing sustainable operational improvements through optimization of cost structures and providing management teams with the flexibility to prudently manage cash flows.

Subsubsection Title: Support the decarbonization of the energy system in Ireland
Subsubsection Text: The Energia Group is committed to reducing the carbon intensity of its electricity generation by 50% to 165 gCO2/kWh by 2030 compared to Fiscal Year 2020 levels. The transition to a low carbon economy presents opportunities and the Group continues to implement its Positive Energy investment programme across a range of major renewable energy projects including onshore and offshore wind farms, solar PV power, hydrogen fuel generation and the smart grid. The Positive Energy investment programme is aligned with the Government of RoI’s commitment to increase the proportion of electricity generated from renewable sources to 80% by 2030 and will contribute to further sustainability in Ireland’s energy supply and to the achievement of Ireland’s climate change reduction targets. The Group’s commitment to target a 50% reduction in the carbon intensity of its electricity generation by 2030 compared to Fiscal Year 2020 levels is expected to be achieved through a number of measures including the delivery of its Positive Energy investment programme.

Subsubsection Title: Improve profitability and maintain stable cash flows
Subsubsection Text: The Group seeks to capture available margin and cash flows arising in all parts of the value chain in the Group’s business, both regulated and unregulated. The Group intends to continue to ensure high cash conversion through the consistent delivery of earnings and the ongoing management of maintenance capital expenditure with the average cash conversion over the three years from April 1, 2020 to March 31, 2023 at 80.8% (Fiscal Year 2021: 86.7%, Fiscal Year 2022: 70.6%, Fiscal Year 2023: 85.2%). The Group has renegotiated the original maintenance contracts for the Huntstown plants so that the associated costs are largely variable in relation to operating hours. This allows the majority of LTSA maintenance costs to be recovered as a marginal cost of generation in the Irish electricity market. Furthermore, the Group plans to extend its track record of synergistic deployment of resources across its businesses. For example, the Group benefits from operational synergies between gas and renewable generation, using engineering and management expertise from the established conventional generation business to oversee operations and maintenance in the growing renewable asset portfolio. This has enhanced performance in a costeffective manner. Within the Customer Solutions business, the Group leveraged Power NI’s billing system and mass market operational expertise in the residential retail market when planning and executing Energia’s entry into the competitive RoI residential supply market, resulting in a low-cost market entry and competitive cost to serve. Finally, the Group optimizes its naturally hedged position arising from its vertically integrated structure. Within the Energia Group, management intends to continue to optimize its wholesale portfolio and its complementary positions in supply and generation to ensure stability of earnings and improve profitability. For example, Energia’s gas customer base allows the cost of gas capacity purchased on the gas transmission network to be optimized with the Huntstown plants, making Energia’s customer offerings more cost competitive.

Subsubsection Title: Support the predictability of the Group’s earnings through the diversity of contracted and structurally supported revenue streams
Subsubsection Text: The Group aims to continue delivering excellent performance against price controls for Power NI for the mutual benefit of the regulated businesses and customers. Having delivered a current operational portfolio of 309MW of renewable onshore wind generation, the Group also expects to complete the delivery of additional windfarm projects (with 49MW of onshore wind capacity currently in construction and a further 218MW of onshore wind capacity in development). While the current operational portfolio avails itself of valuable government-backed support mechanisms, such as ROCs and REFIT, which are provided to renewable energy generators, the projects going forward are expected to be supported by corporate PPAs with Microsoft. The Group expects to maintain high availability levels for the system critical Huntstown CCGT plants located on the outskirts of Dublin. The plants both have low minimum stable generation levels thereby giving a wide operational range. The Group believes that their location, their high availability, reliability, and their low minimum generation levels increase the attractiveness of the Huntstown plants to the Transmission System Operator (“TSO”), allowing it to use the plants to accommodate a broad range of variability in wind generation. -----

Subsubsection Title: Deliver integrated energy margin, enhance product offerings and look for opportunities to diversify Customer Solutions’ customer bases
Subsubsection Text: Energia Group seeks to sustain a robust and profitable market share through the entrenched position of its Customer Solutions’ businesses. The Group aims to continue to deliver the integrated energy margin from its customer base and focus on customer retention through technological advances with enhanced and differentiated product offerings while looking for opportunities to increase, diversify and enhance the quality of its customer relationships. This is intended to allow the Group to compete other than on price alone, thus aiming to preserve Group margins. The Group offers additional products and services to residential customers, beyond core electricity and gas supply, in the areas of energy efficiency, boiler maintenance and smart home products, which help differentiate the Group’s offerings and, the Group believes, brings value and convenience to customers. The Group offers energy efficiency consulting services to business customers throughout Ireland and operates a dedicated key account management service for large consumption customers and a sales agent channel for smaller customers. The Group supports and is actively participating in the smart meter roll out in the RoI and the development of “smart services” which integrates smart meters with digital controls over home energy systems such as solar PV, battery storage, electric vehicle (“EV”) charging and heating control. In NI, the Group supplied 47.3% of overall residential prepayment meter customers as at December 31, 2022 and offers a range of online billing and consumption monitoring services tailored to meet customer requirements. Furthermore, for customers who have installed micro-renewables, such as solar PV panels, on their own premises, the Group provides access to the market. The Group continues to focus on maintaining its high-quality customer service proposition to improve efficiency and foster continued and increased customer loyalty. The Group has invested in the development of a ‘digital IQ’ platform (the Group’s software as a service platform) to allow customers greater access and transparency, thereby accelerating the shift to zero carbon. From advanced billing to smart EV charging, the ‘digital IQ’ platform will empower the Group to provide a more efficient and personalized service to its customers. This real-time cloud platform helps to reduce costs, boosting customer engagement and enabling decarbonization through smart, low carbon energy technologies. The Group will continue its focus on maintaining a low level of customer debt compared to industry peers. This has been achieved through a thorough debt management process, including debt checking potential customers and by using prepayment meters as a debt management tool.

Subsubsection Title: Build upon the Energia Group platform to realize complementary growth opportunities accretive to earnings
Subsubsection Text: Management’s continued focus on consistently achieving a high conversion rate of earnings to cash both enables the Group to maintain a prudent capital structure and underpins the potential to capitalize on growth opportunities which are value enhancing through earnings accretion, enhancing the business risk profile, and/or which are otherwise complementary to current operations in supply and generation. Two such areas of opportunity for near-term growth are the expansion of renewables and the development of the Group’s data center at the Huntstown campus in Dublin. _Continue to drive growth through expansion in renewables_ Government targets continue to support Energia Group’s expansion in the renewables sector in Ireland and facilitate the Group’s objective to achieve a balanced and sustainable generation mix and play a leading role in the decarbonization of the energy system across the island of Ireland. The Group aims to increase the volume of renewable electricity generated by it to three times the current levels by 2030. This offers the opportunity to further diversify the Group’s asset base with investments backed by contracted, government-backed renewable support mechanisms or corporate PPAs. The Group has a proven renewable energy development and operational platform, with 309MW of owned onshore wind generation capacity, 49MW under construction and 218MW in development and a pipeline of 628MW of solar PV projects in development, in each case as at March 31, 2023. The Group is well-positioned to take advantage of further medium-term growth opportunities in Irish renewables. These may include strategic acquisitions of development projects, facilitated by our strong presence in the market as a PPA provider with 1.2GW of capacity contracted as at March 31, 2023, as well as by the Group’s relationships with developers and its track record of successfully bringing projects into operation. ----- Furthermore, the Group intends to pursue the development of offshore wind generation capacity in order to further diversify its platform of renewable assets to accelerate low carbon growth and increase earnings. Given the scale of offshore projects and the offshore development, construction and operations experience required to participate in the Marine Area Consent application and/or ORESS2, the Group is exploring the potential to codevelop, through a joint venture, the North Celtic Sea (“NCS”) and South Irish Sea (“SIS”) offshore wind projects, or alternative sites that may be identified. _Drive growth through the Group’s strategically located data center_ EirGrid forecasts a significant growth in energy demand by 2031 from data centers in the Dublin region and the Group is at an advanced stage of development of a strategically located hyperscale 165MW data center at the Huntstown campus in Dublin. The proposed data center has a grid connection offer and the lands necessary for the project have been acquired. Planning consent for the data center was received in April 2022 but the decision was appealed and the planning application is currently being considered by _An Bord Pleanála, RoI’s national independent planning body. The Group expects An Bord Pleanála to issue its decision in the near term and does not believe that there are grounds on which planning permission should be refused. The Group has entered into a contract with an international hyperscale technology company for a long term lease of the powered shell which typically covers electrical infrastructure, buildings and integrated equipment, but with the interior left as raw space to be finished by the tenant at the data center.

Subsubsection Title: Maintain active engagement with customers, local communities and employees, regulators and other key lobby groups
Subsubsection Text: The Group will continue to engage actively with customers, local communities and employees in order to promote constructive outcomes which are positive both for the Group’s businesses and align with the Group’s overall strategic ESG goals. We are committed to helping all customers in their energy transition, from large corporates to the most vulnerable in our society. Energia Group’s Greener Possibilities Fund aims to support projects with a connection to the UN Sustainable Development Goal 13, “Climate Action.” Eleven projects across Ireland were awarded funding under the Greener Possibilities fund, with each of the 11 awarded projects receiving €10,000 to support their project, representing a total award of €110,000. In Fiscal Year 2023 the Group also provided over €1 million to a diverse range of local community groups and charities across Ireland. The Group also actively engages with regulators, government departments and customer representatives. The Group has longstanding relationships with regulatory bodies such as Commission for Regulation of Utilities (“CRU”) and the UR and their relevant sponsoring government departments, and engages with bodies on matters of regulation, competition, price and service. The Group actively participates in the regulatory process with the goal of encouraging fair and practical measures. Management will continue its very active engagement with and participation in the regulatory process to help ensure the interests of the Group are protected. Energia Group also maintains membership in key industry groups, including the Irish Business and Employers Confederation, Irish Wind Energy Association, Renewables NI, Energy Storage Ireland, Irish Solar PV Energy Association, Economic and Social Research Institute, Electricity Association of Ireland, Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry and was a founding member of the Energy Savings Trust. The Group uses its membership within industry groups to pursue renewable support schemes that benefit owners and customers alike, as well as to engage on other regulatory and market matters.

As a leading Irish energy business which operates Renewables, Flexible Generation and Customer Solutions businesses, the Group has an important role to play in the energy transition to renewables the island of Ireland is set to go through in the next decade. In particular, with this existing portfolio and pipeline of renewable energy projects, such as onshore and offshore wind, solar PV, battery storage capacity and hydrogen projects, and digitally focused, smart customer solutions for residential and business customers, we believe the Group has put itself in a strong position to benefit from these changes. Accordingly, the Group’s strategic ESG goals remains focused on continuing its evolution as a modern, technologically sophisticated and customer centric energy business with a strong emphasis on supporting decarbonization in the energy system, continuing to build renewable energy infrastructure, empower customers and employees and support local communities. -----

The Issuer is a designated activity company incorporated under the laws of the Republic of Ireland on December 14, 2022 with its registered office at The Liberty Centre, Blanchardstown Retail Park, Dublin 15 D15 YT2H, Republic of Ireland. The Issuer is registered with the Companies Registration Office under the number 731641.

During April and May 2023, we completed open market repurchases and the cancellation of £9,512,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Existing Sterling Notes and €2,460,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Existing Euro Notes, in each case, funded by cash on balance sheet. Following these open market repurchases and ----- the cancellation of the Existing Notes repurchased, the outstanding aggregate amount of the Existing Sterling Notes is £215,488,000 and the outstanding aggregate amount of the Existing Euro Notes is €347,540,000. On June 22, 2023, we repaid the outstanding cash drawings of £71.0 million, along with accrued and unpaid interest, under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, funded by cash on balance sheet. Each of the above transactions are collectively referred to as the “Debt Repayment Transactions.”

On or after the Issue Date, as applicable, we intend to complete the following transactions (collectively, the “Refinancing Transactions”): - the issuance by the Issuer of the Notes offered hereby; - the execution and delivery of the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement; - the redemption of the remaining balance of the outstanding aggregate principal amount of the Existing Notes (including payment of the applicable accrued and unpaid interest), and the satisfaction and discharge of the Existing Notes Indenture; - the discharge and termination of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, including the closing out or replacement of ancillary facilities (including letters of credit issued thereunder); - the closing out or replacement of certain Hedging Obligations entered into by the Group; - the payment of the TopCo Dividend in an amount of €150 million to be paid by the Group to Energia Group Topco Limited, which we expect to complete on or after the Issue Date; - the Post-Issuance Reorganization, which we intend to complete after the Issue Date; and - the payment of certain costs, fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing transactions, including the fees and expenses to be incurred in connection with the Offering. For descriptions of the Group’s current and anticipated indebtedness following the Transactions, see “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Capitalization.”
The Transactions comprise the Debt Repayment Transactions, which have been completed prior to the date of this Offering Memorandum, and the Refinancing Transactions, each as described below.

Our operating performance for the three months ended June 30, 2023 remains in line with our expectations and the benefit of our vertically integrated business model. Based on preliminary results for the three months ended June 30, 2023, Restricted Group Adjusted EBITDA for the three months ended June 30, 2023 will be in line with the three months ended June 30, 2022. Restricted Group net senior secured debt and leverage will be lower as at June 30, 2023 as compared to March 31, 2023 as a result of continued strong cash generation.
Following March 31, 2023, we completed the Debt Repayment Transactions described above under “— _The Transactions—The Debt Repayment Transactions.”_

In addition to our 218MW pipeline of onshore wind generation assets, we are in the process of acquiring a further wind farm development project located in the RoI. If the acquisition is completed, we plan to develop a 65MW wind generation asset at the site. We expect to pay a consideration in the range of €20 million to €30 million for the project, which we intend to fund from cash on balance sheet. We currently expect to enter into the definitive documents and complete the acquisition before August 2023. Assuming that the acquisition is completed, the acquired entity will be an Unrestricted Subsidiary. -----

I Squared Capital Advisors is an independent fund manager, registered as an investment advisor with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, that specializes in investing and managing infrastructure assets globally, with a focus on Europe, North America, Asia and Latin America. I Squared Capital targets high quality, resilient infrastructure assets in the energy, utilities, transport, digital, and social infrastructure sectors. I Squared Capital had $37 billion of assets under management as at March 31, 2023. Energia Group is being managed in line with I Squared Capital Advisors’ investment philosophy of being a responsible infrastructure investor focusing on strong operational value creation, proprietary risk methodology, and downside protection. -----

The diagram below illustrates, in simplified form, the Group’s corporate and financing structure after giving effect to the Transactions as described in “Summary—The Transactions.” The diagram does not include all entities in the Group, nor all of the debt obligations thereof. For more details on the debt obligations identified in this diagram, see “Capitalization,” “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Description of the Notes.” (1) I Squared Capital Funds is the indirect principal shareholder of the Company. As at the Issue Date, the Group expects that I Squared Capital Funds will beneficially own 89.75% of the common equity of the Company. See “Principal Shareholder.” (2) The Notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer and will rank pari passu in right of payment with all other existing and future senior debt of the Issuer. The Group intends to utilize the gross proceeds of the Offering, together with a portion of cash on balance sheet, to complete the Refinancing Transactions by (i) redeeming the remaining balance of the outstanding aggregate principal amount of the Existing Notes (including payment of accrued and unpaid interest), (ii) paying the TopCo Dividend and (iii) paying certain costs, expenses and fees in connection with the Refinancing Transactions. See and “Summary—The _Transactions,” “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.”_ (3) The Group intends to enter into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement on or about the Issue Date. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will, among other things, provide for revolving commitments of up to €450 million, including a €125 million sub-limit applicable to cash loans (although such sub-limit may be exceeded solely to provide cash security deposits as an alternative to or replacement for obligations under a standby letter of credit). The Revolving Credit Facility may be used for general working capital and other corporate purposes and will, the Group anticipates, primarily be used for letters of credit and bank guarantees (including by way of ancillary facilities on a bilateral basis with individual lenders, using such lenders’ revolving facility commitments). The original borrowers under the Revolving Credit Facility (including ancillary facilities) are Energia Group NI Holdings Limited and the Issuer. The Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed by the Guarantors concurrently with the Notes. The Revolving Credit Facility will be secured, on or about the Issue Date but in any event no later than within 10 days of the Issue Date and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under the Notes, by first priority security interests over the Collateral. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and certain hedging agreements that are secured by assets that also secure obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees, will receive priority with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over any such assets. As at March 31, 2023, the Group had £71.0 million in principal amount of cash drawings and a euro-equivalent amount of €236.8 million of letters of credit outstanding under ancillary facilities, in each case, made available pursuant to the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. On June 22, 2023, the Group repaid the outstanding cash drawings of £71.0 million under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility along with accrued and unpaid interest, by utilizing cash on balance sheet. On or about the Issue Date, the Group expects to roll over its existing letters of credit into new ancillary facilities under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, and discharge and terminate the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. See “Summary—The Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds.” ----- (4) The Issuer is a designated activity company limited by shares incorporated on December 14, 2022 under the laws of the Republic of Ireland with its registered office at The Liberty Centre, Blanchardstown Retail Park, Dublin 15 D15 YT2H, Republic of Ireland, Republic of Ireland. The Issuer is registered with the Companies Registration Office under the number 731641. (5) The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Company and certain of its direct and indirect subsidiaries. The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Certain _Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of Guarantees and Security.” The Guarantees_ may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—Note Guarantees—Releases of Note Guarantees.” For the year ended March 31, 2023, the Issuer and the Guarantors generated 32.4% of the Group’s consolidated Adjusted EBITDA (excluding all intragroup items except the allocations of intercompany costs from the Huntstown plants and the intercompany PPA revenue from the Unrestricted Subsidiaries) and as at March 31, 2023, held 54.0% of the Group’s consolidated total assets (excluding Consolidation Adjustments). For the year ended March 31, 2023, excluding Unrestricted Subsidiaries, the Guarantors generated 48.7% of the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA (excluding all intragroup items except the allocations of intercompany costs from the Huntstown plants and the intercompany PPA revenue from the Unrestricted Subsidiaries), and as at March 31, 2023, held 73.0% of its consolidated total assets (excluding Consolidation Adjustments). For the year ended March 31, 2023, excluding Unrestricted Subsidiaries, Power NI Energy Limited (which is not permitted to guarantee the Notes for regulatory reasons) and Derrysallagh Supply Limited (which will not guarantee the Notes as it effectively ceased trading on October 1, 2022, following the transfer of its long-term power purchase agreement to Energia Customer Solutions Limited), the Guarantors generated 126.7% of the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA (excluding all intragroup items except the allocations of intercompany costs from the Huntstown plants and the intercompany PPA revenue from the Unrestricted Subsidiaries), and as at March 31, 2023, held 94.0% of its consolidated total assets (excluding Consolidation Adjustments). The Notes and the Guarantees thereof will be secured on a first priority basis by the Collateral. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and certain hedging agreements that are secured by assets that also secure obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees, will receive priority with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over any such assets. The Guarantors’ obligations in respect of the Notes may be released in certain circumstances. In addition, the security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to the Notes,” “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor _Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—Security.”_ (6) Consists of immaterial subsidiaries, Power NI Energy Limited, which is not permitted to guarantee the Notes or the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement for regulatory reasons and, Derrysallagh Supply Limited, which will not guarantee the Notes as it effectively ceased trading on October 1, 2022, following the transfer of its long-term power purchase agreement to Energia Customer Solutions Limited. After the Issue Date, we intend to complete the Post-Issuance Reorganization, whereby certain non-Guarantor Restricted Subsidiaries, namely ElectricInvest (Lux) ROI S.à r.l., Energia Capital Limited, Viridian Enterprises Limited and Choices Pension Scheme Limited, may be dissolved, liquidated, merged or consolidated, or may otherwise cease to exist. (7) The following renewable asset and renewable development companies will be Unrestricted Subsidiaries under the Indenture: Eshmore Ltd, Clondermot Wind Limited, Lisglass Wind Ltd, Whaplode Limited, Energia Offshore Wind Limited, Long Mountain Wind Farm Limited, Thornog Windfarm Ltd., Gortfinbar Windfarm Limited, Altamuskin Windfarm Limited, Mosslee Limited, Windgeneration Ireland Limited, Holyford Windfarm Limited, Energia Renewables Company 3 Limited, Wheelhouse Energy (NI) Limited, Cornavarrow Windfarm Ltd., Slieveglass Wind Farm Limited, Teiges Mountain Wind Farm Limited, Energia Renewables Company 4 Limited, Dargan Road Biogas Limited, Coolberrin Wind Limited, Energia Bioenergy Limited, Energia Renewables Company 2 Limited, Pigeon Top Wind Farm Ltd., Derrysallagh Windfarm Limited, XMR Energy Limited, Energia Solar Holdings Limited, Solar Farmers Limited, Seven Hills Wind Limited, Energia Hydrogen Limited, Energia Data Centre Limited, Drumlins Park Limited, Gaofar Limited, North Celtic Sea Offshore Renewables Limited, North Celtic Sea Offshore Windfarm Holdings Limited, North Celtic Sea Offshore Windfarm Limited, South Irish Sea Offshore Renewables Limited, South Irish Sea Offshore Windfarm Holdings Limited, South Irish Sea Offshore Windfarm Limited and a direct subsidiary of Energia Renewables ROI Limited, which is expected to be acquired on or prior to the Issue Date as described under “Summary—Recent developments—Potential wind farm acquisition” in this Offering Memorandum. Each Unrestricted Subsidiary listed above will not guarantee the Notes or the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and will not be subject to the restrictive covenants contained in the Indenture. The unrestricted entities listed above generated Adjusted EBITDA of €87.3 million for the year ended March 31, 2023. As at March 31, 2023, the Unrestricted Subsidiaries held 26.0% of the Group’s consolidated total assets (excluding Consolidation Adjustments) and had an aggregate €288.5 million of indebtedness outstanding under project finance bank loan facilities, which are secured on a non-recourse basis over the assets and shares of the specific project finance companies that are party to each respective facility. -----

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption: ............. The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at any time on or after      ,

See “Description of the _Notes—Optional redemption.”_

See “Description of the _Notes—Redemption for taxation reasons.”_

A “change of control” will not be deemed to have occurred on one occasion if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded as a result of such event that constitutes a Specified Change of Control (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Certain definitions—Specified Change of _Control Event”). Subsection Title: Certain covenants: ................... The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Issuer, the

Subsubsection Title: Our businesses are subject to complex governmental legislation and regulations that have affected, and may in the future affect, our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We operate in a highly regulated environment and our businesses are subject to a wide range of complex governmental legislation and regulation, including those overseen by regulatory bodies in the RoI, the UK and the EU, including the UR and the DfE in NI, the CRU and the DECC in the RoI, as well as the SEM Committee (the decision-making authority for the SEM which comprises representatives from the CRU and UR in addition to an independent and deputy independent member) on an all-island basis. Regulation impacts numerous aspects of our business and industry including, but not limited to, overall market structure and design, construction and operation of generation facilities, acquisitions, disposals, recovery of costs and investments, return on Power NI’s and PPB’s regulated business activities, market behavior rules, support mechanisms for renewable generation, present or prospective wholesale and retail competition and environmental matters. We are also subject to general competition rules and pro-competition government policies. In response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine the EU and the UK have imposed comprehensive trade restrictions on Russia as well as significantly expanded the existing sanctions against individuals and entities. Furthermore, as a direct response to the energy crisis and in order to enhance protection for domestic electricity and gas customers in the RoI, the RoI Government introduced a moratorium on disconnections for the 2022-2023 winter period. The moratorium on disconnections was one of a number of measures in place to protect domestic customers who engage with their suppliers regarding the management of debt and a further review of customer protection measures that are in place with suppliers and will be undertaken by the RoI Government before the 2023-2024 winter period. These rules, policies and trade restrictions have affected, may continue to affect or have the potential to affect the operation of our business and any changes to such rules could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, we are subject to applicable public procurement laws, including the EU Utilities Directive. Changes in, revisions to, or reinterpretations of existing or pending laws and regulations may have an adverse effect on our businesses. Further, our ability to take actions and implement new policies may be constrained by government regulations. As a result of the third EU energy package, the Clean Energy for all Europeans package and EU regional integration initiatives in the electricity and natural gas sectors, regulators are required to monitor the level and effectiveness of the opening of markets and the development of competition in the supply of electricity and natural gas to final customers. This requires suppliers, including us, to provide additional information to regulators relating to retail business activity, including contractual and tariff information, level of customer switching to alternative utility providers, customer debt and payment plans, disconnection levels, customer complaints, and retail margins. This level of increased transparency may result in regulators taking actions that have an adverse effect on our retail businesses. Suppliers may also be required to include the end date of customer contracts on their bills, provide customers with clear prompts when contracts are coming to an end, notify customers of the benefits of switching suppliers, and provide customers with estimated annual bills. These may require changes to our IT systems. Suppliers are also subject to additional compliance requirements related to safe-guarding customer information, implemented through regulator-approved customer charters and codes of practice. Failure to comply with these additional consumer protection measures could result in sanctions or revocation of our supply licenses. The rules to which we are subject, and the licenses under which we operate, are complex and subject to interpretation. In the event our interpretation is inconsistent with one taken by the relevant regulatory authority, we could lose certain benefits, or be required to reallocate certain revenues and expenses across our regulated and ----- unregulated businesses. Changes in regulation may also require us to invest in maintenance or other improvements to our generation facilities or result in costs of operation no longer being recoverable in the market. Any such expenditures could adversely affect our financial condition. In addition, we may be subject to, or requested to participate in, regulatory inquiries, reviews, or investigations from time to time. There can be no guarantee that the findings of such inquiries, reviews, or investigations will not result in regulatory changes that could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our development assets are subject to planning consent and licensing regimes in the jurisdictions in which they are located, which are constantly subject to change and in the case of offshore wind projects in some instances still evolving. There can be no assurance that any or all of the planning permissions and licensing regimes our assets are subject to will not become more restrictive in the future or that we will be successful in meeting or complying with these requirements. For instance, planning consent for the proposed data center at our Huntstown campus in Dublin, RoI, was received in April 2022 but the decision was appealed and the planning application is currently being considered by An Bord Pleanála, RoI’s national independent planning body. The Group expects An Bord Pleanála to issue its decision in the near term and does not believe that there are grounds on which planning permission should be refused. However, there can be no assurance that such consents will be obtained in a timely manner or at all. In addition, our operating assets are subject to planning compliance conditions such as noise and shadow flicker, which are reliant on third party technology and which is not guaranteed to meet the compliance levels, as well as environmental requirements, which may also be dependent on third party landowners cooperation and compliance with contractual arrangements. Such arrangements cannot be guaranteed over a project lifetime, and therefore, there can be no assurance that the Group complies, or will continue to comply, with any of these conditions, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Further, while we benefit from regulatory price controls in relation to Power NI and PPB, these price controls are subject to regulatory intervention, which could reduce the prices that Power NI is able to charge for the supply of electricity to customers in regulated categories in NI, even if its costs increase or remain the same, and can therefore negatively affect our results. A reduction in prices or regulated entitlement as a result of changes to the price controls could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We face growing competition in each of our markets, which could lead to a loss of customers, reduced margins, an adverse effect on our retail strategy or reduction in profitability on renewal of PPAs.
Subsubsection Text: We face growing competition in the electricity and natural gas supply markets in which we operate from both established market participants and new market entrants that could adversely affect our market share in both the residential and business sectors. Our principal competitors in NI business electricity supply markets are SSE Airtricity, Electric Ireland and Go Power. The main competitors in the residential market are SSE Airtricity, Electric Ireland, Budget Energy and Click Energy. New competitors may enter either one or both of the business electricity supply or residential electricity supply markets in the near to medium term. The form of Power NI’s current price control, which runs to March 31, 2025, ensures 70% of its regulated allowance is fixed, with the remainder variable based on customer numbers, which has the effect of limiting the impact of customer attrition on Power NI’s results. While such a provision remains in place, nevertheless, the impact of competition by new entrants or an increase in capacity of existing market participants may, in the longer term, have a material adverse effect on Power NI’s business, financial condition and results of operations. In the RoI’s competitive retail electricity and natural gas markets, our principal competitors are the local incumbent utilities, Electric Ireland and BGE, which have the advantage of long-standing relationships with their customers. Our other competitors include SSE Airtricity, Pinergy, Panda Power and PrePay Power. It is also possible that substantial new entrants from outside Ireland may enter the energy market, further increasing competition in our market. Furthermore, the Group supports and is actively participating in the Government’s smart meter roll out in the RoI and is committed to the development of “smart services” which integrate smart meters with digital controls over home energy systems such as solar PV, battery storage, EV charging and heating control. However, there is a risk that the Group may not be able to develop the products and tariffs to satisfy customers’ demand for “smart services” and therefore may, in the longer term, have a material adverse effect on Customer Solutions’ business, financial condition and results of operations. In both the RoI and NI markets, certain of our competitors or potential competitors may be larger or better capitalized than us or they may be government-owned, as is currently the case with Electric Ireland. These competitors may be able to offer lower prices or other incentives that may attract customers away from us, thereby reducing our market share, which, in turn, may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition ----- and results of operations. Furthermore, when electricity prices increased significantly as a result of the energy crisis and high commodity prices, there was a reduction in the levels of churn of customers to other suppliers. As commodity prices have stabilized since early 2023, it remains to be seen what the medium to longer-term impact is on customer churn. Our results may be adversely affected if we have to give further discounts to customers or increase our operational costs to reduce the churn of customers to other supply companies. The Group has a 1.2GW portfolio of contracted PPA capacity as at March 31, 2023, the majority of which is underpinned by government-backed renewable support mechanisms. When originally entered into the NIRO, PPAs were typically for a 20-year term and the REFIT PPAs were for 15 years. Some of the Group’s older PPAs have expired and a number of other PPAs will expire in the years ahead. The Group will therefore be required to negotiate renewal terms with generators ahead of the expiry of PPAs in order to agree on commercial terms for the renewal of the contractual agreement between those renewable generators and the Customer Solutions businesses. The Group faces competition from other suppliers in the market as well as corporate PPA offtakers, which could result in commercial terms not being agreed with generators or the achievement of commercial terms which are significantly less favorable or profitable for the Customer Solutions businesses, and therefore this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: The rules of the Single Electricity Market are complex and could adversely affect our revenues and/or undermine the long-term viability of our power generation assets and therefore adversely impact our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The rules of the SEM, which came into effect on May 23, 2018, are complex and affect the major revenue streams of all generators, thermal and renewable, who sell into the market. While freely bidding into the ex-ante physical energy markets in the SEM, the Huntstown plants can be required to generate to relieve constraints, placing them in the balancing market. Participation in this market is mandatory; moreover, maximum bids they can offer for balancing actions are regulated. The SEM rules contain prescriptive and detailed costing rules defining which elements are considered to fall within allowable “short run marginal costs,” placing restrictions on the costs the Huntstown plants may take into account when setting their bids in the balancing market. This could preclude the recovery of legitimate short run marginal costs associated with running the plants. The capacity remuneration mechanism operates through capacity auctions, open to owners of physical generation assets and other providers of capacity, that award Reliability Options to successful bidders at the market clearing price. A Reliability Option is a one-way contract for difference, entered into between a generator and a central agency, that incentivizes a generator to generate electricity at times of market spikes in exchange for a fixed payment, while foregoing incremental revenue (by means of a ‘difference payment’) when the market price is above a defined strike price. The capacity remuneration mechanism also includes the possibility that Reliability Options may be awarded on an elevated pay-as-bid basis within certain constrained network areas, or that a targeted contracting mechanism could be used to provide sufficient income to support continued operation of system-critical generation capacity required to ensure security of supply (which may require State aid clearance). The maximum bid that may be submitted by an existing generator in the capacity auction is limited, by rule, to half the estimated net cost of new entry of a new dispatchable power plant, unless a higher unit specific price cap is applied for and granted to a generator. For the CY 2027/28 T-4 capacity auction, the existing capacity price cap is €54,586/MW/year, although the granting of unit specific price caps could potentially increase this figure if any plants receive such caps. As a result of the competitive auction process, the Group faces uncertainty with respect to the pricing and remuneration of its capacity. For example: - Due to the amount of generation capacity across the island of Ireland, generators might offer very low prices per MW of contracted capacity, in an effort to win Reliability Options at the auction. Depending on the number of bidders and the prices they offer, our Huntstown plants may not win Reliability Options at auction or may win Reliability Options only at unattractive prices. Alternatively, we may attempt to bid our Huntstown plant, which operates in the constrained Dublin area system, at its maximum allowable bid (which would be the existing capacity price cap of €54,586/MW/year, unless we were granted a higher unit specific price cap) on the expectation that we would receive a Reliability Option and be paid at our bid price, notwithstanding our high bid, due to the limited availability of alternative generation capacity within the constrained Dublin area system. However, there can be no assurance that we would win a Reliability Option under those circumstances, or that the Dublin-area constraints will not eventually be alleviated through the construction of new infrastructure, which would reduce our ability to win Reliability Options when bidding at the cap; ----- - The requirement of a generator to make difference payments under a Reliability Option during price spikes, which could be triggered by administered scarcity pricing, would result in a generator holding a Reliability Option suffering negative cash flow, which could only be offset if that same generator was selling power into the market at the prevailing elevated spot price.
