If we win Reliability Options in respect of our generation capacity, we run the risk that if we fail to operate at our contracted capacity during spot market price spikes, we will not receive elevated market revenue to offset the cost of the difference payment we would be required to make. While there are certain ‘stop loss’ limits in case of outages, even relatively short outages during periods of price spikes could result in net negative cash flows in respect of the Reliability Option awarded to us; - Some capacity auctions are scheduled up to four years ahead of the Reliability Option period and with such a delay we bear the risk that, even if we bid the maximum allowable price, our plant costs may change in the intervening period, rendering our bids uneconomical and resulting in losses if we were to win a Reliability Option and be required to deliver such capacity. This problem is exacerbated by the fact that the maximum value of a bid is set by the regulators based on an assessment of market conditions at the time of bidding. To the extent that we place a successful bid in the capacity auction at below cost and do not receive sufficient additional revenues from other sources, we may operate at a loss; - In 2018, the Group secured four-year local reserve service agreements (“LRSAs”) for both of the Huntstown plants, which expired on September 30, 2022. The LRSAs ensured that the Huntstown plants continued to be available to meet security of supply in the Dublin area whilst providing sufficient remuneration to the plants for services provided in the SEM market. Although the LRSAs have since expired, there could be a potential risk that the award of those contracts is subject to challenge or the European Commission’s decision to approve State aid for the Irish capacity market could be subject to challenge; - In future years there can be no guarantee that the SEM Committee will maintain the existing capacity price cap at the current level set of €54,586/MW/year for the CY 2027/28 T-4 capacity auction. As a result, we could receive prices that do not cover the fixed costs of the Huntstown plants; - The Irish Capacity Remuneration Mechanism received State aid approval from the European Commission in November 2017 for a period of 10 years starting from the day the reformed SEM market entered into force, which was October 1, 2018. This means that capacity auctions can continue to take place up to October 2028 under the current State aid approval. The continuation of capacity auctions beyond October 2028 is subject to renewed State aid approval. Should the Huntstown plants not be adequately remunerated in SEM, it may not be economically viable for either or both of them to continue to operate. The RoI Grid Code purports to require a generator that wishes to cease to operate to give three years’ notice of such intention. If the Huntstown plants were required to operate for three years in such circumstances, it could have a material adverse effect on the Group’s results of operations and financial performance. Where a generator cannot comply with a provision of the Grid Code it may apply for a derogation from the relevant requirement. If the CRU considers that the grounds for the derogation are reasonable, then the CRU shall grant such derogation unless the derogation would, or it is likely that it would, have a materially adverse impact on the security and stability of the transmission system or impose unreasonable costs on the operation of the transmission system or on other users. Given that the Huntstown plants are frequently constrained on to provide system critical support in the Dublin region, there is a risk that the CRU may seek to enforce the purported notice requirement and/or seek to deny a derogation and if the CRU were able to sustain such a position the Huntstown plants would be required to continue to operate. In the event that the Huntstown plants ceased to operate (whether having been required to fulfil the three year’s notice or otherwise) we would incur the loss of the revenues associated with the operation of the Huntstown plants and any costs arising from ceasing to generate and may sustain reputational damage from ceasing to operate system-critical plant. If any of these risks were to materialize, our revenues may be reduced and/or additional costs incurred, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial performance.

Subsubsection Title: Fluctuations in market prices of electricity, changes to renewable support mechanisms and the availability of generators may adversely affect our wind farm generation and PPA results.
Subsubsection Text: Our profitability and potential growth is influenced by the prices we receive for the electricity we generate. The Renewables business in the RoI is supported by the REFIT regime, which protects us from downside market price fluctuations below the REFIT base price level. Above this level, revenues are dependent on wholesale ----- electricity prices and are subject to volatility. Volatility in electricity prices, which can be impacted by commodity prices for coal, oil, natural gas and carbon, and, in particular, a drop in the prices for such traditional energy fuels, may cause electricity generated from wind power to achieve a lower than anticipated market price for electricity and adversely affect our business. Throughout Fiscal Year 2022, the commodity markets for gas and carbon experienced sustained periods of volatility and increasing prices, which resulted in higher market prices for electricity. Geopolitical circumstances caused further volatility in the wholesale commodity markets in Fiscal Year 2023, resulting in periods of higher market prices for electricity. Customer demand and the amount of energy generation on the system, including the amount of wind, can also impact market prices. A sustained reduction of market prices could adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. See “—Government _price interventions and/or reductions in governmental support for renewable energy sources in general, or wind farms in particular, may adversely affect our operations.”_ Our Renewables businesses in NI benefit from the Renewables Obligation (“RO”) regime and attract ROC revenues and revenues from wholesale electricity prices, as described above for the RoI (see also “Business—Group activities and reporting segments—Renewables”). The Renewables business obtains income from ROCs, through both direct bilateral sales in auctions with suppliers who require additional ROCs to meet their obligations and through obtaining its portion of the recycled buyout fund payment, which Ofgem distributes each year to electricity suppliers in respect of the ROCs held by them. The value of the buyout fund payment is based on the aggregate buyout payments Ofgem receives from electricity suppliers who did not meet their RO obligations in the relevant compliance period. However, the Renewables business cannot know in advance or control the prices or the payment they will receive each year. A material downward fluctuation in the market prices of electricity and ROCs, or the size of the recycled buyout fund may have an adverse effect on our financial results. Furthermore, any changes to the existing RO regime in the UK or the implementation of a new support in NI to replace the existing NIRO support could have a negative impact on the value of ROCs in NI, including those we hold from time to time. See “—Government price interventions and/or reductions in governmental support for _renewable energy sources in general, or wind farms in particular, may adversely affect our operations.”_ In addition, parties to our PPA agreements and the Group’s own wind farms may experience reduced electricity generation revenues as a result of generator faults, gear box rebuilds, grid availability issues or other mechanical failures, which could have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, or financial condition. See “Industry—Generation—Support for renewable energy.”

Subsubsection Title: Our business and our service providers are susceptible to cyber-security failures, which could adversely affect our business, reputation, financial condition, and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The Group and its service providers are susceptible to operational, information security, and related “cyber” risks, both directly and through their service providers. Cyber incidents can result from deliberate attacks or unintentional events and may include, but are not limited to, gaining unauthorized access to digital systems (e.g., through “hacking” or malicious software coding) for purposes of misappropriating assets or exfiltrating sensitive information, corrupting data, or causing operational disruption. Cyber-attacks may also be carried out in a manner that does not require gaining unauthorized access, such as causing denial-of-service attacks on websites (i.e., efforts to make network services unavailable to intended users). Recent geopolitical tensions may have increased the risk and scale of deliberate cyber-attacks, particularly those from nation-states or from entities with nation-state backing. There is a risk that the Group may be unable to protect itself from a nation-state cyber-attack due to their advanced cyber capabilities. Substantial costs or regulatory fines may be incurred by the Group in order to resolve or prevent cyber incidents in the future. While the Group has implemented information security management measures in light of its operations, industry, and associated risks, as well as established disaster recovery plans and business continuity plans in the event of, and cyber-security risk management systems to prevent, such cyber incidents, there are inherent limitations in such plans and systems, including the possibility that certain risks have not been identified, that prevention and remediation efforts will not be successful or that cyber-attacks will go undetected. For instance, as a precautionary measure, we have in the past temporarily suspended the use of third-party supplier systems for suspected cyber-security incidents. However, there has been no material adverse effect on our systems as a result of such suspensions. Furthermore, the Group cannot control the cyber-security plans and systems put in place by its service providers. The Group could be negatively impacted as a result. Cyber-security failures of, or breaches of, the Group’s systems and other service providers’ systems have the ability to cause disruptions, impact business operations and could result in significant costs, including ----- investigation and remediation expenses, regulatory scrutiny, legal liability and the loss of personal or sensitive information, and could have a material adverse effect on our business, reputation, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: Mechanical failure, equipment malfunction or technological breakdown could adversely affect our business and operating results.
Subsubsection Text: The successful operation of our business depends upon maintaining the integrity of our key systems and equipment, such as the Huntstown plants, our portfolio of wind farm assets, trading systems, our hydrogen generation and battery storage assets, and our integrated IT systems. Our systems and equipment are vulnerable to mechanical failure, equipment malfunction, technological breakdowns or other interruptions from events, certain of which are beyond our control, including: - fire, flood and other natural disasters; - adverse weather conditions; - trips in the electricity grid, in particular to the extent that these are not compensated through the SEM; - failure of the natural gas transportation network; - mechanical, technology or electrical failures; - telecommunications or data network failures; or - unauthorized physical or electronic access, including cyber-attacks. Systems or equipment failures could also affect or damage our facilities and our electricity production capacity could be materially adversely impacted as a result. It could also take longer than expected to repair damaged facilities due to delays in the supply chains, many of which are international, used by the Group. While we maintain standard business interruption insurance for our wind farm assets and the Huntstown plants and have disaster recovery plans and prevention policies in place, any damage or interruption (for example, an unexpected outage at the Huntstown plants leading to a service interruption) could cause a significant disruption to our operations. From time to time, we experience technical issues at our plants, including faults resulting in outages, incidents requiring urgent repairs or involving significant costs and breakdowns that cause unexpected interruptions. Even though business interruption insurance is in place, the Group could potentially be exposed to a greater than necessary financial impact in the event that the cause of the interruption is not covered under the policy or that the rectification of the cause of the interruption is delayed, e.g. due to supply chain issues, beyond the business interruption period covered under the policy. An IT disaster recovery plan is in place (which is essentially linked to physical damage/defects), which covers the whole Group. Centrally coordinated business continuity plans are in place covering the various locations where each business operates and office-based staff have the capability to work from home securely. However, despite such disaster recovery plans and business continuity plans being in place, there remains the risk of significant unexpected interruption to the Group’s business operations through unavailability of systems in the event of malicious cyber-attack on the Group’s information technology (“IT”) systems or its outsourced service providers’ IT systems or employee negligence. There can be no assurance that there will be no interruptions to the availability of our assets, specifically, the Huntsown CCGT. For instance, on January 29, 2021, a fault was identified on the Huntstown 2 main generator transformer, which resulted in the plant not being available to the market. While we suffered losses as a result of such interruption, they were largely covered by our business interruption insurance; however, such insurance cannot be guaranteed for any future outages or interruptions. A new replacement transformer was successfully installed and commissioned and the plant returned to service on October 23, 2021. The new replacement transformer was procured from a new supplier with whom the Group had no previous relationship. Although diligence was undertaken on the supplier’s credentials and workmanship, the Group does not have first-hand experience of the operation of similar transformers and therefore there could be a risk that other unexpected interruptions occur in the future and/or that maintenance and repair costs or times are greater than expected. For the Huntstown CCGTs, while we seek to manage the risk of any interruption or breakdown by having long-term maintenance agreements in place with the plants’ original equipment manufacturers and operating the plants to the manufacturers’ approved operation, maintenance and safety policies and procedures, they may experience breakdown or interruptions for an extended period of time and there can be no assurance that we will be able to ----- recover for our losses in the event of such an interruption of breakdown under our insurance policies, including our business interruption insurance policies. The connection offer, providing for firm import capacity for the Huntstown data center, contains obligations on Huntstown Power Company Limited to maintain ongoing availability of Huntstown 1. Any material reduction in availability could result, under certain circumstances, in the loss of firm import capacity and ultimately could lead to a termination event under the lease with the tenant of the data center. In the event that we are forced to shut down any of our sites for a significant period of time as a result of mechanical failure, equipment malfunction, cyber-attack, technological breakdowns or other interruption, it could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our Customer Solutions businesses are subject to the risk that personal or sensitive customer data may be compromised, which could result in an adverse impact to our reputation and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our Customer Solutions businesses require access to personal or sensitive customer data in the ordinary course of business. Examples of personal or sensitive customer data include names, addresses, bank account information, historical electricity usage, expected patterns of electricity usage, payment history, credit bureau data and credit and debit card account numbers. Digitalization of our industry is also increasing the requirement to access such sensitive customer data, e.g. the National Smart Metering Programme in the RoI is upgrading all electricity meters to smart meters. As a result, there could be a risk that increased regulatory requirements are placed on our Customer Solutions businesses, which we may not be able to comply with or that such failure to comply with could result in significant costs, including expenses related to regulatory scrutiny or legal liability also causing reputational damage to our Customer Solutions businesses and which could have a material adverse effect on our business, reputation, financial condition, or results of operations. In addition, our Customer Solutions businesses provide personal or sensitive customer data to vendors and service providers that require access to this information in order to provide services to the retail businesses. If a significant or widely publicized inappropriate disclosure of customer data were to occur, whether as a result of a failure of our IT security systems, employee negligence or the actions of our vendors, the reputation of our Customer Solutions businesses may be adversely affected, customer confidence may be diminished and our Customer Solutions businesses may be subject to legal claims or fines, any of which may contribute to the loss of customers and have a material adverse effect on our business, reputation, results of operations, or financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: Decreases in demand for electricity may adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Furthermore, the projected increase in demand for electricity may not materialize.
Subsubsection Text: The future profitability and growth of our businesses are partially reliant upon a projected increase in the demand for electricity in the Irish market that may not occur in the manner we anticipate. This projected increase is dependent on a variety of factors, including general economic conditions, weather conditions and residential consumption, which are inherently unpredictable and difficult to forecast accurately. Moreover, the historic correlation between economic growth and demand for electricity that we generate may not hold true in the future. Furthermore, in light of the energy crisis and the climate change agenda, the governments in both the RoI and NI are targeting a reduction in energy consumption. The use of subsidies and support measures, for instance retrofit solar PV and energy efficiency measures, could lead to a reduction in the demand for electricity. Accordingly, there can be no assurance that our revenue will grow in line with expectations, which are based, in part, on the projected increase in demand for electricity in the SEM and this, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Government price interventions and/or reductions in governmental support for renewable energy sources in general, or wind farms in particular, may adversely affect our operations.
Subsubsection Text: The development of renewable energy sources and generation of renewable energy typically relies in large part on national and international regulatory and financial support. For several years, the EU, the RoI and NI have adopted governmental policies and subsidies actively supporting renewable energy. A number of the Group’s renewable assets are supported by financial support schemes that have now closed, such as the NI Renewable Obligation (“NIRO”) regime and the RoI REFIT schemes. Unlike newer support schemes that are typically designed on the basis of a two-way mechanism providing both a ceiling and floor to investor returns (such as the RoI RESS scheme), the NIRO and REFIT schemes provide only a floor. During periods of high wholesale market prices, the fact that renewable generators can at times earn significant market revenue without any commensurate increase in input costs, as is the case for thermal units, has caused governments in Ireland and ----- the UK to introduce measures aimed at limiting what has been interpreted as surplus revenues. In the RoI and NI, there could be a risk that longer term changes are made to existing support schemes that place a ceiling on the potential revenue a supported generator can earn, i.e. REFIT and NIRO. _NI_ The 2022 Autumn Statement announced by the UK Chancellor, unveiled the Electricity Generator Levy, a new temporary 45% charge on exceptional receipts generated from the production of wholesale electricity, applicable to all electricity generators across the UK and thus including renewable generators in NI. Exceptional receipts are defined as wholesale electricity sold at an average price in excess of £75 per MWh over an accounting period. The levy will be limited to generators whose in-scope generation output of electricity exceeds 50GWh across a period of a year. The levy will only apply to exceptional receipts exceeding £10 million in an accounting period. Some generators within the scope of the levy have seen certain costs increase in line with the wholesale price of electricity. This is often in the form of fuel costs or revenue-sharing agreements with third parties. The levy will allow for the deduction of a limited set of exceptional costs when calculating generators’ liability. Generators that operate under the contracts for difference support scheme, investment contracts or in receipt of feed-in tariff export payments are excluded from the levy. The levy is in effect from January 1, 2023 until March 31, 2028, and applies to pro-rated profits for accounting periods between those dates. The levy brings the headline rate of tax to 70% on such receipts and the legislation is being introduced to enact the levy. Until such time that this is enacted, it is not possible to conclusively determine the financial impact on the Group’s operations from the introduction of the levy. The NIRO regime is designed to incentivize the generation of electricity from renewable sources and places an obligation on suppliers to source a portion of their electricity from renewable sources. Under the NIRO regime, eligible renewable generators receive ROCs for each MWh of electricity generated and consumed within NI or used in a permitted way. ROCs are freely tradable at auction and can be sold to suppliers throughout the UK in order to fulfil their obligations under the relevant Renewable Obligation regime. From 2027, it is proposed that fixed-price certificates will be issued, in place of ROCs, to projects qualifying for ROC support until the end of the RO regime in 2037. It is currently proposed that fixed-price certificates will be set at the 2027 buyout price plus 10% and will be inflation-linked. In August 2015, DETI confirmed that the fixed-price certificate scheme will be introduced for the NIRO in 2027, however, a consultation on the detailed design of the fixed-price certificate scheme and the associated legislation has not yet been issued. DfE are consulting on the implementation of a new support scheme for NI, expected to be in the form of a contract for differences (“CfD”). A proposal within the consultation is to replace existing ROC support with a CfD contract as a means of placing a ceiling on renewable generators’ potential returns and therefore there is a risk that the final design of the support scheme for NI from 2027 could have a material adverse effect on the Renewables business, financial condition and results of operations. Our ability to utilize ROCs depends on their timely issuance by Ofgem. In the event they are not issued on a timely basis, we may be unable to utilize them within the time periods we intend, which could have an adverse effect on our cash flows or our wind farm project finance arrangements. Furthermore, our ability to utilize ROCs depends on our ability to demonstrate that the wind power we generate in NI is actually consumed by our own customer base. While our wind power generation is off-taken by our supply business for customers in NI, wind power generation and customer demand can each fluctuate substantially over short term timescales. Accordingly, there is some risk that there may be a mismatch between the wind power we generate and consumption by our customer base. _Republic of Ireland_ The European Commission has set a revenue cap on all electricity generators across Europe, requiring them to hand over to national governments, in accordance with EU rules, any excess revenue they receive for selling their non-gas generated power at over €180/MWh. The Irish Government has decided to implement the cap at a lower price of €120/MWh for both wind and solar PV generators. In line with the EU guidance the cap has been in place since December 1, 2022 and is expected to expire by June 30, 2023. While a recent European Commission consultation on the future design of the electricity market stopped short of extending the cap, the EU is keeping the matter under review. A risk remains therefore that the cap could be extended. The detailed methodology by which the cap will be implemented in RoI has yet to be published. Until such time that the final methodology is published, it is not possible to conclusively determine the financial impact on the Group’s operations from the introduction of the cap. ----- The RoI REFIT regime reimburses suppliers for the out-of-market costs associated with their purchase of renewable energy. The reimbursements are paid from PSO Levies collected from end users and allow suppliers to offer fixed price PPAs to generators of renewable electricity. The REFIT mechanism in the RoI relies upon a comparison between actual annual market prices received by suppliers for selling power into SEM and the revenue floor guaranteed by the relevant REFIT Scheme in respect of the relevant renewable technology. Any shortfall in revenue is recovered by reimbursements paid out of the PSO levies. Recent high market prices have resulted in no requirement to make top up payments from the PSO levy to generators. There is a risk that in the future a requirement to make such top up payments may arise and that there may be a delay in receiving such payments. The RoI or UK governments may choose to reduce or eliminate subsidies for the renewable energy sector or may delay the implementation of legislation or other efforts geared towards developing this sector. Should high wholesale prices occur for a sustained period, there could be increasing pressure for the introduction of a mechanism by which electricity market revenues can be limited for generators receiving PSO support. There is also a risk that should the EU decide not to implement a further revenue cap, the Irish Government might seek to review the terms of the REFIT scheme in an effort to curb surplus revenue accrual by its participants. The reduction or abandonment of governmental support for renewable energy sources in general, or for wind power in particular, or the introduction of further market interventions, could render the renewable energy sector significantly less profitable and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. There is also a risk that electricity market reform at an EU level (such as the EU Commission’s current proposal for a reform of the EU Electricity Market Design announced on March 14, 2023) could threaten the existing marginal cost pricing model whereby the most expensive generators needed to meet demand (e.g. gas fired generators) set the price paid to all generators, including those with lower marginal cost (e.g. renewables). Whilst the European Commission is not proposing any change to the pricing mechanism based on marginal pricing, there is an appetite within some Member States for fundamental reform to prevent high gas prices from setting high electricity prices in future. Such reforms, if implemented, could render the renewable energy sector significantly less profitable and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation.

Subsubsection Title: The exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union (“Brexit”) may adversely impact trading arrangements, be a source of instability in international markets and create significant currency fluctuations, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: When the UK formally left the EU on January 31, 2020, it remained in the EU’s Single Market and Customs Union until the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement (the “EU-UK TCA”) became operational from January 1, 2021. Notwithstanding the wider EU-UK TCA, the NI Protocol, agreed as part of the Withdrawal Agreement, also came into force on January 1, 2021 to ensure that there would be no new checks on goods crossing the border between NI and the RoI. As a result of the protocol, NI has in effect remained in the EU’s Single Market for goods, while England, Scotland and Wales have left the EU’s Single Market for goods. The NI Protocol also protects the continued operation of the SEM market, however, the framework for electricity trading across interconnectors between Ireland and Great Britain has changed and these two interconnectors are no longer able to participate in the EU single day-ahead market. The NI Protocol contains a consent mechanism to retain the provisions under which NI applies EU single market regulations and the EU customs code. The NI Assembly’s first vote on the NI Protocol is to take place before the end of 2024. The Withdrawal Agreement states that the NI Protocol will cease to apply if consent is sought, a decision is reached, and the UK notifies the EU that the decision is not in favor of continued application of the NI Protocol. This suggests that if consent is never sought and a decision is never made because the NI institutions are not functional, the default is that the NI Protocol will continue to apply. Due to significant disagreements surrounding the NI Protocol, the UK and EU entered into negotiations to amend it. These negotiations concluded with the announcement of the “Windsor Framework” on February 28, 2023. The Windsor Framework is made up of a number of documents including a UK Government Command Paper, a joint UK-EU political declaration, draft decisions to be taken by the Withdrawal Agreement Joint Committee and unilateral measures to be adopted by each party respectively. On March 24, 2023, it was ratified by the UK and the EU. Post-Brexit uncertainty and unpredictability concerning the UK’s legal, political and economic relationship with the EU could be a source of instability in the UK economy and international markets, and it may create significant currency fluctuations and/or otherwise adversely affect trading agreements or similar cross border cooperation arrangements (whether economic, tax, fiscal, legal, regulatory or otherwise) for the foreseeable future. A portion of our business is conducted in NI, which is a part of the UK. Should there be a future material adverse effect on the UK economy, such an event could negatively affect demand for our products and services in NI. Also, revenues from our businesses in NI are collected in pound sterling, and a decline in the value of the pound sterling against other currencies used in the international energy, commodity, and equipment markets (such ----- as the euro and U.S. dollar) could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial performance. It is also possible that Brexit could lead other EU member states to consider leaving the EU, which could be an additional source of instability in international markets. Further, other EU member states within the eurozone could decide to discontinue their use of the euro as their functional currency. The exit of another country from the EU, the potential secession of Scotland, Wales or NI from the UK, or prolonged periods of uncertainty relating to any of these possibilities, could result in significant macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, decreases in global stock exchange indices, increased foreign exchange volatility (in particular a further weakening of the pound sterling and euro against other leading currencies), and decreased GDP in the European Union. Given the RoI’s proximity to the UK and its strong trade, investment and finance links with the UK, the longer-term impact of Brexit could damage RoI trade and the RoI economy in the years ahead. In turn, an economic downturn could also negatively affect demand for our products and services in the RoI. Also, revenues from the Group’s businesses in the RoI are recognized and collected in euros, and a decline in the value of the euro against other currencies used in the international energy, commodity, and equipment markets (such as the U.S. dollar) could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial performance. In the event of Scottish independence and in the lead up to such an event, a considerable amount of uncertainty in the Irish energy markets could arise, as it is unknown if a newly independent Scotland would reaccede to the EU, and what the terms of the relationships would be between an independent Scotland and her neighbors. Great Britain and Ireland’s electricity and gas grids are linked via several interconnectors, some of which run through Scotland, and the vast majority of Ireland’s gas consumption is supplied via a Scottish interconnector. If Scotland votes to secede from the UK, nearly all of the British North Sea oil fields, half of its natural gas fields, along with its accompanying highly important transit infrastructure would fall under Scottish control. See “—We rely on electricity and natural gas interconnectors with Great Britain to meet our electricity _and natural gas requirements.”_ Any of these risks and also potentially unforeseen related risks concerning Brexit could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsubsection Title: The quantity of electricity actually produced by Energia Group’s wind farms and PPAs, including as a result of curtailment and constraint actions by the TSO, may vary from its estimates.
Subsubsection Text: As is the case for most wind farm operators, estimating the amount of electricity generated by the Group’s wind farms and PPAs is inherently subject to uncertainty. Estimates of output are based on various assumptions, many of which are beyond our control, including weather conditions. The quantity of electricity actually produced by the Group’s owned and contracted wind farms, or the quantity of electricity generated therefrom in the future, may vary materially from our estimates. Under SEM, the unpredictability of wind farm generation could lead to costs under Reliability Options, if such wind farms take part, or the need to turn to the balancing market during periods of unexpected generation shortfall. Subsequent evaluations of actual production output and the performance of our owned wind farms, as well as the third-party wind farms in respect of which the Group has PPAs, based upon production data or other information, may result in material revisions to our original output estimates. Any significant negative variance in the quantity of electricity produced by our owned wind farms, or procured through our PPAs, or a change in the proportion of wind energy that can be captured and utilized by such wind farms or their ability to convert wind energy to electricity, could adversely affect the Renewables business’ revenue and the profitability of our renewables assets, which could, in turn, have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. In addition, from time to time, the wind farms on the network may produce more renewable power than can be accommodated on the all-island power system. In the event TSO deems it necessary to retain certain types of power stations on the network for technical reasons, such as to ensure adequate maintenance of the system frequency, it may undertake curtailment actions, which may include instructions to one or more renewable generators to reduce the export of power to the network in favor of a generator with different characteristics. Even when there is no network-wide surplus of renewable power, limitations may apply to a geographically defined subset of the transmission network, which may be caused by such factors as the current carrying capacity of a local transmission network, the requirement to maintain local voltage profiles, or the requirement to remain within switchgear ratings. It is expected that Dublin will continue to be highly constrained in the period to 2030. The TSO must manage local generation and supply within these constraint limits, which ----- may result in the TSO instructing a renewable generator connected to a constrained part of the system to reduce its export of power to the network. While curtailments and constraints have historically taken place from time to time, the increasing prevalence of wind power in the Irish network gives rise to the risk that such actions may become more frequent. Significant investment in the electricity grid and interconnection to facilitate wider and deeper electrification powered by renewable electricity is fundamental to the long-term decarbonization of the island of Ireland. The decisions taken by the TSO imposing constraints and curtailment on our wind farms and PPAs directly impact upon the revenue and profitability of those wind farm assets and PPAs, and if the scale of these actions were to increase it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We face development risks related to the construction and development of new assets.
Subsubsection Text: We are currently in the process of developing a substantial pipeline of onshore and offshore wind, solar PV, emergency gas generation, battery storage and data center projects. The Group is currently constructing one onshore wind farm and an emergency gas generation plant and plans to undertake construction of further projects in the future. Any construction delay, change in government policy, issues with securing permissions from local landowners or need to obtain planning amendments could result in delays to the estimated commencement date for commercial operations and increased costs or could render a project uneconomic. Our projects must obtain connections to the electricity grid, however there are significant demands for connections from the system operators, EirGrid and SONI, made by ourselves and other developers, which could result in significant delays in securing the connections we need. The process of obtaining grid connections may also be costly and timeconsuming, as we must, among other requirements, obtain planning and other consents from relevant authorities, secure any required easements or wayleaves from landowners and construct the physical connection between the generation asset and the power grid. In addition, the post-COVID-19 recovery and global supply chain shortages have the potential to disrupt the availability of contractors, equipment, and supplies, which could cause delays to construction of assets. For instance, planning consent for the proposed data center at our Huntstown campus in Dublin, RoI, was received in April 2022 but the decision was appealed, and the planning application is currently being considered by An Bord Pleanála, RoI’s national independent planning body. The Group expects An Bord _Pleanála to issue its decision in the near term and does not believe that there are grounds on which planning_ permission should be refused. While there is no further mechanism for appeal on planning grounds against the decision of An Bord Pleanála, a sufficiently interested party could obtain leave from the court to apply for judicial review of the lawfulness of the decision by An Bord Pleanála. Accordingly, there can be no assurance that such planning consents will be obtained in a timely manner or at all. The capacity capable of being contracted under the REFA is subject to a number of conditions, including the timely achievement of certain related planning, consenting and development requirements and requires that a threshold volume achieves first export by December 31, 2024. In the event that Microsoft are not obliged to offer a project a CPPA under the REFA and no CPPA is otherwise agreed with Microsoft, the Group is likely to be free to pursue alternative routes to market such as RESS or through CPPAs with other parties. In the event that certain of the Group’s renewable development projects are not supported by CPPAs entered into under the REFA or are unsuccessful in achieving an alternative route to market they may not be capable of being constructed and operated economically. Any failure to obtain the necessary consents or access rights, or delays in establishing the connection between the generation asset and the grid (or achieving compliance with relevant grid code tests), or construction delays in general, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, or results of operations. In addition, where the Group enters into PPAs in respect of in-development third-party wind farms, such thirdparty wind farms face similar development, grid connection and construction risks that could lead to delays in the commencement of commercial operations. Any delays in the development of onshore and offshore wind, solar PV, emergency gas generation, battery storage and data center projects, or their cancellation, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: An overall rise in interest rates could increase our financing costs, and could make the construction and development of new projects more expensive, thereby negatively affecting our business, results of operations, or financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We finance our business activities with our own and borrowed capital. In response to increased levels of inflation in major economies around the world, central banks, such as the European Central Bank, the U.S. Federal ----- Reserve and the Bank of England, raised interest rates or have signaled that they will or may raise interest rates in the future. For instance, in December 2021, the Bank of England voted to increase the base rate to 0.25% in the first increase since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, and since then, has steadily increased the base rate through 2022, and most recently in June 2023, to 5.00%. Similarly, the European Central Bank raised its benchmark deposit rate, on multiple occasions throughout 2022, and most recently in June 2023, to 3.50%. Continued increase in interest rates could affect our ability to finance the development of new projects by debt capital and the general ability to refinance debt that becomes due. In particular, to the extent we use external debt financing at partially variable interest rates or when refinancing existing fixed rate indebtedness, an increase in interest rates would directly result in higher financing costs for us, including through higher costs for funding capital expenditure requirements, requiring further cash outflow for our business. To control our interest rate risk we may enter into hedging contracts in respect of a portion of our interest rate exposure. However, if any counterparty to these hedging contracts is unable to meet its obligations or if our hedging procedures turn out to be ineffective for other reasons, the interest expenses incurred by us could be higher than expected. An overall rise of interest rates could therefore have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, or results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our insurance policies may not cover us for all losses incurred.
Subsubsection Text: We believe we currently have insurance arrangements in place that provide a level of coverage adequate for an energy generation and supply business of the size and with the scope of operations that we have and that such coverage is in line with industry norms. Our policies cover product and public liability, property damage, business interruption, employer’s liability, directors’ and officers’ liability, and credit risk insurance. However, these insurance policies may not cover any losses or damages resulting from the materialization of all of the risks to which we are subject. For example, like other power companies, we are not insured for the risk of viruses attacking our operational IT systems. Furthermore, in the event we suffer a loss in relation to an insured risk, there is no guarantee that the amount of insurance protection to which we are entitled will be sufficient to cover the entire loss incurred. Insurance, warranties or performance guarantees may not cover all or any lost revenues or increased costs of working/expenses from business interruptions or other events, including the cost of replacement electricity. It could also take longer than expected to repair damaged facilities due to delays in the supply chains, many of which are international, used by the Group. Even though business interruption insurance is in place, the Group could potentially be exposed to a negative financial impact in the event that the cause of the interruption is not covered under the policy or that the rectification of the cause of the interruption is delayed, e.g. due to supply chain issues, beyond the business interruption period covered under the policy. Furthermore, our ability to obtain insurance, and the cost of and coverage provided by such insurance, could be affected by adverse events, some of which may be outside our control. Our future inability to obtain important insurance policies at all, or on commercially acceptable terms, could have an adverse impact on our business.

Subsubsection Title: Our assets or positions are not and cannot be fully hedged against fluctuations in commodity prices and market utilizations and our revenues and margins may be impacted and hedging transactions may not function as intended.
Subsubsection Text: Volatility in market prices for electricity and natural gas may result from a variety of factors, including severe or unexpected weather conditions, changes in electricity and fuel usage, geopolitical events, availability of competitively priced alternative energy sources, and changes to energy, environmental and other regulation and legislation. We do not and cannot fully hedge the risks associated with changes in electricity, natural gas and CO2 prices or generation plant utilizations or our relative size in the market. To the extent we have unhedged positions, fluctuating commodity prices and inaccuracies in forecasting electricity market prices can materially affect our results of operations and financial condition, either favorably or unfavorably. Energia Group’s own thermal generation has historically acted as a hedge against price spikes or other circumstances that require increased capacity in the SEM, for example when other generators are experiencing outages. However, as the proportion of renewable generation increases, the effectiveness of the Huntstown plants as a hedge decreases. The Group’s hedging activities are carried out by its trading team, which has developed a range of sophisticated retail-related products to reduce our exposure to movements in commodity prices, including financial and physical natural gas contracts, financial and physical power contracts, interconnector capacity purchases and CO2 and foreign exchange trades (these being the primary drivers of variable generation costs in the SEM). Specifically, the Customer Solutions businesses employ commodity swaps to hedge a large proportion of their exposure to natural gas prices and forward purchase contracts to hedge CO2 emission costs, while PPB hedges its exposure to commodity price fluctuations with respect to its generation contracts through the use of commodity swaps and forward purchase contracts. Further, the Customer Solutions businesses and PPB enter into ----- CfDs to hedge their exposure to electricity market price volatility; however, for a variety of reasons, including a lack of liquidity in the CfD market, it may not be possible to enter into forward purchases at commercially acceptable terms, or the business may decide not to enter into such hedges at all, for any or all of our electricity requirements. This necessitates the use of hedges based on the underlying drivers of electricity generation costs, but these hedges do not provide a perfect hedge to electricity prices, which are also influenced by, among other things, weather, demand, the fuel mix in the power generation markets (including the relative cost of natural gas compared to coal), and plant availabilities, reducing the effectiveness of this risk mitigation strategy. The price we can obtain for electricity sales from our customers may not change at the same rate as changes in input costs, thereby potentially restricting the margins realized on these sales and reducing our revenue. Volatility in the foreign exchange market may also affect the price of inputs and, consequently, our costs and earnings. Although we have in place risk management procedures, we attempt to reduce our exposure to price volatility and to achieve margin certainty, and we regularly review how our procedures are implemented in practice, we may not eliminate all the risks associated with our activities. As a result of these and other factors, we cannot predict the impact that hedging and other risk management actions may have on our business, financial condition or results of operations and hedging policies.

Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to counterparty risk, where we engage in hedging and risk management activities, and the risk of market resettlement.
Subsubsection Text: Where we engage in hedging and risk management activities, we are exposed to the risk that counterparties owing us money or obligated to supply us with energy or other commodities as a result of market transactions will not perform their obligations. Should the counterparties to these arrangements fail to perform, we may be required to enter into alternative hedging arrangements or honor the underlying commitment at thencurrent market prices. In the event of counterparty failure, it may not be possible to find an alternative counterparty willing to step in and provide alternative hedging arrangements. In the event of either having to enter into alternative hedging arrangements or honor the underlying commitment at then-current market prices, we may incur losses in addition to amounts, if any, already paid to the initial counterparties, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. In addition, reductions in our credit quality or changes in the market prices of energy commodities could increase the cash collateral required to be posted in connection with hedging and risk management activities, which could materially affect our liquidity and financial condition. We are reliant on credit lines being made available from our commodity counterparties. The Group employs commodity swaps to hedge gas price exposures and Great Britain power price exposures as well as forward purchase contracts to hedge its shortfall of CO2 emissions allowances and is therefore reliant on credit lines being made available from a limited number of commodity counterparties. In periods of price volatility there could be a risk that commodity counterparties limit or reduce the Group’s ability to place further trades due to their exposure to ‘out of the money’ fair value of the derivative financial instruments. Should such restrictions be imposed, the Group may be required to either find alternative commodity counterparties or cash collateralize current counterparties in order to place further trades. While trading restrictions would not be expected to endure long-term, in the event that commodity counterparties closed or reduced their credit lines, there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Participants in the markets in which we operate are also exposed to the risk that another market participant may default on its obligations to pay the SEMO for electricity taken, in which case such costs, to the extent not offset by posted security and other protections available to the SEMO (which is designed to be a fully collateralized market) may be shared across the various non-defaulting SEM market participants, including us. While any such exposure is not expected to be significant, in the event required payments are larger than anticipated, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, the SEM trading arrangements, which comprise a DAM, IDM and BM, have experienced volatility since the market commenced on October 1, 2018 and the Group’s businesses remain exposed to energy price and volume resettlement risks. As at March 31, 2023 the market operator has resettled these markets up to December 3, 2022 for M+4 resettlement and March 5, 2022 for M+13 resettlement (the market is ordinarily resettled 4 months and 13 months after initial settlement). However, some system defects remain and further market fixes are required to be implemented. The Group is therefore exposed to potential price and volume resettlements in the balancing market ranging the full 54-month period from the commencement of the new market ----- arrangements and therefore has estimated the level of resettlement that will be applied. These estimates are based on known market anomalies as extensively discussed in industry forums and facts and circumstances known at the balance sheet date. Estimations are dependent on the resettlement approach taken by the market operator. While any such exposure is not expected to be significant, in the event that actual resettlement amounts are larger than anticipated, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our cost of compliance with energy efficiency initiatives, environmental laws and regulations, and any environmental liabilities arising from our operating activities could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to extensive environmental regulation by governmental authorities and may incur costs beyond those currently contemplated to comply with these requirements. Existing environmental regulations could be revised or reinterpreted, new laws and regulations could be adopted or become applicable to us or our facilities, and future changes in environmental laws and regulations could occur, including potentially costly regulatory and enforcement developments related to carbon reduction or other greenhouse gas emissions or any other sustainability or climate resilience issues. If we fail to comply with these requirements, we could be subject to civil or criminal liabilities and fines or operation of our facilities could be forcibly stopped, curtailed or modified or could become subject to additional costs. Any such event could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations. We could incur liability under national or local environmental laws or regulations, either as a polluter or as the party managing certain aspects of any of our owned facilities, including the Huntstown plants. We do not have any reserved cash funds held to meet requirements with environmental regulations and any such requirements imposed on the Huntstown plants, or our other owned facilities, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, we may be responsible for any on-site liabilities associated with the environmental condition of facilities that we have acquired, leased or developed, regardless of when the liabilities arose and whether they are known or unknown. In connection with certain acquisitions and sales of assets, we may obtain, or be required to provide, indemnification against certain environmental liabilities. Another party could, depending on the circumstances, assert an environmental claim against us or fail to meet its indemnification obligations. We do not have any provisions in our accounts for environmental liabilities, but the Huntstown plants carry insurance that would cover such liabilities as a result of sudden and accidental pollution. Any costs incurred in relation to such environmental liabilities over and above those covered by applicable insurance policies could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In early 2022, the EPA initiated a review of the Huntstown 1 and Huntstown 2 IED licenses to take account of the EU best available techniques (“BAT”) conclusions. Energia Group submitted a response in relation to compliance with the BAT conclusions on April 28, 2022. The EPA have not yet issued the license amendments for Huntstown 1 and 2 in relation to the Large Combustion Plants Directive (“LCP”) BAT conclusions. The details of potential amendments have been discussed with the EPA and any changes are expected to be in line with Energia Group’s submission on LCP BAT conclusions, which will introduce some tightening of emission limit values to air within the technical capability of the Huntstown plants. Increased obligations are also being applied to suppliers in relation to energy efficiency. In March 2014, the RoI Government transposed the EU Directive 2012/27/EU on energy efficiency into national law. This Directive was subsequently updated and adopted by the Council of the EU in 2018. This legislation obliges suppliers to achieve a validated energy savings amount equal to certain annual targets notified by way of energy efficiency notice. The obligation commenced with effect from January 2014 and is intended to apply until December 2030. A failure to achieve this level of energy savings will result in a prescribed penalty amount being applied to suppliers. The RoI Government has the right to set the penalty amount. In 2023 the penalty amount was significantly increased on the prior period applicable from 2014 to 2022. The cost of compliance will continue to increase in the forthcoming years as further energy efficiency savings may become more onerous to achieve. The compliance cost and/or penalties levied under this regime could be material and we will therefore seek to recover all or a portion of any such costs from our customers in the retail market. Such recovery may be difficult to achieve in a competitive market environment and any costs incurred in relation to such regulation and not off-set through market prices or otherwise could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, or results of operations. -----

Subsubsection Title: If we are unable to raise capital on commercial terms or at all, our long-term ability to conduct certain corporate activities, in particular to raise project capital to build out our portfolio of onshore and offshore wind, solar PV and data center development projects, would be adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: We and our subsidiaries expect to rely on access to the capital markets for capital requirements not satisfied by existing credit facilities (such as the Revolving Credit Facility), cash on hand or operating cash flows. In particular, we may, in the future, seek to finance the construction of our portfolio of onshore and offshore wind, solar PV and data center development projects, or to refinance existing project finance facilities in relation to operational onshore wind farms, in the credit and/or capital markets. We may also choose to grow our business through certain targeted acquisitions of projects or businesses over the longer term, which, in some circumstances, will require us to obtain additional financing in the credit or capital markets. If we are unable to access the capital markets in the longer-term, on commercially reasonable terms or at all, our ability to engage in these activities would be limited, thereby potentially limiting our future growth opportunities, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our business could be adversely affected if we are unable to maintain relationships with suppliers, consultants, regulatory authorities, customer advocacy groups or customers or if the entities that comprise these relationships cease to exist.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on current and future relationships with a relatively small number of suppliers and service providers for the operation and growth of our business and will continue to be reliant on third parties for our further development. For example, we rely on Siemens and Mitsubishi to regularly maintain and service the Huntstown plants, Global Energy Services for the operation and maintenance of our wind farms and Fluence for the operation and maintenance of our battery storage facility in Belfast as well as a small number of suppliers for our natural gas requirements. In addition, we outsource a significant portion of our information and communication technologies requirements to a third-party supplier, Capita Managed IT Solutions Limited (“Capita”) and our voice and data telecoms services are provided by British Telecom through a contract managed by Capita. There is a risk of disruption to the Group if there are any service delivery failures or availability issues. Although the Group maintains comprehensive business continuity and disaster recovery plans to manage this risk, our dependence on these relationships may impact our ability to negotiate favorable contract terms with these counterparties, and there is no guarantee that we will be able to replace any material suppliers or service providers in a timely manner, or at all, in the event that any of these relationships were to be discontinued or terminated. If we are unable to negotiate favorable contracts with our suppliers or service providers, or such suppliers or service providers are unable to fulfil their obligations or discontinue business with us and we are unable to find other suitable replacements, our business, financial condition and operational results may be materially adversely affected. We also have long-standing relationship with regulatory bodies, such as the CRU, the DECC, the UR and the DfE, as well as with customer advocacy groups, such as the Consumer Council for NI, the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Irish Business and Employers’ Confederation, in each case in relation to our business activities in NI and RoI. While we have a productive relationship with these regulatory bodies and customer advocacy groups, there is no guarantee we will be able to maintain these relationships and any disruption may materially adversely affect our business. In our electricity and gas supply business, we rely on our relationships with a number of large customers. While the loss of any single customer is not expected to have a material impact on our business as a whole, if we were unable to maintain our relationships with our large customers, we could lose market share, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In our electricity and gas supply business, we rely on our relationships with a number of consultants who represent one or more customers. While the loss of any single consultant is not expected to have a material impact on our business as a whole, if we were unable to maintain our relationships with consultants in general, we could lose market share, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. -----

Subsubsection Title: Government actions that restrict or prevent businesses from freely operating could adversely impact our business and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: The actions of governments, such as the national lockdowns and related measures introduced in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, which restrict or prevent businesses from freely operating could have a serious detrimental impact on our business and results of operations. Such restrictions could impact the Group’s own operations and the operations of its customers. The Customer Solutions electricity and gas supply businesses rely on both residential and commercial customers, which could be adversely impacted from the introduction of such restrictions. The Group has centrally coordinated business continuity plans in place (including pandemic response plans) covering the various locations where each business operates and office-based staff have the capability to work from home securely. While the Group is well-positioned to operate through a period of government-imposed restrictions, there could be a risk that the Group’s customers are adversely impacted and therefore their demand for electricity and gas could be reduced. Furthermore, if such restrictions were to be imposed there could be a risk that commercial and residential customers may not be in a position to pay their electricity and gas bills and the Group could be exposed to an increased risk of payment default and bad debts. The introduction of government-imposed restrictions could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our operations expose us to the risk of material health and safety liabilities, which leave us open to substantial liabilities, fines and penalties.
Subsubsection Text: The nature of our operations subjects us to various statutory compliance and litigation risks under health, safety and employment laws. We cannot guarantee the absence of future health and safety accidents or incidents at our sites, including as a result of negligence. If any such incident occurs, we could be subject to prosecution and/or litigation, which may lead to fines, penalties or reputational damage. We cannot guarantee that claims will not be filed against us in the future, or that incidents will not arise in the future. While we maintain insurance coverage in respect of such liabilities, the costs incurred, including any reputational damage, could nevertheless have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition to liability claims, exposure to material health and safety liabilities could affect our brand image, reputation, press coverage, and possibly have political and regulatory implications, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Failure to ensure our business is climate resilient may adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: A failure to ensure our business is climate resilient presents risks if we are not able to successfully manage the impacts of climate change. Physical effects of climate change such as increases in temperature, sea levels, the severity of weather events and the frequency of natural disasters, such as hurricanes, tropical storms, tornadoes, wildfires, floods and earthquakes, among other effects, could result in physical damage or a decrease in in the value of our plants and other assets. In the worst case, such assets could even be damaged beyond repair as a result of such natural disasters. The costs of remediating or repairing such damage, or of investments made in advance of such weather events to minimize potential damage, could be considerable. Additionally, such actual or threatened climate change related damage could increase the cost of, or make unavailable, insurance on favorable terms. Whilst we take steps to mitigate such impacts, including investing to protect our plants and other assets from future impact of climate change and insuring our assets with appropriate and available insurance, there is a risk that there may be events that arise which are unforeseen or are not covered by insurance. If insurance is unavailable to us or is unavailable on acceptable terms, or if our insurance is not adequate to cover business interruption or losses from these events, our results of operations or financial condition could be adversely affected. In addition, changes in legislation and regulations on climate change could result in increased utility expenses and/or increased capital expenditures to improve the efficiencies of our assets or other related aspects of our assets in order to comply with such regulations or otherwise adapt to climate change. Compliance with new laws or regulations relating to climate change, including compliance with planning consent and licensing regimes or any carbon reduction or other greenhouse gas emissions regulation, may require us to make improvements to our existing assets or result in increased operating costs that we may not be able to effectively pass on to our customers. The materialization of any or all of the foregoing risks may therefore have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, or results of operations. -----

Subsubsection Title: We rely on electricity and natural gas interconnectors with Great Britain to meet our electricity and natural gas requirements.
Subsubsection Text: Ireland relies heavily on natural gas interconnectors from Great Britain for its natural gas supply. In the RoI, there are two interconnectors, IC1 and IC2, that transport natural gas from Great Britain’s natural gas transmission network. The natural gas transmission system in NI imports natural gas from Scotland through the Scotland-to-NI Pipeline. Disruption of, or any restriction on access to, these pipelines, or of the common single section of pipeline on mainland Scotland that supplies these pipelines with natural gas, would impact upon the ability of our Huntstown plants to operate. Furthermore, EU sanctions against Russia could result in a shortage of gas in Europe, which, in turn, could affect the flow of gas supplies to the UK and Ireland. Should the Governments of the UK or RoI need to ration the supply of gas there is a risk that the Huntstown plants will not be able to generate due to gas not being available (noting also that there is no emergency storage or LNG facility in Ireland). In such a situation, the Huntstown 1 and 2 plants both have the ability to run on fuel oil as their secondary fuel source, however prolonged running on fuel oil may be constrained by the capacity of fuel oil stored onsite and the rate at which the storage tanks can be refilled as well as by the requirement for environmental permits. We also purchase electricity from the UK through two high-voltage direct current interconnectors, the Moyle Interconnector, which runs between Scotland and NI, and the East-West Interconnector, which runs between Wales and the RoI. A significant disruption in transmission from either interconnector could force us to purchase additional quantities of electricity from alternative sources under potentially unfavorable commercial terms, which could significantly increase our expenditure for electricity. Over the years there have been a number of faults on the Moyle Interconnector and the East-West Interconnector, which have resulted in their unavailability or reduction in available capacity until such faults were repaired. Any disruption to the supply of natural gas or electricity from Great Britain to the RoI or NI could significantly increase our expenditure for natural gas (or alternative fuel sources) or electricity and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See “—The exit of the United _Kingdom from the European Union (“Brexit”) may adversely impact trading arrangements, be a source of instability in international markets and create significant currency fluctuations, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.”_

Subsubsection Title: The maintenance of our assets requires substantial cash flow and may not be adequate to prevent failure.
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we are required to make certain operational and maintenance related capital expenditures on our sites, such as equipment and other infrastructure maintenance, including machine parts for the Huntstown plants. Our ability to undertake such operational and maintenance measures largely depends on our cash flow from our operations and access to capital. However, we may have unforeseen capital expenditure needs for which we may not have adequate capital, including urgent repairs or measures to update or replace essential equipment that has become faulty or breaks down. If we do not have adequate capital to service our plants, we may not be able to operate our plants as efficiently, or at all. In addition, parties to our PPA agreements and our assets may experience reduced capacity availability as a result of generator faults, gear box rebuilds, grid availability issues or other mechanical failures, which could have an adverse effect on our revenues. Our assets, including our electricity generating plants, battery storage, and hydrogen generation assets, require regular maintenance and the provision of this maintenance is itself subject to certain risks. A number of problems may arise in relation to our facilities during maintenance, which may cause interruptions to production, including, among other things, failed deliveries by suppliers or manufacturers or longer-than-expected periods for technical adjustments. In particular, failure of a contractor to perform our contracted services and/or a change in a contractor’s financial circumstances in conjunction with an overreliance on particular contractors may, among other things, result in the relevant asset either underperforming or becoming impaired in value and there can be no assurance that such underperformance, impairment or delay will be fully or partially compensated by any contractor warranty or bank guarantee (which are usually limited in scope and amount, and typically will not cover full loss of profit). The additional costs and loss of revenue that may arise as a result of maintenance of our facilities may adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our inability to attract and retain key personnel could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our future success will depend on our ability to attract and retain highly qualified personnel. The departure of any of our executive officers or key employees may have a negative impact on our operations, ----- including possibly adversely affecting our ability to provide the service levels our customers expect. The ability to attract and retain highly qualified personnel applies across all of the Group’s operations and business functions. In particular, electricity regulation is a specialized field with a limited pool of qualified and experienced personnel while the renewable energy industry is a relatively new industry and, as a result, there is a limited pool of technically qualified personnel with substantial experience. The Group also faces market-led initiatives that require significant investment in specialist personnel in order to deliver complex IT projects required to operate in the market. The Group has a dedicated corporate development team in place responsible for the delivery of identified strategic objectives as well as an IT project management office to oversee the delivery of IT projects who have substantial knowledge of the Group and the industry. We compete with a number of companies as well as government entities and other organizations for qualified personnel and, consequently, we have encountered and may continue to encounter difficulties in retaining certain key employees and attracting new personnel. In addition, the work from home response to the COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in employees in all industries looking for increasingly flexible working options in the future. People now also have more choice about the industry, company and location in which they wish to work and in some areas this has led to scarcity of skills in the market, e.g. IT. While the Group has introduced a hybrid working model for office-based personnel, future personnel strategies will need to be kept under review to ensure that they are sufficiently flexible and in line with evolving practices. This could introduce new risks, which will be required to be managed. Increasing competitiveness in the market for talent has led to increasing salary and benefits inflation, which, in turn, has increased the risk of attrition. While the Group has increased its focus on engagement and retention strategies, there is a risk that there could be a loss of talent from the Group. Any such difficulty in retaining and/or attracting key personnel could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Changes in tax laws, challenges to our tax position or misinterpretations of certain tax laws could adversely affect our results of operations or financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to complex tax laws. Changes in tax laws or misinterpretations of certain tax laws could adversely affect our tax position, including our effective tax rate or tax payments. The Group’s appetite for tax risk is low and our policy is to manage our tax liabilities in an efficient manner and in compliance with relevant legislation and guidance. We often rely on generally available interpretations of applicable tax laws and regulations. There cannot be certainty that the relevant tax authorities are in agreement with our interpretation of these laws. If our tax positions are challenged by relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we have not anticipated or made provisions for or that we currently do not collect or pay.
