Subsubsection Text: _(€ millions)_

(1) Represents cash and cash equivalents as at March 31, 2023 (€625.6 million), excluding (a) €42.6 million of cash held at the unrestricted subsidiaries under the Existing Notes Indenture, (b) €5.7 million of restricted cash not freely available in the ordinary course, which represents cash received from the UK government in relation to the administration of the UK Government’s Energy Bills Support Scheme, and which is being paid directly to qualifying customers with any surplus after the cessation of the scheme in June 2023 to be repaid to the UK Government and (c) €213.8 million of cash in respect of cumulative overrecovery pursuant to the applicable price control formula held by Power NI Energy Limited as of March 31, 2023, which we expect to repay over the next two years with interest. See “Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.” The adjustment columns above represent adjustments to give pro forma effect to the use of cash in connection with the Debt Repayment Transactions and Refinancing Transactions as described below, in each case, as if each of those transactions had occurred on March 31, 2023: - in connection with the Debt Repayment Transactions, we used cash on balance sheet to (a) complete open market repurchases and the cancellation of £9,512,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Existing Sterling Notes (by utilizing cash for a euro-equivalent amount of €10.8 million, including in respect of purchase price and accrued and ----- unpaid interest) and €2,460,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Existing Euro Notes (by utilizing cash for an amount of €2.4 million, including in respect of purchase price and accrued and unpaid interest), which we completed in April and May 2023, and (b) repay outstanding cash drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility in a principal amount of £71.0 million on June 22, 2023 (by utilizing cash for a euro-equivalent amount of €82.0 million, which includes the payment of accrued and unpaid interest); and - in connection with the Refinancing Transactions, we intend to utilize €173.0 million of cash on balance sheet along with proceeds from the Offering, as set forth in “Use of Proceeds.” - We have excluded the cash and cash equivalents of unrestricted subsidiaries in connection with the Existing Notes for illustrative purposes. This does not reflect the financial calculations under the Indenture for the Notes and it does not reflect all of the Unrestricted Subsidiaries in connection with the Notes and the Indenture. - The Group’s cash and cash equivalents as shown in the table above is not adjusted for any cash on balance sheet that may be utilized by us to fund the proposed acquisition of a wind farm development project located in RoI. We currently expect to enter into the definitive documents and complete the acquisition before August 2023. See “Summary— _Recent developments—Potential wind farm acquisition.”_ (2) Indebtedness presented above does not include: - loans at the unrestricted subsidiaries under the Existing Notes Indenture, which are repayable in semi-annual installments up to 2035 (these loans comprise of ring-fenced non-recourse project finance facilities that are secured over the assets and shares of certain unrestricted subsidiaries and as at March 31, 2023, such unrestricted subsidiaries had €277.2 million of ring-fenced non-recourse project finance facilities (which includes unamortized debt issuance costs of €11.3 million)); and - lease liabilities of the Group pursuant to IFRS 16, which as at March 31, 2023, was €38.0 million. We have excluded the project finance debt of the unrestricted subsidiaries in connection with the Existing Notes for illustrative purposes. This does not reflect the financial calculations under the Indenture for the Notes and it does not reflect all of the Unrestricted Subsidiaries in connection with the Notes and the Indenture. (3) Represents €600 million aggregate principal amount of the Notes offered hereby, assuming an issuance at par. (4) Represents the euro-equivalent of aggregate principal amount of the £225,000,000 Existing Sterling Notes (€255.7 million euro equivalent) and the aggregate principal amount of the €350,000,000 Existing Euro Notes, in each case, jointly issued by the Existing Issuers on September 13, 2017, and outstanding as at March 31, 2023, as adjusted for the Debt Repayment Transactions, pursuant to which we used cash on balance sheet to complete open market repurchases and the cancellation of £9,512,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Existing Sterling Notes (€10.8 million euro equivalent) and €2,460,000 in aggregate principal amount of the Existing Euro Notes, which we completed in April and May 2023, in each case, as if each of these transactions had occurred on March 31, 2023. Upon completion of the Refinancing Transactions and the redemption of the Remaining Existing Notes on the Issue Date, the Existing Notes Indenture will be satisfied and discharged. See “Summary—The _Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds.” The aggregate carrying amount of the Existing Notes on our consolidated balance sheet_ as at March 31, 2023 was €602.1 million, consisting of a euro-equivalent amount of €254.4 million in respect of the Existing Sterling Notes and €347.7 million in respect of the Existing Euro Notes, and represents the euro-equivalent of the outstanding aggregate amount of the Existing Notes as at March 31, 2023, net of aggregate unamortized transaction cost of €3.6 million. (5) The Group intends to enter into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement on or about the Issue Date. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will, among other things, provide for revolving commitments of up to €450 million, including a €125 million sub-limit applicable to cash loans (although such sub-limit may be exceeded solely to provide cash security deposits as an alternative to or replacement for obligations under a standby letter of credit). The Revolving Credit Facility may be used for general working capital and other corporate purposes and will, the Group anticipates, primarily be used for letters of credit and bank guarantees (including by way of ancillary facilities on a bilateral basis with individual lenders, using such lenders’ revolving facility commitments). The original borrowers under the Revolving Credit Facility (including ancillary facilities) are Energia Group NI Holdings Limited and the Issuer. The Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed by the Issuer and the Guarantors and, on or about the Issue Date, will be secured by first priority security interests over the Collateral. See “Description of Other _Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.”_ (6) Represents the euro-equivalent of £71.0 million in principal amount of cash drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility as at March 31, 2023, as adjusted for the Debt Repayment Transactions, pursuant to which such borrowings were repaid in full on June 22, 2023. In addition to cash drawings, the Group had a euro-equivalent amount of €236.8 million of letters of credit outstanding under the ancillary facilities made available pursuant to the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, which on or about the Issue Date and following the completion of the Refinancing Transactions, the Group intends to close-out or replace with letters of credit under the Revolving Credit Facility, and the Existing Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will then be discharged and terminated. See “Summary—The Transactions.” (7) The adjustment of €150.0 million to shareholders’ equity relates to the payment of the TopCo Dividend, which is expected to be paid by the Group on or after the Issue Date. The table above excludes the impact of amounts relating to the write-off of existing unamortized debt issuance costs in connection with existing indebtedness and the incurrence of unamortized debt issuance costs in connection with the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Renewables_ Renewable energy continues to be a key priority in NI and the RoI and both governments have set targets for increasing the proportion of electricity sourced from renewables. NI’s energy strategy targets the achievement of 80% renewable electricity by 2030 and the RoI Climate Action Plan also sets an 80% renewable electricity target by 2030. ----- As at March 31, 2023, the Renewables segment owns and operates 309MW onshore wind generation assets across the RoI and NI, and has a pipeline of 49MW onshore wind generation assets under construction and 218MW of onshore wind generation assets in development. The Renewables segment also has a pipeline of 628MW of solar PV projects in development, and is currently commissioning a hydrogen electrolyzer onsite at one of its NI onshore wind farms. In addition, the Group is also progressing the development of two offshore wind generation projects off the coast of Ireland totaling up to 1.8GW. The Renewables segment’s operational and inconstruction onshore wind generation assets are outside of the Restricted Group. Similarly, assets in relation to the pipeline of other wind projects and solar PV projects, are also owned by Unrestricted Subsidiaries and therefore outside of the Restricted Group. The Restricted Group received distribution from the unrestricted subsidiaries under the Existing Notes Indenture totaling €61.8 million during Fiscal Year 2023. The Renewables segment also purchases renewable electricity through PPAs covering 1,247MW of operating renewable capacity as at March 31, 2023. Energia Group was the first independent supplier to participate in the deregulated electricity market and an early mover on offering offtake contracts to third parties. Its first renewable PPA was signed in 2002. The Group estimates that it currently represents approximately 21% of the Irish market for Renewable Obligation Certificates (“ROCs”) and Renewable Energy Feed-In Tariff (“REFIT”) supported wind PPAs. The Renewables segment provides the Energia Group with further access to regulated renewable support mechanisms, with minimal capital requirements and potential upside to the extent of future increases in wholesale power prices, as well as positioning Energia and Power NI as ‘green’ suppliers and enhancing relationships and presence with key stakeholders within the sector. In addition, the Group has a entered into a REFA with Microsoft designed to meet a substantial proportion of their electricity demand in Ireland, whereby the output from the Renewables segment’s pipeline of in-development onshore wind projects (including the 49MW of renewable capacity currently under construction) and solar PV projects are expected to be supported by corporate PPAs with the technology company. Energia Group’s Renewables segment revenue for Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022 was €427.2 million and €401.9 million, respectively, and its Adjusted EBITDA during these periods was €224.5 million and €211.5 million, respectively. _Flexible Generation_ The Flexible Generation segment undertakes trading, regulation and asset management activities on behalf of the Group. This includes the day-to-day operation and commercial optimization of two CCGT plants (Huntstown 1 and Huntstown 2) owned by the Group. The two Huntstown CCGTs are highly reliable, flexible and efficient plants, and their strategic location in the constrained Dublin area ensures at least one unit is running on most days of the year. Moreover, the Huntstown plants have the technical capacity to provide system-critical “Delivering a Secure, Sustainable Electricity System” (“DS3”) ancillary services, the importance of which has been increasing as the proportion of electricity generated by wind in Ireland has been growing. As at March 31, 2023, Huntstown has a total combined generation capacity of 747MW, which is able to supply approximately 10% of peak demand on an all-island basis (based on estimated peak demand of approximately 7,700MW). We believe that the two Huntstown CCGTs are critical to the security of electricity supply in the Dublin area. Under the Single Electricity Market (“SEM”), the Huntstown plants sell the generated energy into the Day-Ahead (“DAM”), Intra-Day (“IDM”) and Balancing Mechanism (“BM”) markets and sell capacity several years in advance via ‘Reliability Options’ as part of the Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (“CRM”). The Reliability Options have been awarded to the Group’s Huntstown plants for the current and next four capacity years, and include a clearing price of €83,050/MW for the capacity year 2026 to 2027. See also “Industry—The _All-Island Single Electricity Market—Energy Trading Arrangements—Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (CRM).” Huntstown sells energy at the market clearing prices in the DAM and IDM as well as receive (or in some_ cases make) other payments for energy through constraint payments in the BM. The Huntstown plants also receive payments associated with DS3 ancillary services. The Group has also recently developed and commissioned a 50MW battery storage project in NI which is operated and traded by the Flexible Generation business. The project has been awarded a 10-year capacity contract commencing in the capacity year 2022/2023, at a clearing price of £78,600/MW for 8.15MW of its 11.3MW derated capacity. The Group plans to develop a further pipeline of battery storage projects, which we expect will strengthen the Group’s position for future capacity auctions and provide an additional source for ancillary revenue. The Group has also entered into a contract with EirGrid to provide 50MW of emergency gas generation located at the Huntstown site for a duration of three years, extendible by EirGrid to five years. ----- Construction of this emergency gas generation project commenced in December 2022 and is planned to be completed by the end of 2023. The Group is developing a 165MW data center at its Huntstown campus in Dublin. The proposed data center has a grid connection offer and the lands necessary for the project have been acquired. Planning consent for the data center was received in April 2022 but the decision was appealed and the planning application is currently being considered by An Bord Pleanála, RoI’s national independent planning body. The Group expects _An Bord Pleanála to issue its decision in the near term and does not believe that there are grounds on which_ planning permission should be refused. The Group has entered into a contract with an international hyperscale technology company for a long term lease by it of the electrical infrastructure, buildings and integrated equipment at the data center. Capital expenditure in respect of the development of the data center was €20.0 million in Fiscal Year 2023 and €11.1 million in Fiscal Year 2022, primarily, in respect of land and development of electrical connections. Going forward, the Flexible Generation segment’s investment in the proposed data center in respect of the development of the data halls is expected to be an unrestricted investment and therefore outside of the Restricted Group. Investment in respect of the purchase of land, the design and build of all the high voltage electrical infrastructure (including a gas insulated substation and high voltage transformer switchyard) will be within the Restricted Group. The Flexible Generation segment also includes the Group’s PPB business which administers 600MW of contracted generation capacity from the Ballylumford power station in NI, which is subject to price control and entitles it to an allowance (effectively a management fee). This legacy PPB contract will expire in September 2023 in accordance with its terms. The PPB contract generated €14.6 million, €8.5 million and €9.3 million of EBITDA during the Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2022 and Fiscal Year 2021, respectively. For Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022, Flexible Generation generated €1,769.7 million and €989.5 million in revenue, respectively, and €204.7 million and €104.0 million in Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, based on, or after taking into account the adjustments for over/under recovery against, the regulated entitlement of PPB. _Customer Solutions_ The Group’s Customer Solutions business operates under the Energia and Power NI brands. Energia Energia is a price control unregulated retail supply business, which supplies electricity and natural gas to residential and business customers in the RoI. Business customers include LEU and SME customers. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, Energia supplied electricity to 14% of the LEU market, 30% of the SME market and 12% of the residential market in the RoI in terms of consumption. As part of its hedging strategy, the Group’s Flexible Generation segment undertakes wholesale electricity, natural gas, carbon and green certificate trading activities on behalf of the Customer Solutions segment. Power NI Power NI is the incumbent electricity supplier in NI, supplying electricity primarily to residential customers. While the residential electricity supply market in NI is open to competition, Power NI remains the biggest supplier with a 55.0% market share of residential supply in terms of consumption during the twelve months ended December 31, 2022. As a result, Power NI is still regarded as the dominant supplier and is therefore subject to price regulation. As a regulated business, Power NI is subject to price control which permits it to recover an allowance calculated by reference to its forecasted operating costs at the time of the relevant price control, plus an allowed margin based on a percentage of forecasted regulated revenue. On January 26, 2023, the UR confirmed the extension of the existing price control (which applies in respect to residential customers) to March 31, 2025. In addition, Power NI supplies electricity to business customers in the unregulated market and secures additional revenues through off-take from certain contracted smaller scale third party renewable generators (which are reported through the Renewables segment). In addition, the Customer Solutions business also offers energy efficiency services and car charging solutions to its customers across Ireland. For Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022, Customer Solutions generated €2,345.2 million and €1,780.1 million in revenue, respectively, and a loss of €162.1 million and €115.4 million in Adjusted EBITDA, ----- respectively, based on, or after taking into account the adjustments for over/under recovery against, the regulated entitlement of Power NI.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group is a leading integrated Irish energy business active in both Republic of Ireland (“RoI”) and Northern Ireland (“NI”). The Group primarily operates through three business units: - Renewables; - Flexible Generation; and - Customer Solutions. The Renewables business owns and operates 309MW of onshore wind generation assets as at March 31, 2023, and purchases electricity from 1,247MW of renewable generation capacity across Ireland as at March 31, 2023, through off-take contracts (primarily, renewable Power Purchase Agreements (“PPAs”)). In line with the Group’s decarbonization strategy, the Renewables business has expanded in recent years and now has a substantial pipeline of additional onshore wind and solar photovoltaic (“PV”) development projects and has also entered into a renewable energy framework agreement (“REFA”) with Microsoft, which is designed to meet a substantial proportion of their electricity demand in Ireland. The Renewables business is also currently commissioning a hydrogen electrolyzer onsite at one of its NI onshore wind farms and is progressing the development of two offshore wind generation projects off the coast of Ireland totaling up to 1.8GW. The Flexible Generation business owns and operates 747MW of conventional gas-fired generation assets in the RoI and procures power under contract with 600MW of conventional generation assets in NI, in each case, as at March 31, 2023. In addition, under the Flexible Generation business, the Group is currently undertaking the following key initiatives: - 50MW battery storage project in NI, which has been recently commissioned; - 50MW emergency gas generation project under a contract with EirGrid that is currently under construction and is planned to be commissioned by the end of 2023; and - a 165MW data center at its Huntstown campus in Dublin, which is currently under development. The Customer Solutions business supplies electricity or gas to a total of 828,300 customer sites across Ireland, comprising 311,700 customer sites in the RoI and 516,600 customer sites in NI, as at March 31, 2023, through its two retail brands, Energia and Power NI. With a digitally-enabled customer-centric focus, the business also offers energy efficiency services and car charging solutions to its customers across Ireland.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group receives a significant proportion of its revenue from capacity payments and wholesale generation sales. Revenues are impacted by the availability of generation capacity and generation volumes. There are two key revenue streams: (i) capacity payments, which are earned under Reliability Options received when the Group’s generation plants are successful in capacity auctions; and (ii) payments for generating and/or being scheduled to generate electricity, which are earned when the Group’s generation facilities are scheduled and/or dispatched by the system operator to generate electricity. Under SEM, whether a plant is scheduled to generate electricity is a function of its position in the Merit Order. See “Industry—Generation—The Merit Order” and “Industry—Generation—Network infrastructure, constraints and curtailment.” _Capacity payments_ The capacity remuneration mechanism, or CRM, was established by the UR and the CRU with the objective of ensuring the adequate supply of electricity by encouraging the construction and maintenance of electricity generation capacity and by promoting efficient long-term price signaling and price stability. The CRM capacity year runs from October 1 to September 30, and the mechanism is operated through capacity auctions, open to owners of physical generation assets and other capacity providers, that awards Reliability Options to successful bidders at the market clearing price (or above, if constrained on). A Reliability Option is a one-way contract for difference, entered into between a generator and a central agency, that incentivizes a generator to generate electricity at times of market price spikes in exchange for a fixed payment, while foregoing incremental revenue (by means of a “difference payment”) when the market price is above a defined strike price. Reliability Options may be awarded on an elevated pay-as-bid basis within certain constrained network areas. The maximum bid that may be submitted by an existing generator in the capacity auction is limited, by rule, to half the estimated net cost of new entry of a new dispatchable power plant (which at present is assumed to be an OCGT plant), unless a higher unit-specific price cap is granted to a generator. See “Industry—The All-Island Single Electricity _Market—The Single Electricity Market—Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (CRM).”_ The Reliability Options awarded to the Group’s Huntstown plants for the current and next four capacity years is summarized as follows:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s operating results are affected by a combination of economic, regulatory, industry- specific and company-specific factors. Economic conditions influence electricity demand and the pricing of fuel commodities and electricity, which affect both the revenues and costs associated with the Group’s operations. The regulatory framework determines the parameters within which the industry, generally, and the Group, specifically, operates. Industry-specific factors include technology, competition, capacity and supply/demand balance. Groupspecific factors that impact the Group’s operating results include, but are not limited to, plant reliability and efficiency, management of fixed and variable operating costs, capital expenditure requirements, management of working capital, customer retention, collection of receivables and bad debts, and the extent to which the Group has hedged its exposure to the SMP and commodity prices. The most important of such factors are discussed below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Huntstown 1 plant ................................................................................... 81.9 97.0 94.8 Huntstown 2 plant ................................................................................... 83.9 44.3 99.4 The Group believes the Huntstown plants have historically been among the most reliable CCGT plants in Ireland. Between Fiscal Year 2021 and Fiscal Year 2023, Huntstown 1 and Huntstown 2 plants had average availabilities (including planned and unplanned outages) of approximately 91% and 76%, respectively. For Fiscal Year 2022, Huntstown 2 plant’s availability (including planned and unplanned outages) was 44.3%, compared to 83.9% for Fiscal Year 2021, reflecting a transformer outage whereby on January 29, 2021, a fault was identified on the Huntstown 2 main generator transformer which resulted in the plant not being available to the market and resulted in a material impact to Group revenues as further discussed in “—Results of operations.” A new replacement transformer was procured and successfully installed and commissioned and the plant returned to service on October 23, 2021. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to our business—Mechanical failure, equipment _malfunction or technological breakdown could adversely affect our business and operating results.”_ For Fiscal Year 2022, Huntstown 1 plant’s availability (including planned and unplanned outages) was 97.0%, compared to 81.9% for Fiscal Year 2021, reflecting a 57-day planned major outage which commenced in October 2020 and was successfully completed in December 2020. For Fiscal Year 2023, Huntstown 2 plant’s availability was 99.4% compared to 44.3% for Fiscal Year 2022 (availability in Fiscal Year 2022 reflects the plant being unavailable since January 29, 2021 due to the generator transformer outage with subsequent return to service on October 23, 2021). For the Fiscal Year 2023, Huntstown 1 plant’s availability was 94.8% compared to 97.0% for the Fiscal Year 2022, reflecting a 12 day unplanned outage as a result of the failure of a circuit breaker connected to the plant’s static frequency convertor. While these outages, with the exception of the Huntstown 2 transformer outage, were largely within the Group’s planned guidelines, they nonetheless had an impact on the Group’s results for the periods in which they occurred. The Group expects availability going forward to remain high, considering planned outage time and an estimated 3% allowance for unplanned outage time based on historical performance. _Renewables_ The Group’s renewable PPA portfolio primarily consists of off-take contracts with third party owned wind farms alongside wind generation assets in which the Group has an equity interest. The Group, pursuant to its Customer Solutions business, has entered into contracts with developers under which it has agreed to purchase the long-term output of a number of wind farm projects and with generators from other renewable sources (e.g., anaerobic digestion and biomass technologies). As at March 31, 2023 the Group had PPAs in place with an operating capacity of 1,247MW of which the NI operating capacity was 664MW and the RoI operating capacity was 583MW. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Demand for electricity in Ireland is a key driver of the Group’s revenue and affects price levels for wholesale generation as well as both volumes and margins for electricity supplied to customers. Demand for energy, including electricity, has historically been correlated with GDP and the wider macroeconomic climate. Based on their median demand scenario, EirGrid and SONI have forecast annual all-island electricity demand to grow, on average, by 3.5% per year from 2021 through 2031; however, such growth is dependent on the factors described above as well as under the heading “Risk Factors—Risks related to our business.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s plant utilization levels depend on the positions contracted in the ex-ante physical markets, as well as any balancing actions ordered by the TSOs in the ex post balancing market. A large proportion of demand is currently met by coal and gas-fired generators whose ranking in the Merit Order fluctuates depending on the relative coal-to-gas price differentials and carbon prices. Last in the Merit Order are generation units such as oil-fired turbines, which are mainly used as peaking plants with typically the highest marginal costs. The Huntstown plants are reliant upon the continued provision of imported natural gas in terms of both capacity and commodity price risk, although the plants can switch to less efficient distillate oil, if necessary. However, their Merit Order position may also be affected by: - the commissioning of new more efficient power plants that can generate electricity at a lower marginal cost than the Huntstown plants as well as; and - increased wind and solar PV capacity. ----- For Fiscal Year 2023, average unconstrained utilization was 63.9% for the Huntstown 1 plant and 73.0% for the Huntstown 2 plant compared with 65.5% and 44.0%, respectively, for Fiscal Year 2022 and 68.4% and 54.7%, respectively, for Fiscal Year 2021. The decrease in unconstrained utilization of Huntstown 2 in Fiscal Year 2022 compared to Fiscal Year 2021 reflected a transformer outage whereby on January 29, 2021, a fault was identified on the Huntstown 2 main generator transformer which resulted in the plant not being available to the market. A new replacement transformer was procured and successfully installed and commissioned and the plant returned to service on October 23, 2021. The Huntstown plants have experienced incremental constrained utilization to support the grid within the Dublin region. The Huntstown plants are frequently dispatched “out of merit,” and at any time, at least one of the plants is typically running either “in merit” or on a “constrained” basis to ensure system stability. For Fiscal Year 2023, the incremental impact of constrained utilization was 4.1% constrained on for the Huntstown 1 plant and 11.4% constrained off for the Huntstown 2 plant compared with 0.9% constrained on and 0.4% constrained off, respectively, for Fiscal Year 2022 and 2.6% constrained off and 6.2% constrained off, respectively, for Fiscal Year 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Renewables_ Renewable energy continues to be a key priority in NI and the RoI and both governments have each set targets for increasing the proportion of electricity sourced from renewables. NI’s energy strategy is built around a target to achieve 80% renewable electricity by 2030 and the RoI Climate Action Plan also sets an 80% renewable electricity target by 2030. To help achieve these targets, both governments have provided mechanisms to support investment in renewable sources. See “Industry—Generation—Thermal generation.” _Support for renewable energy_ In the RoI, support for renewable energy is currently provided by the RESS and Offshore RESS (ORESS) schemes having previously been provided by the REFIT scheme. Both RESS and ORESS allocate support in the form of a two way CfD via a competitive pay as bid auction. The Climate Action Plan 2023 commits Ireland to having 9GW of onshore wind, 8GW solar PV and at least 5GW of Offshore wind installed by 2030, with the expectation being that RESS and ORESS will provide the route to market for the majority of this capacity. The First RESS auction took place in 2020, procuring over 1.2GW of onshore wind and solar PV at an average strike price of €74.08/MWh. RESS 2 took place in 2022 and awarded support to just under 2GW of capacity at an average price of €97.87/MWh again predominantly onshore wind and solar PV. RESS 3 is scheduled to take place in 2023, targeting the procurement of almost double the capacity in RESS 2. RESS 4 is scheduled to take place in 2024 and will seek to procure a similar quantity of capacity to RESS 3. The first offshore RESS auction (ORESS1) took place in May 2023, procuring over 3GW at a weighted average strike price of €86.05/MWh for a 20 year term. Latest government policy indicates that a second offshore RESS auction for 900MW (ORESS2.1) off the South coast process could begin by the end of 2023 with an auction expected in the first half of 2024. ORESS2 is expected to run up to two further auctions, so that ORESS1 & ORESS2 will procure the 5GW of capacity required to achieve the CAP target. European State aid clearance for the RESS and ORESS Scheme expires in 2025, although it may be possible to extend it beyond 2025. In the RoI, support for renewable energy was provided by the REFIT scheme, which is now closed to new capacity. REFIT was implemented in 2006 and was designed to encourage licensed electricity suppliers to enter into PPAs for up to 15 years with renewable generators, under which the suppliers would contractually agree the off-take price to be paid to the generators. Electricity suppliers are then compensated for the additional cost of purchasing electricity from renewable sources. Under REFIT, suppliers are compensated if the SEM market price, including constraint payments achieved for electricity generated and capacity payments earned by a particular renewable generating unit in a calendar year, is below a base reference price. The reference price is indexed annually (upwards only) at the RoI Consumer Price Index, and in 2023 is set at a floor of €78.356/MWh for large scale wind generation and €81.105/MWh for smaller scale wind generators together with an unindexed (in the case of REFIT 2 and REFIT 3) supplier balancing payment of (a) in the case of REFIT 1, 15% of the large scale wind price for REFIT 1 (being €11.754/MWh for 2023) and (b) in the case of REFIT 2 and REFIT 3, up to €9.90/MWh, depending on the extent to which the market revenues exceed the applicable reference price in REFIT 2 and 3, REFIT, therefore, requires a minimum price to be paid to electricity suppliers for electricity sourced from renewable generators while allowing the supplier to retain any price upside should the SEM market price exceed ----- the floor price. The REFIT floor price mechanism is of particular value in markets with volatile fuel and electricity prices. DfE are consulting on the implementation of a new support scheme for NI, which, although not yet decided, is expected to be in the form of a 2-way CfD type contract awarded via a competitive auction. NI’s prior support mechanism was an extension of the RO regime used in Great Britain. The previous scheme, called the NI Renewables Obligation (NIRO) closed to new large scale onshore wind on March 31, 2016, to new small scale onshore wind on June 30, 2016 and to all other technologies on March 31, 2017, with exceptions to those projects that met the criteria for grace periods. Under the NIRO regime, eligible renewable generators receive ROCs for each MWh of electricity generated. ROCs are freely tradable at auction and can be sold to suppliers in order to fulfil their obligations under the RO regime. Suppliers have the option of presenting ROCs to cover their obligations or paying a buyout fee of £59.01/MWh (for the 2023-24 financial year) for any shortfall. All proceeds from buyout fees are repaid to the holders of ROCs. _Constraints and curtailment_ The TSOs have a responsibility to ensure that the electricity system is managed prudently which requires generation to be constrained at certain locations. To ensure efficient and secure operation of the electricity system, generation is constrained to certain levels to prevent overloading, voltages outside prescribed limits or system instability. In the context of wind farms, a constraint event occurs when there is insufficient capacity on the network to accept the export of the generator. Access to the transmission network is currently offered either on a “firm” or “non-firm” basis depending on whether network reinforcements are required to facilitate the generator’s full export capacity. While a generator which has been granted firm access to the transmission network may experience a reduction in its exported generation at times of high system production, it is eligible to receive limited financial compensation. Non-firm generators by contrast are not entitled to financial compensation for any reduction in its exported generation experienced due to either constraint or curtailment. However, a generator with non-firm access may have its exported output reduced without any compensation. Firm access would only be granted once the required investment in the transmission network infrastructure has been completed or by a deemed firm date which the TSO notifies to each generator. Curtailment is a system operation issue and is not linked to the capacity of the network. Curtailment of wind generation occurs where there is excess wind generation available relative to system demand when taking account of system operation restrictions (such as minimum stable generation levels of thermal assets). Curtailment occurs when this excess wind generation cannot be accommodated and the overall level of renewable generation must be reduced across the system. While the increasing amount of wind generation capacity in Ireland naturally increases the risk of curtailment, the increase in ancillary services under DS3 and the potential for an increase in electricity exports to Great Britain (and in future to France) under SEM are expected to provide a countervailing influence. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to our business—The quantity of electricity actually produced by _Energia Group’s wind farms and PPAs, including as a result of curtailment and constraint actions by the TSO, may vary from its estimates” and “Industry—Generation—Network infrastructure, constraints and curtailment.” NI supply regulation_ While RoI electricity market prices are fully deregulated, in NI, Power NI residential customers remain subject to a regulated tariff. The last non-residential customer segment (customers consuming less than 50MWh per year) was only fully deregulated from April 1, 2017. The UR’s plans for deregulation of the residential market are not yet clear. As a result, the Group is unable to accurately predict the structure of future market regulation and further deregulation could affect the Group’s market share. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to our business— _Our businesses are subject to complex governmental legislation and regulations that have affected, and may in the future affect, our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_ The regulated tariffs set by the UR are currently based on an allowed revenue model, which allows Power NI to recover an allowance calculated by reference to its forecasted operating cost at the time of the relevant price control and residual depreciation plus a net margin. The regulatory model has an incentive mechanism by which Power NI is allowed to retain savings achieved through efficiencies for at least the period of the price control. If the amount of revenue recovered in any one year exceeds or falls short of the amount allowed by the relevant price control formula, a K factor operates in the following year that requires either a repayment of any surplus with interest or a recovery of any deficit with interest, as appropriate. A surplus is referred to as an overrecovery and a deficit as an under- recovery. In the formulation of its regulated tariffs, Power NI is allowed to pass through to customers all underlying wholesale costs, subject to an economic purchasing obligation. ----- Power NI is required to submit a forecast of all its input costs for each tariff review, which is then subject to agreement with the UR. The main tariff year runs from October each year. Once agreed, the new tariffs apply from October 1, with the possibility that they may be changed at the beginning of each quarter if actual costs and revenues do not stay within a level of tolerance to the tariff (i.e., plus or minus 2.5%). On June 2, 2023 Power NI announced a 5.1% increase in its regulated electricity tariff, effective from July 1, 2023. The increase, agreed with the UR, reflected a reduction in government support.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The profitability and cash generation of the Group’s Customer Solutions business are driven by its ability to pass wholesale prices to end customers together with retail margin, the collection of receivables and the minimization of bad debts. The ability to pass wholesale prices to end customers is affected by the level of competition and regulation. Regulated businesses, such as Power NI, are entitled to recover their operating costs and make a regulated margin. As this margin is relatively low, it restricts competition in the regulated marketplace, but it also places a limit on the regulated business’ profitability. Unregulated supply businesses may be significantly more exposed to competition, and their ability to recover their operating costs depends on the level of competition. There is limited liquidity in the market for CfDs related to the SMP, which means that supply businesses may be exposed to cost premiums for such CfDs and may be required to resort to less effective hedging arrangements or risk exposure to increases in operating costs that they may not be able to recover in the market. However, the Group considers supply businesses backed by physical generation capacity within the SEM, such as the Energia Group, which is backed by Huntstown and its owned and contractual wind farms, are better protected against such cost premiums as they benefit from a natural hedge against price spikes, outage at other generators or a drop in wind output to the extent of the overlap between generation and supply volumes. Although the Energia Group substantially hedges any mismatch, mainly through CfDs, it is exposed to movements in the wholesale price when the hedges expire and to the extent of any unhedged or imperfectly hedged volume. See “Business—Hedging.” Bad debts can have a material impact on cash flows, especially during periods of economic downturn. Historically, Energia and Power NI have been successful at minimizing bad debt levels, with a bad debt to revenue ratio of 0.2% for Energia and 0.3% for Power NI for Fiscal Year 2023. The Group considers that this was achieved through proactive credit management, including a focus on creditworthiness at the time of customer acquisition, and the use of prepayment meters and direct debit payment plans. For Fiscal Year 2023, approximately 35.4% of Power NI’s customers utilized prepayment meters and approximately 92.0% of Energia’s customers and approximately 39.0% of Power NI’s customers paid using a direct debit payment plan. In addition, the Energia Group mitigates the effect of customers defaulting by using credit insurance in respect of certain customers. See “—Quantitative and qualitative disclosure about market risk—Credit risk.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s business is subject to seasonal variations, which normally impact levels of demand for electricity and natural gas, with demand typically trending higher during the winter months and lower during the summer months. However, because variations in demand from season to season are largely offset by counterbalancing movements in natural gas transmission costs, seasonality does not tend to have a significant impact on the Group’s profitability from period to period. However, changes in demand and prices caused by seasonal variations can have an impact on the Group’s working capital over the course of the year, with working capital typically increasing during the winter months when demand and prices are high, and decreasing during the summer months. Seasonality also influences the volume of electricity the Group generates from wind farms, with less wind-generated electricity during the summer months.

Subsubsection Text: - RoI ......................................................................... — — 628 **628 **309** **49** **846** **1,204** The table above excludes the Group’s two offshore wind generation projects off the coast of Ireland with a combined capacity of up to 1.8GW. The Group continues to progress the development of its onshore wind pipeline projects and expects to enter into corporate PPAs for such development projects. Over the course of Fiscal Year 2022, Energia Group completed the acquisition of two wind farm development projects (Drumlins Wind Park and Ballylongford) in the RoI. In May 2022 the Group entered into a turbine supply agreement for the Drumlins project. Construction has commenced and commissioning is expected in 2024. The project is expected to be underpinned by a corporate PPA with Microsoft. The Group has foreshore licenses to carry out preliminary surveys to investigate the feasibility of offshore wind generation at sites in the North Celtic Sea and the South Irish Sea and public consultation processes are ongoing for both projects. The Group has consented solar PV projects in the RoI for which it has submitted planning applications to increase the scale of these projects. In addition, the Group is progressing a number of further greenfield solar PV development opportunities in the RoI. The Group continues to assess a number of other opportunities to acquire and develop further renewable development projects. Energia Group, through certain of the Unrestricted Subsidiaries, has put in place certain non-recourse project finance facilities in respect of its operating onshore wind assets. The Group expects to put in place further project finance facilities for its renewable development projects going forward. See “Description of Other _Indebtedness.”_ In Fiscal Year 2023, distributions of €61.8 million were made from the operating onshore wind generation assets, which are held by Unrestricted Subsidiaries, to the Restricted Group. Distributions from the Unrestricted Subsidiaries, in respect of the operating onshore wind generation assets, are eliminated upon consolidation at Group level.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes the ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs, debt service obligations, capital expenditures, contractual obligations and other commitments. The Group’s primary sources of liquidity are cash from operating activities and its financings. In addition, the Group currently has access to the Revolving Credit Facility to service working capital and general corporate needs. The Group’s liquidity requirements arise primarily to meet debt service obligations, to fund capital expenditures (including the development of the Group’s Renewables and Flexible Generation businesses) and to provide working capital (including collateral required to ----- be posted to the markets in which the Group trades). The availability of the Revolving Credit Facilities is dependent upon conditions, including compliance with a financial maintenance covenant as described further under “Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.” The Group’s financial condition and liquidity is and will continue to be influenced by a variety of factors, including: - the Group’s ability to generate cash flows from its operations; - the level of outstanding indebtedness and the indebtedness of the Group’s subsidiaries, and the interest on such indebtedness; - the Group’s ability and the ability of the Group’s subsidiaries to continue to borrow funds from financial institutions; and - the Group’s growth funding requirements, which consist primarily of the funding of development of its Renewables and Flexible Generation businesses. The Group’s cash requirements consist mainly of the following: - funding working capital requirements (including collateral required to be posted to the markets in which the Group trades); - funding capital expenditure needs (including the development of the Group’s renewables businesses); - servicing the Group’s indebtedness and the indebtedness of the Group’s subsidiaries; - operating activities; and - paying taxes. The Group expects that its sources of liquidity will consist mainly of the following: - cash generated from the Group’s operating activities; - borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility; - issuances of debt securities; and - borrowings under other loan facilities and finance leases, including project finance facilities. Although the Group believes that its expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings, will be adequate to meet its anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, no assurance can be given that the Group’s business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to the Group in an amount sufficient to enable it to pay its debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund other liquidity needs. The Group believes that potential risks to its liquidity include: - a reduction in operating cash flows, which could be due to downturns in performance or the industry as a whole; - a reduction in the ability of the Group to obtain dividends or other distributions from the businesses in its Unrestricted Subsidiaries; - adverse working capital developments (including potential shifts by market operators to cash collateral requirements away from letters of credit); - exposure to increased interest rates in relation to borrowings which bear interest at a variable rate, including the Revolving Credit Facility; and ----- - higher capital expenditure, such as due to higher than expected expenses incurred in connection with the Group’s development projects and strategies. If the Group’s future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay its obligations as they mature or to fund liquidity needs, the Group may be forced to: - reduce or delay business activities and capital expenditure (including development projects); - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or - restructure or refinancing all or a portion of the Group’s debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. No assurance can be given that the Group would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of the Group’s existing debt, including the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility, limit the Group’s ability to pursue any of these alternatives, as may the terms of any future debt.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group has significant leverage and debt service obligations. As at March 31, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, the Group would have had €888.5 million of total debt and the Restricted Group would have had €600 million of total debt reflecting the Notes and excluding letters of credit issued under our Revolving Credit Facility. The Indenture governing the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement collectively contain covenants significantly restricting the Group’s ability to, among other things: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase capital stock of the Company or its restricted subsidiaries; - make certain investments; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - create encumbrances or restrictions on the ability of subsidiaries to pay dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to, and on the transfer of assets to, the Company or any of its restricted subsidiaries; - transfer, lease or sell assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - enter into unrelated businesses; - impair the security interests in the Collateral; and - amend certain documents. Each of the covenants is subject to a number of important exceptions and qualifications. These covenants could limit the Group’s ability to finance its future operations and capital needs. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also contains a financial covenant requiring the Group to comply with a certain minimum EBITDA level when the Revolving Credit Facility is drawn beyond a certain level at the end of a quarter (which financial covenant applies only to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). ----- Management anticipates that the Group’s significant leverage could increase for the foreseeable future and an increase in the Group’s high level of debt may have important negative consequences for you. For further information, see “Risk Factors—Risks related to our structure—The Group’s significant leverage and debt service _obligations could adversely affect its business and prevent it from fulfilling its obligations with respect to the Notes and the Guarantees,” “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Description of the Notes.”_ Historically, the Restricted Group has been financed through a combination of cash generated from operations, revolving credit arrangements and from long term financing arrangements such as the Existing Notes. Following the Transactions, the Restricted Group’s primary financing arrangements will comprise of the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Certain Relationships and _Related Party Transactions.” Liquidity, including short-term working capital requirements, is managed through_ committed senior revolving credit bank facilities together with available cash resources. The following table summarizes the Group’s cash flow activity for Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2022 and Fiscal Year 2021.

Subsubsection Text: (1) Includes Adjusted EBITDA of unrestricted renewable assets (Fiscal Year 2023: €89.5 million; Fiscal Year 2022: €79.1 million; Fiscal Year 2021: €43.9 million). (2) Includes changes in working capital of unrestricted renewable assets (Fiscal Year 2023: €10.6 million decrease; Fiscal Year 2022: €8.7 million increase; Fiscal Year 2021: €0.6 million decrease). Changes in working capital includes the net expenditure on the sale and purchases of other intangibles. (3) Includes capital expenditure on unrestricted renewable assets (Fiscal Year 2023: €27.6 million; Fiscal Year 2022: €12.9 million; Fiscal Year 2021: €17.2 million). (4) Includes deferred income of €6.9 million (Fiscal Year 2022: nil) in relation to the group’s emergency generation project and grant income of €0.7 million (Fiscal Year 2022: €0.3 million) offset by €0.3 million release of government grant in relation to the Hydrogen project. _Pro-forma cash flow from operations_ Pro-forma cash flow from operations increased to €393.8 million for Fiscal Year 2023 from €357.5 million for Fiscal Year 2022, primarily reflecting an increase in Adjusted Group EBITDA from €200.1 million to €267.1 million, an over-recovery of regulated entitlement of €149.8 million during Fiscal Year 2023 (Fiscal Year 2022: €35.5 million), and a lower increase in security deposits of €15.0 million during Fiscal Year 2023 (Fiscal Year 2022: €30.8 million), partly offset by an increase in working capital of €7.6 million during Fiscal Year 2023 (Fiscal Year 2022: €155.5 million decrease). Pro-forma cash flow from operations increased to €357.5 million for Fiscal Year 2022 from €112.4 million for Fiscal Year 2021, primarily reflecting an increase in Adjusted Group EBITDA from €194.1 million to €200.1 million, a decrease in working capital of €155.5 million during Fiscal Year 2022 (Fiscal Year 2021: €109.9 million increase), partly offset by a higher increase in security deposits of €30.8 million (Fiscal Year 2021: €0.2 million). ----- _Net movement in security deposits_ The net movement in security deposits was an outflow of €15.0 million for Fiscal Year 2023 (Fiscal Year 2022: outflow of €30.8 million). The cash flow for Fiscal Year 2023 reflects the impact of high commodity prices and inflation on collateral requirements. The net movement in security deposits was an outflow of €30.8 million for Fiscal Year 2022. The cash flow for Fiscal Year 2022 reflects the impact of high commodity prices on collateral requirements. The net movement in security deposits was an outflow of €0.2 million for Fiscal Year 2021. The cash flow for Fiscal Year 2021 reflects the replacement of letters of credit with cash security deposits. As at March 31, 2023 there were €56.6 million of security deposits in place (March 31, 2022: €42.1 million; March 31, 2021: €11.3 million). _Changes in working capital_ Working capital consists of inventories plus trade and other receivables (primarily retail energy sales including unbilled consumption wholesale energy income, capacity payment income and ROC sales), prepayments and accrued income less trade and other creditors (primarily wholesale energy costs, capacity payments, natural gas and fixed natural gas capacity costs, renewable PPA costs, ROC costs, emission costs and use of system charges), payments received on account, accruals and tax and social security. Group working capital Working capital increased by €7.6 million for Fiscal Year 2023, primarily reflecting a decrease in trade and other payables (reflecting a decrease in gas prices (March 2023 relative to March 2022), a reduction in volumes partly offset by an increase in contract liabilities (associated with the RoI Electricity Support Credit scheme), provision for the Inframarginal Revenue Cap and Electricity Generator Levy and a net increase in emissions liabilities/assets (associated with an increase in carbon prices and higher generation volumes) and an increase in ROC assets, partly offset by a decrease in trade and other receivables (reflecting a decrease in contract assets (associated with proceeds from the Huntstown 2 outage insurance claim and lower hedge accrued income due to lower gas prices (March 2023 relative to March 2022)) and by an increase in trade receivables (due to increased tariffs and prices partly offset by lower volumes)). Working capital decreased by €155.5 million for Fiscal Year 2022, primarily reflecting an increase in trade and other payables (reflecting higher prices, an increase in the Renewable Energy Feed-In Tariff (REFIT) creditor (previously debtor) for Renewables PPAs resulting from higher prices, a decrease in ROC assets held, a net increase in emissions liabilities/assets (driven by higher prices and volumes), partly offset by an increase in trade and other receivables (reflecting higher prices, an increase in hedge debtors (partly offset by early settlement of some hedges when gas prices peaked in March) together with amounts outstanding for the property damage and business interruption insurance claim. Working capital increased by €109.9 million for Fiscal Year 2021, primarily reflecting a reduction in the PSO creditor in PPB, an increase in the Renewable Energy Feed-In Tariff (REFIT) debtor for renewable PPAs, an increase in ROC assets, favorable reassessment of SEM market resettlement provisions and an increase in trade and other receivables (reflecting higher electricity sales volumes and prices). _Over/(under)-recovery of regulated entitlement_ The regulated businesses of Power NI and PPB over-recovered against their regulated entitlement by €149.8 million for Fiscal Year 2023, over-recovered by €35.5 million for Fiscal Year 2022, and over-recovered by €34.4 million for Fiscal Year 2021. These changes were primarily due to the phasing of tariffs. _Exceptional cash outflows_ Exceptional cash outflows of €1.1 million for Fiscal Year 2023, €1.1 million for Fiscal Year 2022 and €0.3 million for Fiscal Year 2021, primarily relate to costs associated with acquisitions and disposals (whether successful or not). ----- _Capital expenditure_ Capital expenditure in respect of tangible fixed assets and intangible software assets increased to €103.0 million for Fiscal Year 2023 from €66.5 million for Fiscal Year 2022, reflecting increased capital expenditure in the Renewables, Flexible Generation and Customer Solutions businesses as outlined below. Capital expenditure in respect of tangible fixed assets and intangible software assets increased to €66.5 million for Fiscal Year 2022 from €39.5 million for Fiscal Year 2021, reflecting higher expenditure in Renewables and Customer Solutions offset by lower expenditure in the Flexible Generation businesses, reflecting lower expenditure in respect of the storage and data center projects. Capital expenditure at Renewables increased to €40.6 million for Fiscal Year 2023 from €14.7 million for Fiscal Year 2022, reflecting capital expenditure on development projects (notably including the commencement of construction of the Drumlin on-shore windfarm project and expenditure on off-shore projects). Capital expenditure was €17.2 million for Renewables for Fiscal Year 2021. Capital expenditure at Flexible Generation was €49.3 million for Fiscal Year 2023 and €39.1 million for Fiscal Year 2022 primarily reflecting initial expenditure on the data center and emergency generation projects (primarily in respect of the purchase of lands and infrastructure costs) partly offset by lower expenditure on the recently commissioned 50MW battery storage project in NI. Capital expenditure was €7.2 million for Flexible Generation for Fiscal Year 2021. Capital expenditure at Customer Solutions companies increased to €13.1 million for Fiscal Year 2023 (Fiscal Year 2022: €12.7 million), primarily reflecting higher expenditure in respect of IT projects. Capital expenditure was €15.1 million for Customer Solutions for Fiscal Year 2021. _Other_ The Group can have significant movements in its liquidity position due to working capital variations such as the movements in commodity prices, the seasonal nature of the business and regulatory under- and overrecoveries. Short-term liquidity is reviewed daily by the treasury function and Group cash forecasts, covering a rolling two-year period, are reviewed monthly. Liquidity, including short-term working capital requirements, is currently managed through the Existing Revolving Credit Facility together with available cash resources. In March 2022, with the consent of its lenders, the Group increased the Existing Revolving Credit Facility to £305 million (previously £225 million) and extended the maturity to June 2024 (previously September 2023). At March 31, 2023, the Group had letters of credit issued under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility of €236.8 million (at March 31, 2022: €193.3 million; at March 31, 2021: €155.0 million) resulting in undrawn committed facilities of €29.1 million (at March 31, 2022; €109.0 million; at March 31, 2021: €109.2 million). Cash drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility at March 31, 2023 were €80.7 million (at March 31, 2022: €59.3 million; at March 31, 2021: nil). As of the Issue Date, the Group expects to have no cash drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the Group’s indebtedness, the Group has three primary types of contractual obligations. First, the Group is a party to PPAs with the Group’s wholly-owned and third-party owned wind farms and with third-party generators of other renewable energy sources through which the Group is obligated to purchase the electricity these generators produce. Second, through PPB, the Group has entered into GUAs with Ballylumford in NI, where Ballylumford makes their generating units available to PPB in return for the receipt of availability payments. The Ballylumford contracts will expire in September 30, 2023. Third, the Group has entered into operating lease arrangements for the hire of equipment and buildings as these arrangements have historically been a cost-efficient way of obtaining the short-term benefits of these assets. These are accounted for under IFRS 16 Leases. As at March 31, 2023, the Group had contracted future capital expenditure in respect of tangible fixed assets of €39.9 million (€15.0 million as at March 31, 2022 and €6.2 million as at March 31, 2021) and intangible fixed assets of €2.5 million (€3.6 million as at March 31 2022 and nil as at March 31 2021). Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group is required to provide LOCs to certain counterparties to support the Group’s performance obligations during the ordinary course of the Group’s business activities. These LOCs are required for companies operating in the Irish energy markets and are primarily to cover the counterparty’s settlement exposure. The LOCs may be called for cash by the counterparty in the event of a non-payment. The Group provides LOCs primarily to counterparties to the Group’s contracts for the purchase of electricity and natural gas, the Group’s CfDs and its contracts for transmission and distribution use of system. The SEM in Ireland is a fully collateralized market requiring all supply companies to provide collateral in the form of an LOC or cash to ensure that generators of electricity are paid for their output. Both Power NI and Energia Group provide LOCs to the SEMO for this purpose. Energia Group is also required in certain circumstances to provide LOCs to its natural gas suppliers for its purchases of natural gas for both fueling the Huntstown power plants and selling on to its retail customers. Further, both Power NI and Energia Group are required to provide LOCs to ESB to cover charges under CfDs entered into with generators to hedge their exposure to volatility in the SEM pool price. ----- The Group also provides LOCs to those counterparties that provide for the transmission and distribution of electricity and transportation of natural gas. Power NI and Energia Group provide LOCs to ESB and NIEN for the use of their electricity systems. Energia Group provides LOCs to GNI for the use of its natural gas transportation network. The Group typically provides LOCs with a tenor of up to twelve months.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For a description of the Group’s project financing arrangements with respect to its Unrestricted Subsidiaries, see “Description of Other Indebtedness—Non-recourse project finance facilities.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and qualitative disclosure about market risk
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s treasury function manages liquidity, funding, investment and the Group’s financial risk, including risk from volatility in currency, interest rates, commodity prices and counterparty credit risk. The treasury function’s objective is to manage risk at optimum cost in line with Group policies and procedures approved by the Board. The treasury function employs a continuous forecasting and monitoring process to manage risk and to ensure that the Group complies with its financial and operating covenants.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and qualitative disclosure about market risk
Subsubsection Text: Energia employs commodity swaps to hedge gas price exposures and forward purchase contracts to hedge its shortfall of carbon dioxide (CO2) emission allowances. Energia’s policy is to hedge its exposure to changes in the price of gas and CO2 emission allowances in line with retail electricity sales contracts. Power NI employs commodity swaps to hedge gas price exposures and GB Power price exposures. Power NI’s policy is to hedge its exposure to changes in the price of gas and GB Power relative to retail electricity sales contracts. PPB is exposed to commodity price fluctuations in respect of its generation contracts. These exposures are hedged through the use of commodity swaps and forward purchase contracts in accordance with a policy agreed with the UR. Energia, Power NI and PPB enter into SEM CfDs to manage their exposure to pool price volatility. The estimated fair value of the Group’s commodity derivative financial instruments is disclosed in the notes to the Financial Statements contained in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and qualitative disclosure about market risk
Subsubsection Text: As at March 31, 2023, the Group’s debt was relatively evenly split between Euro and Sterling. The Group has not designated a hedging relationship between the Euro-denominated assets on the Group’s balance sheet and the Group’s Euro borrowings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Loans and other borrowings currency analysis:
Subsubsection Text: The Group may enter into interest and currency hedging agreements to hedge its exposure to fluctuations in interest rates and foreign currency exchange rates, primarily in respect of its outstanding capital markets debt obligations, including the Notes. Under these agreements, the Group is exposed to credit risks of its counterparties. If one or more of its counterparties falls into bankruptcy, claims the Group has under the swap agreements may become worthless. In addition, in the event that the Group refinances its debt or otherwise terminates hedging agreements, it may be required to make termination payments, which would result in a loss.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Loans and other borrowings currency analysis:
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s credit risk is primarily attributable to its trade receivables. Provisions are made based on previous experience and identifiable events which indicate a reduction in the recoverability of cash flows. Sustained periods of volatile and increasing prices for gas and carbon have resulted in higher SEM market prices for electricity. In this regard, with increasing electricity prices being passed through to customers through higher tariffs, the Group has applied an incremental allowance for expected credit losses in line with the methodology adopted. However, there remains a risk that the actual level of deferral or default on payments by customers is higher than that assumed when estimating the provisions made at the balance sheet date. Energia and Power NI are not exposed to major concentrations of credit risk in respect of their trade receivables, with exposure spread over a large number of customers, but may be exposed to credit-related loss in the event of non-performance by hedging counterparties. Energia and Power NI hold credit insurance and obtain security deposits, where relevant, under their credit policies in respect of certain trade receivables. Energia, PPB and Power NI also receive security from certain suppliers in the form of letters of credit, parent company guarantees or cash collateral. The Group may be exposed to credit-related loss in the event of non-performance by bank counterparties. The Group manages this credit risk by establishing and monitoring counterparty exposure limits which are adjusted and tightened when necessary. The Group actively manages its banking exposures on a daily basis and cash deposits are placed for periods not exceeding six months to provide maximum flexibility. During Fiscal Year 2021, Fiscal Year 2022 and Fiscal Year 2023, the Group did not suffer any bank counterparty exposure loss.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Loans and other borrowings currency analysis:
Subsubsection Text: Prior to the Offering, the Group’s only exposure to interest rate risk is in respect of drawings on the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, which were €80.7 million at March 31, 2023 (€59.3 million was drawn at March 31, 2022), and to a minor portion of its project financed facilities which are based on SONIA/EURIBOR rates but which are largely fixed through the use of interest rate swaps. As a result, at March 31, 2023, 89.1% of the Group’s total borrowings were on a fixed rate basis and therefore not subject to any interest rate risk. Following the Transactions, the Group will be subject to interest rate risk in respect of drawings on the Revolving Credit Facility, to the extent drawn.

The Group’s policy is to identify foreign exchange exposures with a value equivalent to or greater than €1.0 million with the percentage level of hedging dependent on the specific project.
