Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group has disclosed additional information in respect of exceptional items on the face of the income statement to aid understanding of the Group’s financial performance. An item is treated as exceptional if it is considered unusual by nature and scale and of such significance that separate disclosure is required for the financial statements to be properly understood. “Certain remeasurements” are remeasurements arising on certain commodity, interest rate and currency contracts which are not designated in hedge accounting relationships, and which are accounted for as held for trading in accordance with the Group’s policy for such financial instruments. This excludes commodity contracts not treated as financial instruments under IFRS 9 where held for the Group’s own use requirements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue on energy sales include an estimate of the value of electricity or gas supplied to customers between the date of the last meter reading and the year end. This will have been estimated by using historical consumption patterns. At the balance sheet date, the estimated consumption by customers will either have been billed or accrued (estimated unbilled revenue). Management apply judgement to the measurement of the quantum and valuation of the estimated consumption, including an estimate in respect of the impact of increased commodity prices, inflation and interest rates that may impact the Group customers’ ability to pay. As at March 31, 2023, the level of unbilled revenue not recognized was €37.6 million (As at March 31, 2022: €44.7 million). The judgements applied and the assumptions underpinning these judgements are considered to be appropriate. However, for every 1% change in these assumptions the impact upon the amount of revenue recognized would be €1.5 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group reviews the carrying amounts of its goodwill, other intangible assets and property, plant and equipment to determine whether there is any indication that the value of those assets is impaired. This requires an estimation of the value in use of the CGUs to which the assets are allocated which includes the estimation of future cash flows and the application of a suitable discount rate. Subsequent changes to these estimates or judgements may impact the carrying value of the assets within the respective CGUs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Business combinations require a fair value exercise to be undertaken to allocate the purchase price to the fair value of the identifiable assets acquired and the liabilities assumed. The determination of the fair value of the assets and liabilities is based to a considerable extent on management’s judgement. The amount of goodwill initially recognized as a result of a business combination is dependent on the allocation of this purchase price to the identifiable assets and liabilities with any unallocated portion being recorded as goodwill.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group has both defined benefit and defined contribution arrangements. The cost of providing benefits under the defined benefit scheme is determined using the projected unit method. The key assumptions used in relation to the cost of providing post-retirement benefits are set after consultation with qualified actuaries. While these assumptions are considered to be appropriate, a change in these assumptions would impact the earnings of the Group.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group applies the IFRS 9 simplified approach to calculate ECLs for trade receivables and uses a provision matrix. The matrix approach allows application of different rates to different groups of customers with similar characteristics. The provision matrix is initially based on the Group’s historical observed default rates. The Group then calibrate the matrix to adjust the historical credit loss experience with forward-looking information. At every reporting date, the historical observed default rates are updated and changes in the forwardlooking estimates are analyzed. The Group has adjusted the ECL matrix for the forecast impact of the current economic environment including the impact of higher sustained energy costs, higher inflation and interest rate increases on the Group customers (both businesses and residential). -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The SEM market trading arrangements, which comprise a Day Ahead Market, Intra-Day Market and Balancing Market, experienced volatility since the market commenced on October 1, 2018. The market has become more stable, with a number of fixes applied by the Market Operator; however, the Group’s energy purchase and supply businesses remain exposed to some energy price resettlement risks. As at March 31, 2023 the Market Operator has resettled these markets up to December 3, 2022 for M+4 resettlement and March 5, 2022 for M+13 resettlement in line with the expected market resettlement timetable of 4 months and 13 months after initial settlement. The market has had two main system fixes released over the last year; however, further market fixes are required to be implemented before the market settlement solution can be considered fully aligned to the market code requirements, with a number of additional resettlements to occur ranging across the full 54-month period since the market commenced. The Group therefore continues to be exposed to potential price resettlements in the balancing market and estimates the level of resettlement that may be applied. These estimates are based on known market anomalies as discussed in industry forums and facts and circumstances known at the Balance Sheet date. Estimations are dependent on the resettlement approach taken by the market operator. There is therefore a significant degree of judgement required in order to estimate the level of resettlement that will be applied. During Fiscal Year 2023, an estimated average of approximately 1.6% from October 2018 (During Fiscal Year 2022: estimated average of approximately 3.5% for all periods from October 2018) of balancing market revenues is considered a reasonable estimate and is supported by actual resettlements seen in the market to date, and reflect the various fixes applied by the market operator during the past 12 months. A quantitative sensitivity analysis in relation to these key assumptions shows that, for every 1% increase or decrease in the percentage used in the resettlement provisions for balancing market exposures would be an increase or decrease to operating profit respectively of €3.8 million. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS. In connection with the preparation of the Financial Statements, the directors are required to make assumptions and estimates about future events and apply judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses and the related disclosures. The Group bases its assumptions, estimates and judgments on historical experience, trends and other factors that the Group believes to be relevant at the time its financial statements are prepared. On a regular basis, management reviews the accounting policies, assumptions, estimates and judgments to ensure that the Financial Statements are presented fairly and in accordance with IFRS. However, because future events and their effects cannot be determined with certainty, actual results could differ from its assumptions and estimates, and such differences could be material. The Group believes that the following accounting policies and estimates are the most critical to aid in fully understanding and evaluating its reported financial results, and they require management’s most difficult, subjective, or complex judgments, resulting from the need to make estimates about the effects of matters that are inherently uncertain. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations is based upon, and should be read in conjunction with, the Financial Statements, and the related notes thereto included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Except as the context otherwise indicates, when discussing historical results of operations in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “Group” and “Energia Group,” are generally used to refer to the business of the Company and its subsidiaries. The following discussion also contains forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to such differences include, but are not limited to, those discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, particularly under “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.”_

Subsection Title: History of the Irish Electricity Market
Subsubsection Text: The RoI market commenced liberalization in 1999 following the passage of the Electricity Regulation Act (the “1999 Act”), which created a framework for the liberalization of electricity generation and supply in the RoI and established the CRU as the independent industry regulator. Further regulations that came into effect in 2000 established EirGrid, a statutory company owned by the RoI government) as the RoI’s independent transmission system operator (the “TSO”). EirGrid operates the RoI’s electricity transmission system under a regulated agreement with the incumbent utility ESB (a corporate body owned by the RoI government), which retains ownership of the onshore transmission and distribution network assets. ESB retains responsibility for operation of the distribution system. Prior to liberalization, ESB had a monopoly position at all levels of the electricity supply chain and supplied customers through bundled tariffs set by the RoI Government. Although ESB was reorganized after liberalization of the RoI electricity market, it retains a significant market share in both generation (through ESB Power Generation) and retail supply (through Electric Ireland). Since liberalization, a number of companies have entered the RoI electricity market and established strong market positions, some of which include: - Energia Group, which developed the Huntstown plants, and Energia as its competitive retail supply business. - Scottish and Southern Energy, now known as SSE plc (“SSE”), a public company that entered the RoI market in 2008 by acquiring Airtricity, operates both a renewable generation and retail supply business. SSE also acquired generating units with a capacity of approximately 1,000MW from Endesa in 2012 (which Endesa had previously purchased from ESB in 2008) and subsequently built a 464MW CCGT plant in 2015. - Bord Gáis Energy Limited (“BGE”) a former subsidiary of the State-owned Bord Gáis Eireann (now known as Ervia) acquired by Centrica in 2014 and which owns the 445MW Whitegate CCGT plant and the electricity and natural gas retailing businesses (including the brand) of Bord Gáis Eireann. - Orsted, which in 2021 acquired Brookfield’s onshore renewable energy business in Ireland (which Brookfield had acquired from Bord Gáis Eireann in 2014) and in 2023 entered into a joint venture with ESB for the development of offshore wind in Ireland. - EirGrid, which commissioned the 500MW HVDC EWIC (running between the RoI and North Wales) in 2013 and is currently developing the 700MW Celtic Interconnector (running between RoI and France). The retail RoI electricity market has been fully deregulated since April 2011, when ESB’s retail market share fell below the regulated threshold of 60% for residential customers and 50% for business customers. All residential and business customers in the RoI are therefore able to choose their electricity supplier.

Subsection Title: History of the Irish Electricity Market
Subsubsection Text: The NI market commenced its transition to a liberalized, unbundled structure earlier than the RoI, when the incumbent utility, NI Electricity Service, was privatized in 1992. During the first phase of privatization, the UK Government sold the four then-existing thermal generating plants, with combined capacity of approximately 2GW, under long-term PPAs and established NIEN to perform all non-generation functions, including acting as the contractual counterparty to the PPAs, thereby constituting the single buyer of electricity in the NI market. ----- In the second phase of privatization, in 1993, NIEN, comprising transmission and distribution, power procurement and supply, was listed on the London Stock Exchange. At this time, entry into the retail market was deregulated. However, new entrants were required to purchase power from NIE under a bulk supply tariff, which had the effect of restricting competition. NIEN was restructured in 1998 into separate regulated and unregulated businesses, under the holding company Viridian Group PLC (the Viridian Group). The Viridian Group was acquired by Arcapita in 2006. The System Operator for NI (“SONI”) was sold to EirGrid in 2009 and the transmission and distribution business was sold to ESB NI in 2010. In 2016 Arcapita sold the Viridian Group to I Squared Capital Funds and the Viridian Group was renamed as the Energia Group in 2019. The Moyle Interconnector, a 500MW interconnector between Scotland and NI commissioned in 2002, is owned by Moyle Interconnector Limited, a subsidiary of Mutual Energy Limited (a NI mutual company formed to acquire and hold energy infrastructure assets in NI). The Moyle Interconnector is operated under contract by SONI. Other than the 600MW Ballylumford CCGT plant and the 400MW Coolkeeragh CCGT plant, the only other generation commissioned in NI since liberalization began in the 1990s has been renewable generation and 84MW of distillate-fired generation at Kilroot that is generally only operated to meet peak demand when there is low wind output. Existing coal/oil fired generation at Kilroot is expected to close in the near term (2023), to be replaced by new gas fired generation. All customers in the NI market are able to choose an electricity supplier. Although the retail market is fully open to competition, Power NI, the regulated incumbent residential electricity supplier, continues to be the largest supplier (by number of supply points) to the residential and small business segments. A number of new suppliers have entered the market over the past 22 years.

Subsection Title: History of the Irish Electricity Market
Subsubsection Title: Creation of the Single Electricity Market (SEM)
Subsubsection Text: In November 2007, the electricity market regulators in the RoI and NI, the CRU and the UR, respectively, replaced their individual wholesale market arrangements with an all-island market known as the Single Electricity Market, or SEM. At the heart of the SEM was a mandatory “gross pool” that provided a transparent wholesale electricity price and a guaranteed outlet for all electricity production on the island of Ireland, together with an explicit capacity payment mechanism. The SEM wholesale market was adopted by the CRU and UR following a long period of development in order to provide advantages over the pre-existing bilateral contracts markets in the areas of security of supply, efficiency, practicality, equity and competition, while maintaining stability. In February 2014, the relevant authorities launched a process to further evolve the unified Irish electricity market in order to maximize the efficient use of interconnectors and ensure compliance with the EU Target Model. Following numerous industry consultations, revised market arrangements (as described in more detail below) were put in place from October 1, 2018.

The energy trading arrangements in the SEM comprise of a number of energy markets that allow trading of electricity: a financial forwards market, a Day-Ahead Market (DAM), a number of Intraday Markets (IDM) (collectively the “ex-ante Energy Markets”) and a Balancing Market for trading out differences between ex-ante positions and actual physical positions in real time. The SEM and its component energy markets have been physically disconnected from the EU since Brexit, as reflected in the description below. However, the Celtic Interconnector, a planned 700MW DC interconnector linking the SEM to France with a target commissioning date of Q4 2026, will physically reintegrate the SEM with the EU energy markets and this is expected to bring about revisions to the current SEM structure to facilitate new cross-border trading opportunities. ----- _Financial Forwards Market_ The financial forwards market provides market participants with opportunities to hedge against energy price fluctuations months to years in advance of energy delivery. It allows participants to trade “CfDs,” which are hedging instruments in which a price is struck (the “strike price”) for a quantity of energy delivered on a future day. The contract holder then receives or pays the difference between the strike price and the spot price on the delivery date (called the “reference price”), depending on which side of the trade was taken by that holder. For example, a generator might agree a CfD with a supplier, under which the generator would pay the supplier the difference if the reference price was in excess of the strike price on the delivery date, while the supplier would pay the generator the difference if the reference price was lower than the strike price. This allows generators and suppliers effectively to lock-in pricing for fixed quantities of electricity on specific future days, as a hedge against price spikes or dips in the spot market. Products traditionally available in advance of the DAM include CfDs between market participants or in the form of a Directed Contract (DC), whose price and volume is set by the SEM Committee. Settlement under these CfDs is generally also capped such that the spot price is effectively capped at the RO strike price (if the spot price was to be higher than the RO strike price then suppliers will be compensated under the RO mechanism). _The Day Ahead Market (DAM)_ The DAM is a daily auction to allow day-ahead trading within the SEM (it is no longer coupled with Great Britain) and is the largest ex-ante Energy Market by volume and value. The DAM auction takes place at 11 a.m. Irish time for the 24-hour trading day starting the same evening at 11:00 p.m. Irish time. Participation for generation is largely on a unit-basis with aggregation for demand. The use of different bid formats is permitted to allow thermal generators to reflect technical characteristics such as start-up costs. An algorithm determines the market price and position for all participants on an hourly basis. Participation in the DAM is not mandatory, but it is the only way of achieving a day-ahead position in the SEM that will minimize market participants’ exposure in the balancing market. Participants have opportunities to adjust their position by trading in the intraday markets. _The Intraday Markets (IDM)_ Following the DAM, the IDM allows participants to adjust their physical positions closer to the time power is delivered. The IDM consists of three daily auctions (two of which are coupled with Great Britain via the interconnectors) and a separate continuous (SEM only) market. _The Balancing Market (BM)_ The Balancing Market reflects actions taken by the TSOs to keep the system balanced and secure. Unlike the other ex-ante Energy Markets, participation in the Balancing Market is mandatory. Before and into real time, the TSO calls on system services to keep the transmission system balanced (i.e., energy supply = energy demand), carry reserve and manage energy flows on the transmission system. System services, including Energy balancing services, are offered into the Balancing Market (BM) by generators (energy producers) and suppliers (energy consumers). For example, if demand is higher than expected, the TSO might instruct a generator with available capacity to increase its output. The generator is then paid through the BM for the additional energy used to balance the grid. The Balancing Market determines the imbalance settlement price for settlement of these balancing actions. This includes any uninstructed deviations from a participant’s notified ex-ante position. A market participant’s net energy position is the accumulated volume of all its trades on the ex-ante Energy Markets (DAM and IDM) and any balancing actions taken by the TSO in the Balancing Market. Typically in the ex-ante Energy Markets, generators will establish traded positions to maximize profitability and suppliers will establish traded positions to match their expected physical position and reduce their exposure to the imbalance price determined in the Balancing Market. _Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (CRM)_ The CRM allows generators to recover a proportion of their fixed costs. It also helps to ensure there is enough capacity to meet demand and that this capacity is purchased competitively through auctions. Capacity providers can sell pre-qualified capacity to the market in the form of Reliability Options, which rewards those who contribute to the reliability of the power system when needed. A Reliability Option is a one-way contract for difference, entered into between a generator and a central agency, that incentivizes a generator to generate electricity at times of market spikes in exchange for a fixed payment, while foregoing incremental revenue when the market price is above the strike price. Auctions are normally held by the TSOs between one and four years ahead of delivery. ----- Generation plants that are “in-merit” in the CRM auction (that is, plants offering a price low enough to be selected to meet the capacity requirement) will be paid based upon the market clearing price set by the highest accepted bidder. However, as the Irish electricity network has limitations and operational constraints, generation plants can therefore be required for system stability in certain ‘locationally constrained’ zones irrespective of their Merit Order position in the CRM auction. These plants typically play a system-critical role in balancing the energy network and ensuring security of supply and will therefore be paid “as bid” within the auction framework. The Group’s Huntstown plants are located in localized constraints in the Dublin area and are therefore frequently dispatched to alleviate system constraints. Existing generation plants are required to be bid into the CRM auction, unless a plant is due to close before the capacity period being auctioned, has an extended outage, or is due to be mothballed. Bids into the CRM auction are subject to regulatory caps. The general Existing Capacity Price Cap (“ECPC”) is one half of the net Cost of New Entrant (“CONE”), which is determined using a best new entrant calculation carried out by the SEMC. This calculation makes reference to the cost of developing a new OCGT power plant. A generator can also apply for a Unit Specific Price Cap (“USPC”) if the plant can justify to SEMC that its net going forward costs are higher than the ECPC. New entrants will be able to bid up to 1.5 times net CONE and secure a contract for up to 10 years. Subject to market conditions, a new entrant plant can set the clearing price of the CRM auction for the first year of its contract resulting in all generators participating in that auction receiving the new entrant price for that year. The value for net CONE is reviewed periodically by the SEMC. The value of net CONE for previous auctions and the next scheduled auction is shown in the table below.

There are three distinct areas that provide revenue streams relating to the services provided by market participants. The Energy Trading Arrangements (ETA), Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (CRM), and ancillary services procured under the DS3 program (Delivering a Secure Sustainable Electricity System).

Separate settlement and credit cover arrangements apply in each market and under the rules of each market operator. The _ex-ante physical markets (DAM and IDM) are settled daily. Each participant appoints a clearing member—a bank that is a member of the European Commodity Clearing (“ECC”) house—who settles with the market operator on behalf of the participant. The ECC has also introduced a direct clearing market participant model to allow small and medium size enterprises to access certain spot markets without the need to appoint a bank. The ECC acts as a central counterparty for all payments in the market and guarantees payments in the event of a default by a participant. The ECC assesses the collateral requirements of each clearing member and ensures it holds adequate security to protect against default. Each clearing member then imposes similar obligations on the participant. Under SEM, the Group expects that collateral requirements in these markets will often be fulfilled using cash collateral or letters of credit. The Balancing Market is settled weekly. Settlement documents reflect balancing and capacity transactions in that billing period. Credit management is in the form of credit cover provided by a qualified bank. The market operator draws on the participant’s credit cover to cover any defaults and monitors the exposure of every participant. Settlement in the BM takes into account instructed and uninstructed imbalances. The payments and charges that arise from balancing depend on the nature of the imbalance, the commercial data submitted, the status of the generating unit, the available metering data, and other data. Settlement and credit risk management for the FM and FTR auctions are outside the SEM arrangements. Capacity providers receive a monthly capacity payment based on the capacity provider’s awarded capacity and the price paid. Payment is made regardless of whether the capacity provider is scheduled to physically deliver energy. Settlement can also include difference charges if the reference price exceeds the strike price. In such an event, capacity providers also pay a capacity difference charge for any undelivered capacity. Difference charges are settled weekly to align with the billing period for energy payments and charges.

The provision of system services to the TSOs by flexible, responsive gas fired plants has become essential as wind penetration has increased in the Irish energy market, fostered by governmental policies aimed at having renewable sources supply up to 80% renewable electricity (RES-E) by 2030. Wind is an intermittent and nonsynchronous technology; moreover, power demand in Ireland varies on daily and seasonal cycles, and often not in tandem with changes in the supply of wind power. To address system security arising from even greater wind penetration, the TSOs established a multi-year program called “Delivering a Secure, Sustainable Electricity System” (“DS3”). As part of the DS3 program, new system services under regulated tariff arrangements were introduced in 2016, funded by an annual budget which has increased from €75 million to €235 million. This has been important in enabling increased levels of non-synchronous renewable energy on the system, increasing the maximum System Non-Synchronous Penetration (“SNSP”) level from 50% to 75% while maintaining system stability. The Group’s Huntstown plants have played an important role in this regard providing ancillary services required under DS3, and additionally benefiting from DS3 Locational Scarcity Scalars for certain services provided in the Dublin area which is funded by a further €12.5 million per annum (over and above the €235 million budget) The DS3 Locational Scarcity Scalars for the Dublin area are in place until October 1, 2024, after which time it is unclear if they will be continued. Further development of system services is needed to deliver SNSP levels of 95%+ required to achieve 2030 RES-E targets. This combined with EU requirements under the Clean Energy Package (CEP) and the Electricity Balancing Guideline (EBGL) Network Code has led to the launch of a System Services Future Arrangements (SSFA) project in July 2020. The High Level Design (HLD) for the SSFA was published by the SEMC on April 14, 2022. The HLD puts in place a framework for the competitive procurement of system services comprising daily auctions and longer-term contracts and it is envisaged that a transitional period will be required. The detailed design for the SSFA has yet to commence, which will include numerous industry consultations. It has been recently proposed by the SEM Committee that the regulated tariff arrangements will be extended by 24 months until 30 April 2026 (with a phased reduction of tariff rates) to allow sufficient time for the competitive arrangements to be implemented. -----
Demand for energy in Ireland, including electricity, has historically been highly correlated to GDP and the wider macroeconomic climate.

Subsection Title: All-Island Historical and Forecast Electricity Demand, 2018 to 2031
Subsubsection Text: Source: Ireland Capacity Outlook 2022-2031. TER denotes Total Electricity Requirement It is notable that total electricity demand during the COVID-19 pandemic remained relatively stable and has since increased. The Ireland Capacity Outlook 2022-2031, published by EirGrid and SONI in October 2022 (more commonly known as the All-Island Generation Capacity Statement, or GCS – hereafter referred to as “the latest GCS”) includes the demand projections shown above providing three credible scenarios: low, medium and high demand. These forecasts are used to derive the capacity requirement of upcoming capacity auctions and give an appropriate view of the range of possible demand growths facing Ireland. In the median scenario, which represents EirGrid’s best estimate, energy demand is forecasted to increase 37% by 2031, from 2021 levels. The largest growth comes from data centers and new tech load, and increased uptake of EVs and heat pumps, particularly later in the decade. Also notable is that by 2031, 28% of all electricity demand is expected to come from data centers and new tech loads and this growth is from contracted projects only, with almost all data center and new large energy user demand growth in the Dublin region.

Subsection Title: Data Center and new Large Energy User Demand Forecasts, additional to 600MVA assumed for 2022 Generation
Subsubsection Text: The following chart shows the total generation capacity mix in 2022 -----

Subsection Title: Total All-Island Generation Capacity Mix (%) in 2022
Subsubsection Text: The RoI’s installed generation capacity is largely a mix of natural gas, wind, coal and oil plants, notably there is a continually increasing contribution from wind generation and other renewables such as solar. There is currently a statutory ban on nuclear development in RoI. Due to the Clean Energy Package (CEP) legislation and CO2 emission limits for capacity payment eligibility, along with increasing restrictions due to Industrial Emissions Directive (IED) legislation, the latest GCS shows that thermal generation using coal and oil as their primary fuel will decommission by 2025 (including 855MW coal fired generation at Moneypoint and 590MW oil ----- fired generation at Tarbert). This capacity, and the capacity from other plant expected to retire out to 2030, is expected to be replaced by new gas-fired generation, battery energy storage, interconnection, and demand side units. However, a large proportion of new generation (730MW) awarded capacity contracts in previous auctions, that was expected to come online in 2022 / 2023, has been withdrawn by the developers. This combined with a prolonged outage of SSE’s oil-fired generation units (590MW) at Tarbert and expected demand growth, has given rise to a negative security of supply outlook in Ireland for the remainder of this decade. Mitigating measures include temporary emergency generation and potentially delaying the closure of existing units. The CRU confirmed in February 2023 (in CRU Information Note CRU202317) that EirGrid’s public procurement exercise for a first tranche of temporary emergency generation has resulted in contracts being signed for 200MW at Northwall (ESB) and 50MW at the Huntstown campus (provided by Energia Group). Procurement for a second tranche of up to 450MW of temporary emergency generation has also resulted in the initial equipment contracts being signed for 258MW of capacity in Shannonbridge (ESB) and 150MW in Tarbert (SSE Generation Ireland Limited). The CRU also communicated that EirGrid continues to engage with a number of operators about extending the operational life of existing units. In NI, installed generation capacity is largely a mix of coal, natural gas and oil plants, with a gradually expanding contribution from wind generation and other renewables. Similarly, to the RoI, existing coal/oil fired generation in NI (476MW at Kilroot) is expected to close in the near term (2023), to be replaced by new gas fired generation. The security of supply outlook for NI is also negative, in this case because the replacement gas fired generation (two new OCGTs at Kilroot) is expected to be subject to annual run hour limits (ARHL) as a result of IED emissions limits. There is an additional steam turbine intended to become operational at the Kilroot site in 2026, this unit is expected to remove any ARHL as the plant will have the ability to operate as a combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT), at which point the security of supply outlook becomes positive. Interconnectors supplying electricity from Great Britain compete against generators in RoI and NI. Ireland currently has limited interconnection capacity to Great Britain through its two HVDC interconnectors: (i) the Moyle Interconnector which interconnects NI to Scotland has an import capacity of 450MW and an export capacity of 270MW; (ii) the EWIC between Wales and the RoI and has a capacity of 500MW in either direction. Two further HVDC interconnectors are currently under construction: (1) the Greenlink Interconnector (500MW) between Ireland and Wales (potentially commissioning in 2024); and (2) the Celtic Interconnector (700MW) between Ireland and France (potentially commissioning in 2026). There are also a number of further interconnector projects at early stages of development.

Subsection Title: Total All-Island Generation Capacity Mix (%) in 2022
Subsubsection Text: All EU member states have requirements under the Fit for 55 to reduce net greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030, compared to 1990 levels. In Ireland, the primary means by which this decarbonization target will be achieved is via increasing the amount of electricity generated from renewable energy sources. The Irish Government, via the Climate Action Plan has therefore committed to reducing electricity sector emissions by at least 75% by 2030. The Climate Action plan therefore targets having 9GW of onshore wind, 8GW solar and at least 5GW of offshore wind installed by 2030. Ireland has a strong track record of growth in renewables, as shown in the table below. -----

Subsection Title: Electricity generated in Ireland by fuel type
Subsubsection Text: _RoI_ In the RoI, support for renewable energy is currently provided by the RESS and offshore RESS (ORESS) scheme, having previously been provided by the REFIT scheme. Both RESS and ORESS allocate support in the form of a two-way CfD via a competitive pay as bid auction. The Climate Action Plan 2023 commits the RoI to having 9GW of onshore wind, 8GW solar and at least 5GW of Offshore wind installed by 2030, with the expectation being that RESS and ORESS will provide the route to market for the majority of this capacity. The First RESS auction took place in 2020, procuring over 1.2MW of onshore wind and solar at an average weighted strike price of €74.08/MWh. RESS2 took place in 2022 and awarded support to just under 2GW of capacity at an average weighted price of €97.87/MWh again predominantly onshore wind and solar. RESS 3 is scheduled to take place in 2023, targeting the procurement of almost double the capacity in RESS 2. RESS 4 is scheduled to take place in 2024 and will seek to procure a similar quantity of capacity to RESS 3. The first offshore RESS auction (ORESS1) took place in May 2023, procuring over 3GW at an average strike price of €86.05/MWh for a 20 year term. Latest Government policy indicates that a second offshore RESS auction for 900MW (ORESS2.1) off the South coast process could begin by the end of 2023 with an auction expected in the first half of 2024. ORESS2 is expected to run up to two further auctions, so that ORESS1 & ORESS2 will procure the 5GW of capacity required to achieve the CAP target. European State aid clearance for the RESS and ORESS Scheme expires in 2025, although it may be possible to extend it beyond 2025. The precursor to RESS was the REFIT scheme implemented in 2006. The scheme was designed to encourage licensed electricity suppliers to enter into PPAs for up to 15 years with renewable generators, under which the suppliers would contractually agree the off-take price to be paid to the generators. Electricity suppliers were then compensated for the additional cost of purchasing electricity from renewable sources. Under REFIT, suppliers are compensated if the SEM market price, including constraint payments achieved for electricity generated and capacity payments earned by a particular renewable generating unit in a twelve month period, is below a base reference price. The reference price is indexed annually (upwards only) at the RoI Consumer Price ----- Index, and in 2023 is set at a floor of €75.856/MWh for large scale wind generation and €81.105/MWh for smaller scale wind generators together with an unindexed (in the case of REFIT 2 and REFIT 3) supplier balancing payment of €9.90/MWh in each case. Suppliers claim any shortfall between the market and the floor prices in an annual period from a PSO Levy pool administered by the CRU. Suppliers are also compensated for the cost of balancing renewable generation via a balancing payment equating to 15% of the floor price for large scale wind generation per MWh generated in REFIT 1 and up to €9.90/MWh (not indexed) for REFIT 2 and 3 depending on the extent to which market revenues exceed the reference price. All REFIT Schemes are now closed to new applicants. REFIT support therefore ensures that a minimum price is paid to electricity suppliers for electricity sourced from renewable generators while allowing the supplier to retain any price upside should the price captured by the supplier in the market exceed the floor price. The market reference price (upon which payments to and from the supplier are calculated) was altered in SEM to the lower of either 100% of the DAM price or an 80:20 split between the DAM price and Balancing Market price (for renewable units exceeding 5MW). Note that for units less than 5MW of installed capacity, the benchmark price will instead be calculated as the lower of either 100% of the DAM price or a 70:30 split between the DAM price and Balancing Market price. This configuration was brought in to provide a level of flexibility to entities trading wind power in the market and reflects the fact that wind units are now balance responsible in SEM and maybe reluctant to overcommit volumes in the DAM. The REFIT floor price mechanism is of particular value in markets with volatile fuel and electricity prices, as has been particularly the case over the past two years. The mechanism allows renewable energy to earn full market upside when fuel prices are high and provides the floor price when they fall. Typically, the contract price paid to the generator would include some, but not all of the balancing payment plus the applicable level of REFIT support, effectively splitting the balancing payment subsidy between the generator and the supplier. Market upside is also typically split. As with the REFIT scheme, RESS was designed once again to encourage suppliers to enter into PPAs for approximately 15 years with renewable generators. Suppliers agree to an off-take price with the RESS generator, orientated around the strike price the generator has been awarded in a RESS. RESS support is awarded on the basis of a pay as bid auction and thus varies by generator. RESS support was not inflation indexed for RESS 1 and 2 however the proposed terms and conditions for the 2023 RESS 3 auction suggested the DECC might introduce at least partial indexation. ORESS support operates in broadly the same manner as RESS support but is partially inflation indexed and is for a 20 year term. The nature of the support paid to suppliers on behalf of their PPA contracted RESS generation is a two-way CfD orientated around the individual generator’s strike price. Suppliers will therefore be required to make payments back to the PSO pot if wholesale market prices exceed the project’s strike price. As before if wholesale prices are less than the strike price, suppliers will be topped up to the project’s strike price. Unlike REFIT however, the wholesale benchmark price (upon which payments to and from the supplier are calculated) for renewable RESS is entirely the DAM price. For ‘variable’ generators (such as wind farms) the reference price is the hourly DAM price, for non-variable generators the reference price is the time weighted average of the DAM price over the PSO year. Crucially however for RESS no support is paid if the market reference price (the DAM price) is less than zero. _NI_ Presently there is no support scheme available to new renewable generators in NI. The DfE is consulting on introducing a support scheme presently, with the expectation being that support could be provided in the form of a two-way CfD scheme along similar lines to RESS in Ireland and the CfD scheme in Great Britain. The previous scheme the NIRO, closed to new large scale onshore wind on March 31, 2016, to new small scale onshore wind on June 30, 2016 and to all other technologies on March 31, 2017, with exceptions to those projects that met the criteria for grace periods. The NIRO was the major route to market for renewables in NI and was largely responsible for NI’s achievement of its 2020 Renewable target to source 40% of NI’s electricity from renewable sources. Under the NIRO regime, eligible renewable generators receive ROCs for each MWh of electricity generated. ROCs are freely tradable at auction and can be sold to suppliers in order to fulfil their obligations under the NIRO regime. Suppliers have the option of presenting ROCs to cover their obligations or paying a buyout fee of £59.01 /MWh (for the 2023-2024 financial year) for any shortfall. All proceeds from buyout fees are repaid to the holders of ROCs. The Renewables Obligation Order (Northern Ireland) 2009, as amended, introduced a banding system for generators, which presented a different number of ROCs per MWh depending on the renewable technology. ----- The bands affect only those projects that were developed after the reforms came into force in 2009, with all accredited projects and generation capacity in existence prior to 2009 grandfathered from the prior ROC scheme. Prior to 2009, there had been a single level of support for all renewable technologies of one ROC per MWh. DETI regularly reviewed the banding system to ensure that the level of support offered was in line with generation costs and continued to incentivize renewables development. For onshore wind farms commissioned in NI after April 1, 2013, the ROC value was reduced to 0.9 ROCs per MWh. This reduction does not apply to onshore wind farms that were operational at that date or became operational within a proposed grace period of six months or those wind farms with a capacity of less than 5MW. In June 2013, DETI confirmed that it did not intend to further review the banding support levels for large scale onshore wind under the RO regime. DETI decided to close the NIRO to large scale onshore wind projects one year early from March 31, 2016. The NIRO Closure Order closed the NIRO to all new large (>5MW) onshore wind capacity from April 1, 2016 and also introduced extensions of time, known as “grace periods” for certain qualifying projects. The new deadlines granted under the grace periods varied depending on the eligibility criteria and ranged from March 31, 2017 to December 31, 2017 and where the qualifying conditions, and all other NIRO eligibility criteria, were satisfied, they could be combined to give extensions of time up to December 31, 2018 at the latest. The NIRO Closure Order permitted large scale onshore wind projects to seek to accredit for the NIRO after April 1, 2016 and up to March 31, 2017 if the onshore wind project met the ‘approved development’ grace period eligibility requirements of planning consent, accepted grid connection offer, and land rights all dated no later than September 30, 2015 in the case of direct connection sites, and October 30, 2015 in the case of cluster connection sites. In addition, where applicable, onshore wind projects could access the ‘radar and grid delay’ grace period up to March 31, 2018 and projects eligible for the “investment freezing” grace period and grid/ radar delay grace period were able to accredit up until December 31, 2018. From 2027, it is proposed that fixed-price certificates will be issued, in place of ROCs, to projects qualifying for RO support until the end of the RO regime in 2037. It is currently proposed that fixed-price certificates will be set at the 2027 buyout price, plus 10% and will be inflation-linked. In August 2015, DETI confirmed that the fixed-price certificate scheme will be introduced for the NIRO in 2027, however, a consultation on the detailed design of the fixed- price certificate scheme and the associated legislation has not yet been issued. For projects receiving ROCs, the benefit of the scheme will extend until 2037 to ensure that generation accredited through 2017 receives the full 20 years of support under the NIRO.

Subsection Title: Electricity generated in Ireland by fuel type
Subsubsection Text: The TSOs have a responsibility to ensure that the electricity system is managed prudently which requires generation to be constrained at certain locations. To ensure efficient and secure operation of the electricity system, generation is constrained to certain levels to prevent overloading, voltages outside prescribed limits or system instability. To schedule and dispatch the system, EirGrid uses specialized software known as the Security Constrained Unit Commitment (“SCUC”) and Security Constrained Economic Dispatch (“SCED”) optimization programs. EirGrid provides weekly updates of the key system and generator constraints which are taken into account in the scheduling process. This results in certain thermal plants frequently being dispatched irrespective of their Merit Order position in order to ensure security of supply and system stability. -----

Subsection Title: Electricity generated in Ireland by fuel type
Subsubsection Text: The UK government legislated to have a net zero emissions target by 2050 in 2019. The Climate Change Act (Northern Ireland) 2022, committed NI to the same net zero target by 2050, along with interim targets including at least 48% reduction in net emissions by 2030 and 80% of electricity consumption emanating from renewable sources. Aside from the requirement to meet these targets, the RoI and NI governments are also driven by key economic considerations to increase wind penetration. Ireland has no significant indigenous fossil fuel resources and, as a result, imports its primary fuel sources from the UK and other jurisdictions. Ireland remains one of the most critically dependent EU nations on imported fuel, with 80% of fuel demand imported. Increased generation from renewable sources reduces this reliance on imported fuels. In addition, Ireland is a particularly attractive location for wind energy, given high wind factors relative to other EU countries, requiring a lower governmental cost support mechanism than that required in other jurisdictions and lower costs, in turn, for consumers.

Subsection Title: Key system constraints considered in the scheduling process
Subsubsection Text: Under SEM, the profitability of generators when generating is primarily dependent on demand, the plant’s availability and position in the Merit Order, which ranks available sources of power in ascending order of their short-run marginal cost of production (i.e., the least expensive sources of power are first in the Merit Order). The following table is indicative of the Merit Order between April 2022 and September 2022. _Source: Single Electricity Market Operator data_ ----- The combination of low coal and carbon prices in recent years has resulted in certain coal plants frequently ranking ahead of most CCGT generators (including Huntstown 1 and Huntstown 2 plants) in the Merit Order. More recently, gas prices have fallen, and coal prices have risen, frequently placing gas plants ahead of coal plants in the Merit Order. Moreover, gas plants which include gas capacity costs in their SEM bids will generally see lower capacity costs in the summer months, when heating demand is lower, improving their competitive position at that time of the year. In the SEM, payments to generators for production are primarily dependent on positions contracted over the ex-ante Energy Markets, rather than on a simple application of the Merit Order by TSO, followed by ex post settlement, which is currently the practice in the SEM. Nevertheless, the Merit Order concept remains significant for determining TSO’s actions in the real-time balancing market. Under SEM, the Merit Order for actions dispatched by TSO in the balancing market will be determined by reference to the price each generation or contracted demand unit would accept to increase or decrease its output or consumption by certain increments, above or below the level such unit contracted at in the ex-ante Energy Markets. Moreover, as the ex-ante Energy Markets divide each generation day into hour or half-hour increments, bids for balancing actions can also vary across the same timescales, leading to hour-by-hour changes in the Merit Order.

Subsection Title: Key system constraints considered in the scheduling process
Subsubsection Text: In the second half of 2021, the UK and EU experienced a significant increase in wholesale energy prices (notably gas and consequently electricity) caused by the surge in global energy demand, as most countries emerged from the COVID-19 pandemic. This situation was significantly exacerbated by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine on February 24, 2022 and has led to a series of government and EU interventions designed to capture windfall profits or the surplus revenues of infra-marginal generators for redistribution to consumers. The most relevant of these interventions to the RoI and NI are described below. _RoI_ On September 14, 2022, the European Commission proposed a new Regulation on an emergency intervention to address high energy prices to reduce end user energy bills. It included a temporary revenue cap on non-gas infra-marginal electricity generators and proposed to set the cap at €180/MWh. Regulation 2022/1854 was adopted on October 6, 2022 and contains, among other things, the following provisions: - A temporary market revenue cap of €180/MWh applicable to electricity generated from wind, solar, nuclear, lignite, biomass, waste, oil or peat that applies from 1 December 2022 until June 30, 2023. - Member States are required to ensure that the cap also applies to intermediaries but includes an exemption where it can be demonstrated that surplus revenues are being passed to end consumers. - Member States may set different limits on revenues to differentiate between technologies, apply further limits on electricity traders, or apply higher limits to producers with investments and operating costs greater than €180/MWh. - Member States must ensure that all surplus revenues resulting from the cap are used to finance targeted support for final electricity customers to mitigate the impact of high electricity prices. The Irish Government has decided to implement the cap at a lower price of €120/MWh for both wind and solar generators. In line with the EU guidance the cap has been in place since December 1, 2022 and is expected to expire by June 30, 2023. Legislation in Ireland for implementation of the temporary market revenue cap under the Regulation has yet to be passed. _NI_ On November 17, 2022, the UK government announced that it would be imposing a new temporary Electricity Generator Levy (EGL) of 45% on the extraordinary revenues of low carbon electricity generators. The fundamentals of the EGL are as follows: - It is a tax of 45% on exceptional receipts that groups realize from electricity generation in the UK from renewables, waste and nuclear. ----- - Exceptional receipts are aggregate receipts in a period to the extent in excess of a benchmark price. The EGL is therefore a tax on revenue, rather than profits, and is charged as if it were corporation tax (once all other liabilities and reliefs have been calculated). - The EGL applies to generation from January 1, 2023 to March 31, 2028. - The benchmark price has been set at £75/MWh, which is subject to CPI indexation from April 2024. - The generation threshold, below which a group will not be subject to the EGL has been set at 50GWh/year and the revenue allowance for a group has been set at £10 million/year.

Subsection Title: Key system constraints considered in the scheduling process
Subsubsection Text: _Source: EirGrid, SONI_ Some of the key system-wide constraints include: - Restrictions to the north-south flow of electricity in both directions across the 275kV transmission line between NI and the RoI; and - Restrictions on the level of non-synchronous generation (primarily wind and interconnector imports) on the system at any given point in time (the System Non-Synchronous Penetration “SNSP”). There are also a number of localized constraints which the TSO applies in order to maintain stability and security of network usage in key load centers and at times of high demand (Source: Weekly Operational Constraints Update). The most important of these are in the Dublin area where the following constraints apply: - Requirement for two of the five large generation units (Huntstown 1 and 2, Dublin Bay and Poolbeg A and B) must be on-load at all times for voltage control; if the East-West Interconnector is not operational then three units must be on load. Typically, this is provided by Huntstown 2 and Dublin Bay in the summer months when system demand is less than 4.0GW; - Requirement for two of four large generation units (Huntstown 1, Dublin Bay and Poolbeg A and B) must be on-load when system demand is greater than 4.0GW for load flow control in the Dublin area. This assumes the East-West Interconnector is available; - Requirement for three of the five large generation units (Huntstown 1 and 2, Dublin Bay and Poolbeg A and B) required for load flow control purposes when system demand is greater than 4.7GW. This assumes the East-West Interconnector is operational. Since December 2014, Huntstown 1 has generally been selected by EirGrid; and - One of Huntstown 1, Huntstown 2 or Dublin Bay is required to be on load at all times for voltage control in the Dublin area. ----- In the context of wind farms, a constraint event occurs when there is insufficient capacity on the network to accept the export of the generator. Access to the transmission network is offered either on a “firm” or “nonfirm” basis depending on whether network reinforcements are required to facilitate the generator’s full export capacity. While a generator which has been granted firm access to the transmission network may experience a reduction in its exported generation at times of high system production, it will receive financial compensation from the TSOs in the form of limited compensation for constrains and, following a recent SEM Committee Decision, curtailment. This decision is currently the subject of a judicial review on the grounds that it is incompatible with EU law and, if successful, the level of compensation available to generators may be significantly increased. A generator with non-firm access may have its exported output reduced without any compensation. Firm access is currently granted once the required investment in the transmission network infrastructure has been completed. Curtailment is a system operation issue and is not linked to the capacity of the network. Curtailment of wind generation occurs where there is excess wind generation available relative to system demand when taking account of system operation restrictions (such as minimum stable generation levels of thermal assets). Curtailment occurs when this excess wind generation cannot be accommodated, and the overall level of renewable generation must be reduced across the system. While the increasing amount of wind generation capacity in Ireland naturally increases the risk of curtailment, the following key developments in the electricity market are expected to provide a countervailing influence: - Provision of a wider range of system services under the evolving DS3 program, provided by a wider range of technologies, is expected to play a key role in operating the power system with SNSP levels up to 95% by 2030 reducing the likelihood of renewable curtailment. - A revised rate of change of frequency limit of 1 Hz/s has been implemented, increasing the resilience of the power system to ride through frequency disturbances caused by significant fluctuations in wind output. - Delivery of enhanced and new integrated control center technologies and tools required to operate the power system securely and efficiently with increasing levels of variable non-synchronous renewables. - Further interconnection and the reintegration of the SEM into EU electricity markets is expected to provide a further outlet for excess wind generation outside of the domestic market.

Subsection Title: Electricity and natural gas supply to final customers
Subsubsection Text: _Electricity supply_ Full liberalization of the RoI retail electricity market was completed in 2005, although the incumbent ESB CS (now Electric Ireland) continued to offer regulated tariffs across all segments until all business markets were deregulated from October 1, 2010, and the residential market was deregulated from April 1, 2011, from which point all suppliers were free to set their own tariffs. The following table provides a breakdown of the electricity supply market in the RoI by market share, based on latest available information:

Subsection Title: Electricity and natural gas supply to final customers
Subsubsection Text: Both NI and the RoI electricity supply markets have been progressively opened to competition and are now fully liberalized. Nonetheless, given Power NI’s residential market share in NI, regulated tariffs still apply to Power NI and its residential customer base. The electricity supply market in Ireland can be split into three segments: LEUs, SMEs and residential customers. LEUs comprise large industrial and commercial users with heavy usage typically connected to the 110kV network or directly to the transmission system. The SME market comprises the service sector and small industrial customers, usually with less than 250 employees. Residential customers represent the largest segment by number of customers making up 92% and 88% (as at December 31, 2021) of the electricity markets in NI and the RoI, respectively. Although business customers represent a much smaller number of customers, they account for approximately 62% and 67% (for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021) of electricity demand in NI and the RoI, respectively. As of December 31, 2022, the NI electricity supply market comprised 827,000 residential customers and 75,000 business customers, while as of December 31, 2021, in the RoI it comprised 2,175,000 residential customers and 289,600 business customers. As of December 31, 2021, the RoI gas supply market comprised 690,000 residential customers and 27,600 business customers.

_Electricity supply_ Although all segments of the NI retail market have been liberalized, the residential market is still subject to regulated tariffs from the incumbent electricity supplier, Power NI, reflected in the price controls that still apply to all residential customers, whereas tariffs for businesses are fully deregulated. The following table provides a breakdown of the electricity supply market in NI by market share: -----

_Source: CRU Energy and Water Monitoring Report for 2021._ (1) Total market size was 12,826GWh for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021. (2) Total market size was 6,975GWh for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021. (3) Total market size was 9,381GWh for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021. Since liberalization, the market share of Electric Ireland across all customer classes has fallen, and it has ceded market share to its three main competitors, Energia Group, SSE Airtricity and BGE. Competition has developed at a different pace across the segments. Electric Ireland continues to lead the residential market, although the market is becoming more competitive with an increase in churn rates being observed, resulting in switching both away from Electric Ireland to independent suppliers and between independent suppliers. Between ----- 2009 and December 2021, Electric Ireland’s residential market share dropped from 99% to 45%, caused by market share gains by SSE Airtricity and BGE. Energia Group entered the RoI residential electricity supply market in January 2014, and as of December 31, 2021 had a 12% market share. Electric Ireland remains the largest supplier of the LEU segment with 46% market share in the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, followed by SSE Airtricity with 21% and Energia Group with a 14% market share. ESB Electric Ireland is also the largest SME supplier with a 35% market share in the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, followed by Energia Group with a 31% market share. These market shares have remained relatively stable over the past number of years. The total residential supply market in the RoI is approximately 2.2 million customers for electricity and 0.7 million customers for natural gas as at December 31, 2021. _Natural gas supply_ The natural gas market in the RoI was fully opened to competition on July 1, 2007 and full price deregulation occurred on July 1, 2014. The RoI imports the majority of its natural gas from Great Britain at prices based on the Great Britain National Balancing Point, plus any costs associated with transmission through the natural gas interconnector. BGE was previously the state-owned incumbent natural gas supplier and retains a dominant position in all customer segments serving 37% of the LEU market, 41% of the SME market and 43% of the residential market in the twelve months ending December 31, 2021. Electric Ireland is the next largest supplier, serving 17% of the LEU market, 8% of the SME market and 20% of the residential market in the twelve months ending December 31, 2021. SSE Airtricity is the third largest supplier, serving 18% of the LEU market, 13% of the SME market and 11% of the residential market in the twelve months ending December 31, 2021 and Energia Group is the fourth largest supplier serving 14% of the LEU market, 13% of the SME market and 11% of the residential market. Other RoI suppliers include Flogas and Prepaypower. These market shares have remained relatively stable over the past number of years. The following table provides a breakdown of the natural gas supply market in the RoI by market share: _Source: CRU Energy and Water Monitoring Report for 2021._ (1) Total market size was 9,751GWh for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021. (2) Total market size was 4,236GWh for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021. (3) Total market size was 7,723GWh for the twelve months ended December 31, 2021.

_Source: UR Retail Energy Market Monitoring report._ (1) Total market size was 4,639GWh for the twelve months ending December 31, 2022. (2) Total market size was 2,855GWh for the twelve months ending December 31, 2022. Since liberalization, the market share of Power NI across all customer classes has fallen, and it has ceded market share to its four main competitors, Budget Energy, SSE Airtricity, Go Power and Electric Ireland. Power NI continues to lead the residential market, although Power NI’s residential market share by consumption, dropped from 100% in 2010 to 55% at December 31, 2022, caused by market share gains by SSE Airtricity, Electric Ireland and Budget Energy. Electric Ireland is the largest supplier in the commercial market with 38% market share by consumption at December 31, 2022 followed by Power NI and SSE Airtricity with 26% and 20% respectively. _Natural gas supply_ The NI natural gas market, which relies solely on imported natural gas, is currently divided into three district areas: the greater Belfast area, where natural gas distribution is conducted by Phoenix Natural gas, the Ten Towns area, which encompasses selected major towns outside Belfast, where Firmus Energy holds the distribution license and the “Gas to the West” area, which encompasses towns in the western portion of the province, where West Transmission Limited (part of the Mutual Energy Group) and SGN Natural Gas Limited have conveyance licenses. _Price controls_ Due in part to limited levels of competition, the UR continues to support the market through price regulation. Accordingly, while RoI electricity market prices have been fully deregulated since April 1, 2011, NI’s residential market is still subject to regulation. Power NI and PPB are subject to price controls, defined in formulae set out in Power NI Energy’s electricity supply license, which limit the revenues they may earn and the prices they may charge. The principles of price regulation employed in the relevant license conditions reflect the general duties of the UR and the DfE under the relevant legislation including the need to ensure that licensees are able to finance their authorized activities. Power NI must supply residential electricity at regulated tariffs. The tariffs are currently based on an allowed revenue model, which allows Power NI to recover the UR’s forecast of its operating cost and residual depreciation plus a net margin. The regulatory model has an incentive mechanism by which Power NI is allowed to retain savings achieved through efficiency for at least the period of the price control. If the amount of revenue recovered in any one year exceeds or falls short of the amount allowed by the relevant price control formula, a correction factor (a “K factor”) operates in the following year that requires either a repayment of any surplus with interest or a recovery of any deficit with interest, as appropriate. A surplus is referred to as an over-recovery and a deficit as an under-recovery. In the formulation of its regulated tariffs, Power NI is allowed to pass through to customers all underlying wholesale costs, subject to an economic purchasing obligation. Power NI is required to submit a forecast of all its input costs for each tariff review, which is then subject to review with the UR. Following completion of the review, the new tariffs would apply, with the possibility that they could be changed at the beginning of each quarter if actual costs and revenues do not stay within tolerance (i.e., plus or minus 2.5%). PPB’s price control mechanism provides an entitlement in respect of PPB’s own costs through the receipt of an allowance (effectively a management fee), together with a further amount covering certain depreciation costs, return on PPB’s assets and an allowance in respect of pension deficit costs. The price control also ----- incentivizes PPB through a ‘gain share’ mechanism whereby PPB is entitled to retain a share of any surplus revenues from trading contracted capacity in the SEM or ancillary services payments which exceed the cost of procuring wholesale power under the Ballylumford contract. Under the ‘gain share’ PPB retains 20% of any surplus up to £10 million and 10% of any surplus in excess of £10 million. -----

_Renewables_ Renewable energy continues to be a key priority in NI and the RoI and both governments have set targets for increasing the proportion of electricity sourced from renewables. NI’s energy strategy targets the achievement of 80% renewable electricity by 2030 and the RoI Climate Action Plan also sets an 80% renewable electricity target by 2030. As at March 31, 2023, the Renewables segment owns and operates 309MW onshore wind generation assets across the RoI and NI, and has a pipeline of 49MW onshore wind generation assets under construction and 218MW of onshore wind generation assets in development. The Renewables segment also has a pipeline of 628MW of solar PV projects in development, and is currently commissioning a hydrogen electrolyzer onsite at one of its NI onshore wind farms. In addition, the Group is also progressing the development of two offshore wind generation projects off the coast of Ireland totaling up to 1.8GW. The Renewables segment’s operational and inconstruction onshore wind generation assets are outside of the Restricted Group. Similarly, assets in relation to the pipeline of other wind projects and solar PV projects, are also owned by Unrestricted Subsidiaries and therefore outside of the Restricted Group. The Restricted Group received distribution from the unrestricted subsidiaries under the Existing Notes Indenture totaling €61.8 million during Fiscal Year 2023. The Renewables segment also purchases renewable electricity through PPAs covering 1,247MW of operating renewable capacity as at March 31, 2023. Energia Group was the first independent supplier to participate ----- in the deregulated electricity market and an early mover on offering offtake contracts to third parties. Its first renewable PPA was signed in 2002. The Group estimates that it currently represents approximately 21% of the Irish market for Renewable Obligation Certificates (“ROCs”) and Renewable Energy Feed-In Tariff (“REFIT”) supported wind PPAs. The Renewables segment provides the Energia Group with further access to regulated renewable support mechanisms, with minimal capital requirements and potential upside to the extent of future increases in wholesale power prices, as well as positioning Energia and Power NI as ‘green’ suppliers and enhancing relationships and presence with key stakeholders within the sector. In addition, the Group has a entered into a REFA with Microsoft designed to meet a substantial proportion of their electricity demand in Ireland, whereby the output from the Renewables segment’s pipeline of in-development onshore wind projects (including the 49MW of renewable capacity currently under construction) and solar PV projects are expected to be supported by corporate PPAs with the technology company. Energia Group’s Renewables segment revenue for Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022 was €427.2 million and €401.9 million, respectively, and its Adjusted EBITDA during these periods was €224.5 million and €211.5 million, respectively. _Flexible Generation_ The Flexible Generation segment undertakes trading, regulation and asset management activities on behalf of the Group. This includes the day-to-day operation and commercial optimization of two CCGT plants (Huntstown 1 and Huntstown 2) owned by the Group. The two Huntstown CCGTs are highly reliable, flexible and efficient plants, and their strategic location in the constrained Dublin area ensures at least one unit is running on most days of the year. Moreover, the Huntstown plants have the technical capacity to provide system-critical “Delivering a Secure, Sustainable Electricity System” (“DS3”) ancillary services, the importance of which has been increasing as the proportion of electricity generated by wind in Ireland has been growing. As at March 31, 2023, Huntstown has a total combined generation capacity of 747MW, which is able to supply approximately 10% of peak demand on an all-island basis (based on estimated peak demand of approximately 7,700MW). We believe that the two Huntstown CCGTs are critical to the security of electricity supply in the Dublin area. Under the Single Electricity Market (“SEM”), the Huntstown plants sell the generated energy into the Day-Ahead (“DAM”), Intra-Day (“IDM”) and Balancing Mechanism (“BM”) markets and sell capacity several years in advance via ‘Reliability Options’ as part of the Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (“CRM”). The Reliability Options have been awarded to the Group’s Huntstown plants for the current and next four capacity years, and include a clearing price of €83,050/MW for the capacity year 2026 to 2027. See also “Industry—The _All-Island Single Electricity Market—Energy Trading Arrangements—Capacity Remuneration Mechanism (CRM).” Huntstown sells energy at the market clearing prices in the DAM and IDM as well as receive (or in some_ cases make) other payments for energy through constraint payments in the BM. The Huntstown plants also receive payments associated with DS3 ancillary services. The Group has also recently developed and commissioned a 50MW battery storage project in NI which is operated and traded by the Flexible Generation business. The project has been awarded a 10-year capacity contract commencing in the capacity year 2022/2023, at a clearing price of £78,600/MW for 8.15MW of its 11.3MW derated capacity. The Group plans to develop a further pipeline of battery storage projects, which we expect will strengthen the Group’s position for future capacity auctions and provide an additional source for ancillary revenue. The Group has also entered into a contract with EirGrid to provide 50MW of emergency gas generation located at the Huntstown site for a duration of three years, extendible by EirGrid to five years. Construction of this emergency gas generation project commenced in December 2022 and is planned to be completed by the end of 2023. The Group is developing a 165MW data center at its Huntstown campus in Dublin. The proposed data center has a grid connection offer and the lands necessary for the project have been acquired. Planning consent for the data center was received in April 2022 but the decision was appealed and the planning application is currently being considered by An Bord Pleanála, RoI’s national independent planning body. The Group expects _An Bord Pleanála to issue its decision in the near term and does not believe that there are grounds on which_ planning permission should be refused. The Group has entered into a contract with an international hyperscale technology company for a long term lease by it of the electrical infrastructure, buildings and integrated equipment at the data center. Capital expenditure in respect of the development of the data center was €20.0 million in Fiscal Year 2023 and €11.1 million in Fiscal Year 2022, primarily, in respect of land and development of electrical connections. Going forward, the Flexible Generation segment’s investment in the proposed data center in respect ----- of the development of the data halls is expected to be an unrestricted investment and therefore outside of the Restricted Group. Investment in respect of the purchase of land, the design and build of all the high voltage electrical infrastructure (including a gas insulated substation and high voltage transformer switchyard) will be within the Restricted Group. The Flexible Generation segment also includes the Group’s PPB business which administers 600MW of contracted generation capacity from the Ballylumford power station in NI, which is subject to price control and entitles it to an allowance (effectively a management fee). This legacy PPB contract will expire in September 2023 in accordance with its terms. The PPB contract generated €14.6 million, €8.5 million and €9.3 million of EBITDA during the Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2022 and Fiscal Year 2021, respectively. For Fiscal Year 2023 and Fiscal Year 2022, Flexible Generation generated €1,769.7 million and €989.5 million in revenue, respectively, and €204.7 million and €104.0 million in Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, based on, or after taking into account the adjustments for over/under recovery against, the regulated entitlement of PPB. _Customer Solutions_ The Group’s Customer Solutions business operates under the Energia and Power NI brands. Energia Energia is a price control unregulated retail supply business, which supplies electricity and natural gas to residential and business customers in the RoI. Business customers include LEU and SME customers. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2021, Energia supplied electricity to 14% of the LEU market, 30% of the SME market and 12% of the residential market in the RoI in terms of consumption. As part of its hedging strategy, the Group’s Flexible Generation segment undertakes wholesale electricity, natural gas, carbon and green certificate trading activities on behalf of the Customer Solutions segment. Power NI Power NI is the incumbent electricity supplier in NI, supplying electricity primarily to residential customers. While the residential electricity supply market in NI is open to competition, Power NI remains the biggest supplier with a 55.0% market share of residential supply in terms of consumption during the twelve months ended December 31, 2022. As a result, Power NI is still regarded as the dominant supplier and is therefore subject to price regulation. As a regulated business, Power NI is subject to price control which permits it to recover an allowance calculated by reference to its forecasted operating costs at the time of the relevant price control, plus an allowed margin based on a percentage of forecasted regulated revenue. On January 26, 2023, the UR confirmed the extension of the existing price control (which applies in respect to residential customers) to March 31, 2025. In addition, Power NI supplies electricity to business customers in the unregulated market and secures additional revenues through off-take from certain contracted smaller scale third party renewable generators (which are reported through the Renewables segment). In addition, the Customer Solutions business also offers energy efficiency services and car charging solutions to its customers across Ireland.
